PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ARCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 139 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised- that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing, therefore your petitioners urge that:
1. All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the national average weekly male earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the pensioner health benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973. Reintroduction of Medibank, in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government inject $200m into State housing authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chipp I present the following petition from 50 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUTTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 11 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate and Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That since December 1975 the people of East Timor have been living under extremely repressive conditions and many tens of thousands have died. Australia has acquiesced with and assisted the Indonesian Military in its subjugation of one of our nearest neighbours.

The people of East Timor lost 40,000 of their own defending Australian commandos in W.W.2. Indonesia gained its Independence from the Dutch in 1949 with effective assistance from the Australian Government and Australian Trade unions.
The East Timorese have an inalienable right to self-determination and independence.
Australia is ideally placed to help the East Timorese in their hour of need, and ought to use its influence to inhibit further military expansion by Indonesia in the region.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate and Parliament assembled will :
1. Recognise the inalienable right of the East Timorese to self-determination and independence, and reverse Australia's recognition of the Indonesian annexation of East Timor.

2. Initiate diplomatic action in support of self-determination and draw attention to the lack of free migration from East Timor at the United Nations and at all other appropriate international forums.
3. Cease all military aid to Indonesia until there is a complete withdrawal of Indonesian occupation forces from East Timor.
4. Suspend negotiations with Indonesia on the Australia-East Timor seabed boundary.
5. Allow Fretilin representatives into Australia to speak to supporters here and to give their account of the situation in East Timor.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HILL

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 79 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That we are concerned for the welfare of Mr Mart Niklus, a leading Estonian and Baltic human rights activist presently imprisoned in the Soviet Union in Perm Labour Camp No. 389/36, and in ill health.

2. The Australian Government has approved the sponsored entry of Mr Mart Niklus into Australia and we urge that the Government use its good offices to make representations to the Government of the Soviet Union to promptly facilitate his release and grant him a passport and exit visa.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 257 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are concerned that the introduction of a loans scheme for tertiary students will replace T.E.A.S. allowances. And that the repayments of such loans will place an unjust burden on young Australians in their first years in the workforce. And that the Senate has already been made aware of the plight of tertiary students in the three volumes of ''Studies of Tertiary Student Finances'', tabled in the Senate on 15th October, 1981.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Immediately, and without reference to a Senate Committee, reject any legislation introducing a loans scheme for tertiary students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 29 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That citizens of South Australia view with great alarm the removal of the Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare services for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled , should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIDDONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 52 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Ex-Servicemen's and Women's Pension Association is a body formed for the express purpose of obtaining a service Pension for all Ex-Service Personnel at Sixty years of age for Men and fifty-five years of age for Women regardless of where they served during the 1939-45 war.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should give urgent consideration to a favourable decision to the granting of the Service Pension to all Ex-Service Personnel who served their country in time of need and who did not serve overseas through no fault of their own. The Service Pension is presently only granted to Returned Ex-Service Personnel.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIBRAA

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 16 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c)that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHIPP

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RYAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 95 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigine Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests .

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland Government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1978 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self-management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUTTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 146 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List. Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P.

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.7 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardships and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIBRAA

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 96 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JESSOP

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 105 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown;
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened;
Humbly Petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post;
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriage between close relatives by blood or marriage;
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will;
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage;
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation;
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intorable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be concious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUTTON

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders, from 53 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasma,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(ii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation. We agree that:
1. PVR will inhibit the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding.
2. PVR will not enhance Australia's access to plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
3. PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
4. PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by the foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
5. The proprietary rights granted by the PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union, and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened.
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post;
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage;
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will;
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage;
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation;
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for out nation .

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Retail Markets

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SWEENEY ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ALLEGED PAYMENTS TO THE MARITIME UNIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether it is a fact that the Sweeney Royal Commission into Alleged Payments to the Maritime Unions, which reported in 1976, referred to the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in Victoria. Is it not a fact that the Sweeney Royal Commission referred to some activities of the Union which centred around tax evasion? In view of this, did the Royal Commissioner seek an extension of time to investigate these activities? Was an extension of time refused by the Fraser Government and was that decision announced by the Prime Minister? If so, why? Is it not the case that the Government was apprised of the possible extent of tax avoidance practices centred on the Painters and Dockers Union in 1976? Why was no action taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any specific details regarding the Sweeney Royal Commission or the questions asked as to whether it, in fact, made some references to tax evasion or asked for an extension of time. I do have a very clear recollection, as I am asked what is the action of the Federal Government, that this Government, unlike other governments, set up the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It, indeed, widened the terms of reference and extended the time of that Commission. That Commission has now reported that the Painters and Dockers Union is not an authentic trade union in the ordinary sense but, in fact, is a gathering of criminals who are recruiting criminals for criminal purposes. That same gathering is affiliated with the Australian Labor Party which sits opposite .

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question in view of the Minister's answer. Is it not a fact that the Labor Government established the Royal Commission into Alleged Payments to the Maritime Unions and did not the Sweeney Royal Commission in its report refer to criminal activities of painters and dockers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My belief is that the Labor Government set up the Sweeney Royal Commission. I have no doubt that its report did refer to criminal activities of painters and dockers. But it seems that the Labor Party, with that knowledge in its mind, nevertheless has found it comfortable to be affiliated over the years with just such criminal behaviour. But, as to the specifics of the earlier question, I will seek the information and let the honourable senator know.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer to a possible problem concerning quarantine regulations for Australian private yacht owners who undertake pleasure cruises and take their animal pets with them to South East Asian countries, as distinct from foreign yachts coming in at recognised ports of entry. As a consequence, these pets may come into contact with infectious diseases, such as rabies, which is a reportable disease under Australian quarantine regulations. Could the Minister advise the Senate as to what quarantine provisions are in force, and whether they are strictly adhered, to protect Australia against diseases brought into the country by these animals on private Australian yachts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Australian yachts do travel extensively around the region. I was not aware that it was normal practice to take animal pets on such trips. I can advise the honourable senator that, as he would know, yachts returning from overseas are subject to normal quarantine requirements. They are advised that they can enter Australia only via a first port of entry where they would be subject to quarantine clearance, so that it is not appropriate for them to return other than through a first port of entry where they can get quarantine clearance.

ANSWER.PARA: If an animal is on board, the master is required to confine the animal and to enter into a bond that the animal will not be brought ashore or be allowed to come into contact with an Australian animal, and the yacht is only permitted to moor mid-water, in that way trying to hold the animal isolated. The animal remains bonded on board the yacht for a period determined by the species of animal. That is laid down in the quarantine regulations. The previous movement of the vessel will help to determine what that period will be, depending upon which countries may have been visited. For example, the yacht may have been to a disease free area or it may have been to a disease infected area. That will vary the period of quarantine laid down. In the case of a dog or cat, the period would not be less than nine months of which, if previously in a rabies free area , some could be spent in a quarantine station. In the case of birds, the period is indefinite if previously in an infected area. I am advised that violation of any of the bond conditions can result in destruction of the animal, in forfeiture of the bond and in prosecution under the Quarantine Act.

Coming as he does from the Capricorn area of Queensland and having the interest he does in the welfare of his State, I can well understand Senator Collard's concern with this matter and I hope that the information has been helpful to him .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I table the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Veterans' Affairs present the second reading speech of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill 1980 to the Senate on 2 December 1980? I ask whether, in the course of that speech, the following passage occurred:

QUESTION.PARA: As I have said, existing legislation has not been found adequate to deal with the evasion practices I have outlined.

Did the Minister satisfy himself of the veracity of this statement before presenting it to the Senate? Could he outline the opinions he reviewed to satisfy himself that he was not misleading the Senate as to the necessity for this legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose we should congratulate Senator Colston on the ingenuity of his question. Of course, I am without a copy of the speech immediately before him, which he acknowledges was made some two years ago. I should like to have the opportunity of referring to that speech before making any further comment on it.

—Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware of a report conducted by Monash University researchers which states that the Olympic Dam copper, uranium and gold project in South Australia would generate 13,800 jobs and inject $360m a year into South Australia's production during its initial stages and far greater financial benefits in the future? Does the Minister agree that these projections are of great significance to Australia, particularly South Australia, with respect to economic growth? Is the Government concerned at the report's warning that policies such as automatic wage indexation may prevent the full realisation of employment benefits of the project? Can the Minister say what the effect would be of the commitment by both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to the repudiation of existing uranium contracts on maximum employment and production benefits flowing to the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a report in the Australian of approximately a week ago regarding a survey done by a number of people into the potential of the Roxby Downs project. I have advice from my Department, particularly the Bureau of Mineral Resources, as to the significance and potential of Roxby Downs for the future. It has been suggested that the development of Roxby Downs would create some 18,600 jobs. My advice is that the mineralisation in Roxby Downs is estimated to be worth in excess of $A140 billion. It is very large by world standards and there is every expectation that the zone of mineralisation extends further to the north-west and the south-east than has yet been established. I am advised that the copper contained in the deposit amounts to about 30 million tonnes. This is around six times as much copper as is at Mount Isa and about two and a half times Australia's total identified resources in other ore deposits. As we understand it, the uranium content is about 1.2 million tonnes of uranium oxide. That is estimated to be the equivalent of about 20 per cent of the identified world high grade uranium resources. These figures were provided to me by objective sources.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked about the significance of such an undertaking to South Australia and to Australia generally. Clearly it would be of enormous significance. I remind the Australian people that the International Energy Agency has made it clear that the world will not be able to maintain its living standards or provide energy for such living standards without a very substantial increase in the use of nuclear power for electric power generation. Indeed, Australia will be one of the few countries capable of providing that energy to maintain the living standards of other countries. The answer is quite clear: If, as is now emerging, the Australian Labor Party is seeking to repudiate uranium contracts then there would be a disastrous effect not only upon the potential development of Roxby Downs but also upon the capacity of the world outside Australia to get the necessary energy source. I understand that the Australian Democrats have a similar attitude towards the export of uranium. It would be an outrage if such action were to deny to the people of the world the energy they need to maintain their living standards and to have both economic and political stability. Such action would be detrimental to South Australia, to Australia, to employment in Australia and the the living standards of the people of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the document from which the Minister has just quoted be tabled.
—I table it.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to the fact that the allowance for the wife of a totally incapacitated ex- servicemen has not risen since 1964 when it was, as it still is, $8.10 a fortnight. Had the rate of inflation been taken into account the allowance now would be $30.20 a fortnight. Considering the fact that the wives of totally incapacitated ex-servicemen, through their devotion, have suffered-various studies bear this out-considerable nervous and physical stress and that the nursing that they perform has kept the costs of medical treatment for such veterans to a minimum, will the Government give attention to raising the allowance paid to wives of totally incapacitated ex-servicemen in recognition of that activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin has a couple of different ideas mixed up in his question. He talked about the wives of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans who are in receipt of pensions and also about allowances which are paid to the wives as dependants. He points out that that allowance has not increased since 1964. The reason is that successive governments over that period have decided there is a need to ensure that it is the veteran who receives the most benefit from what are limited resources. Therefore it has been the policy of governments to ensure that funds are directed to that end. That has meant that over this period there has in fact been a decline in real terms in the amount of the dependant's allowance paid to wives.

ANSWER.PARA: However, a further allowance, known as an attendant's allowance, is payable to those disabled veterans who have considerable problems along the lines that Senator Macklin described in his question. I think it is probably that point which he seeks to address his question to. That is a matter which receives attention in each Budget and consequently it is up for consideration every year at Budget time. Recent increases in the allowance have been made. I think we may need to have further discussions with Senator Macklin if he wants to pursue the matter further. I am sure that after he examines the matter a little further he will understand the reasoning behind the Government's approach to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer explain why a quadriplegic in a recently well publicised case in Queensland, who requires his wheelchair for 75 per cent of the time for the production of his assessable income as a university lecturer, had his claims for depreciation, maintenance and insurance disallowed by a Taxation Board of Review in a decision in May this year? Is the Minister aware that another university lecturer had his claim allowed for depreciation of a briefcase in which he carried lecture notes, as well as, presumably, his lunch?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of either instance concerning the allowance of claims that have been made by people with regard to things that are required in the performance of their duties. I will seek to have some consideration given to the matter. I do not know whether there is any special significance in the matter relating to the wheelchair or other depreciation that might have been claimed, but if there is anything of significance I will see that it is reported to the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister not agree that there is a substantial difference in granting a depreciation allowance for a briefcase and denying a depreciation allowance for a wheelchair which is essential to get to the lecture room?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I said, I am not aware whether there is any significance in the two claims; one being allowed and the other disallowed. I do not know whether it is a--
—He pays sales tax on his wheelchair too.
—The sales tax may not have been applicable in one case. I am not sure of this. I said I will have it checked. If there is anything I can advise, I will do so.

—I refer the Attorney-General to a letter which Mr Ian Warner, President of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party, has written to the Australian Financial Review in which he says that that branch has ' constantly' held-I ask the Attorney particularly to note the word 'constantly'- the position that persons who appear to have broken the law with respect to tax evasion should be prosecuted under existing law. I ask the Attorney, who is incidentally a member of that branch, whether he can give an assurance that the branch was not in receipt of any information from his Department as to the incidence of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes which caused it to adopt that position. I further ask whether he would be kind enough to tell the Senate just how long is 'constantly' and when the Western Australian branch adopted that position.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the letter from Mr Warner referred to by Senator Elstob. The letter referred to the opposition that has been officially expressed by the State Council of the Western Australia Liberal Party, by Mr Warner personally and by others to the proposed legislation to recover the tax lost from vendor shareholders through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. That is one measure which the Government has announced. The legislation is now very well advanced in drafting and will be presented to the Parliament as soon as possible. Mr Warner, as I understand it, is arguing, as indeed other people have argued and as I understand the Opposition argues, that the way to tackle this problem is not with special legislation but by prosecutions. The argument by Mr Warner to which Senator Elstob is referring seems to me to be a familiar argument. I have heard it in the debate from the Opposition as well as from Mr Warner, Mr Bill Mitchell and others. But the fact of the matter is that the Government will not in any way be deterred by these arguments that have been put forward. As the Government pressed on with the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill, it will be pressing on with the legislation to recover the money.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say that despite all the talk of what remedies-civil or criminal-may be available, civil remedies, in particular, are being examined to establish what alternatives there could be. But I am quite convinced that there is no satisfactory alternative and that if we are really serious about recovering the tax that has been lost, special legislation is desirable and probably quite necessary. So I think that the Government's approach, particularly in view of the sort of slurs coming from the Opposition in relation to the Government's attitude on this, should be judged in the light of its firm determination in the teeth of a lot of opposition from, as the honourable senator says, the Western Australian branch or Mr Warner to proceed with legislation which it believes is the most satisfactory way of tackling this problem.

Senator Elstob asked whether the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party was in receipt of any information in the possession of my Department or presumably myself. I can assure the Senate most firmly that it was not in possession of any information that came from me or of which I was in any way aware. I am very satisfied that the officers of my Department would have at all times observed the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Following the success of what is now the Cain-led socialist government in Victoria in selling itself to left wing pressure groups in exchange for electoral support, is the Minister aware of a campaign by the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation to offer electoral support to any political party that is prepared to be bought? Will the Government succumb to such practices or will it continue to allocate resources for education in the interests of all Australian students?
—You should look at the Liberal Party in Western Australia.

—I am becoming accustomed to any matter relevant to the Australian Capital Territory being ridiculed by the Opposition. This electorate will come to know what the Opposition really thinks about the national capital. The third part of the question is: In light of the 1982 Budget, does the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation have any valid grounds for attempting to blackmail the Government in the Minister's area of responsibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the question from Senator Reid. I was aware of the very active and open support by the teachers' organisations in Victoria for the then Opposition -support which extended to quite massive and major financial help. Subsequent to the Victorian election, I have read some of the publications of Victorian teachers in which they make no secret of the fact that they were playing a political rather than an industrial role during that election. I am also aware, from contact which I have had in my State of New South Wales, of the desire of the teachers federation there to hear from political parties what their policies are in education because it has an inclination or disposition to consider lending its support actively to one or other party during the next political campaign. In fact-I must thank the teachers federation for this-I had the opportunity to appear before one of its council meetings and to talk to its members about what the Government has done and is doing. I was able to point out to the teachers, rather to their surprise, that total recurrent support by the Fraser Government for government schools last year, this year and next year is greater than it was in the last year, this year of the Labor Government. That is something which had not been pointed out to them and which they were surprised to hear.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the situation in the Australian Capital Territory, I must confess to Senator Reid that it has not come to my attention what line the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation is taking. But I would not be at all surprised, in the light of what has happened in New South Wales and Victoria, that it might take an active line. The point of Senator Reid's question, and with which I agree, is that this Government is not about to make policy under threat or under duress. We will judge the issues in education on the basis of educational merit and on the basis of the pursuit of educational outcomes. We will receive arguments on that basis whether they be in New South Wales, Victoria or the Australian Capital Territory. I am sure that Senator Reid would want the Government to continue to take that line towards policy formation.

As to the 1982 Budget, it is of course well known now that in the Budget we have increased support for students at a whole range of levels. We have increased postgraduate awards by 48 per cent. We have increased the means test level for the secondary allowance scheme by 44 per cent. We have increased our contribution to support of schools and our contribution in all educational areas . In terms of our financial support for education, we have a very good case to make and there is no justification for a campaign of the kind which Senator Reid suggested may be under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Attorney-General inform the Senate what procedures were used and are currently being used by the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth or any other State capital to report on action to be taken or any investigation, opinion or any other matter being handled by that office? How regularly are reports sent? Has any direction been given by the Crown Solicitor's Office on action to be taken on any such reports received from the Perth office or any other office? Have any such reports been directed to the Attorney-General or his Department for attention? Were any such reports or copies thereof forwarded to the Australian Taxation Office?
—Senator Jones's question seeks a great deal of detail. I will take note of it and provide a considered answer.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen the front page article in this morning's Daily Telegraph in which it is alleged that an individual by the name of Rocky Stone, who died recently, had received more than $100,000 in fraudulent unemployment benefit payments? What action has the Department of Social Security taken or is it taking on this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say that I was delighted when I walked into Parliament House this morning and saw the front page of that newspaper with the headline ' Dole Man Who Was Paid More Than PM!'. I was relieved to find that it was not a new incident but one that had been mentioned in the Press on a previous occasion . The report arises from facts that were discovered following the death of somebody who had been claiming social security benefit under a series of names. I am not in a position to verify totally the very large amounts mentioned in the newspaper reports, but I can confirm to the Senate that it does appear that very substantial amounts of money were collected by that individual.
—He is in the arms of Satan, no doubt, now.

—I do suggest that if there is a special place in hell for tax dodgers there is probably also a similar place in hell for people who rip off the social security system, certainly on the scale that apparently was attempted by the late Mr Stone. In a sense, the report is useful because it provides a balance to the concerns which are often expressed in the media, particularly the media in New South Wales, about the fact that my Department has, as part of its role, the suppression of fraudulent claims on the social security system. I am getting used to picking up newspapers which contain such edifying articles as ' How to beat the social security snoopers'. I am getting used to picking up newspapers which make critical comments about the fact that the Department is forced to make inquiries to try to prevent abuse of the system. It is valuable to be reminded that, unfortunate as it may be, there are individuals who seek to use a system which is there to prevent hardship in Australia to their advantage in a way that is just as fraudulent as is any rip-off of the taxation system.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as this fraud is concerned, I can only say that we are in the position of making retrospective inquiries which cannot affect any future claims since the man is dead. Whether we will be able to recover any of the moneys I do not know. What is quite clear from the information that I have to date is that this fraud was reasonably sophisticated in that the forms of identification required by my Department were obtained in a variety of names. It is a clear, straightforward case of fraudulent activity and I would simply say that unfortunately, while there are people who are prepared to be dishonest in that way and while we have to have a system which is manageable by the great bulk of honest people who require the support of my Department, it will be true that cases of this sort will occur. I can only assure the Senate that every effort is made by us to reduce them to a minimum. I ask all honourable senators, in considering the matter that has been raised by Senator Scott, to remember the very difficult balance that has to be struck in the welfare system between having one which is operable by the needy and often defenceless in the community and one which is reasonably secure against this sort of depredation. It is a very difficult balance to strike. I believe that the officials of my Department have a very difficult job and I ask all honourable senators, and indeed the community, to support them in their very difficult work, rather than run off and criticise them every time some journalist writes an article about social security snoopers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH GRANTS COMMISSION: TAX SHARING ARRANGEMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Acting Treasurer. Did the Commonwealth Grants Commission carry out an investigation into what share of the tax reimbursement pool each State should receive, so that each State can provide, without imposing taxes and charges at levels appreciably different from the levels of taxes and charges imposed by other States, government services at standards not appreciably different from the standards of government services provided by other States? Was this the first investigation that had ever been carried out to assess the fair relativities of the States? Has the Government accepted that the recommendations of the Grants Commission are fair and reasonable? While recognising that implementing these recommendations could cause short term difficulties for those States which received a reduced share, is the Government committed to the recommendations of the Grants Commission as a long term objective? If the Government is committed to the recommendations of the Grants Commission, how long will it be before those recommendations are completely in effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an extensive inquiry into the matters raised by Senator Hamer, and the Grants Commission did come to the view that a change was desirable. I think it is understood that the present arrangements will continue until 1985 and the relativities to apply after that date will be a matter of further consideration before that time. A number of recommendations were made by the Grants Commission and perhaps it would be more appropriate if I were to give a considered answer to Senator Hamer by letter or have it included in Hansard because some detail might be of interest to other honourable senators .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Treasurer. What action has the Government taken so far in order to prevent the tax avoidance racket among car dealers that it is claimed is costing Australia $250m a year? Can the Minister confirm or deny the claim that one transaction attracted $18 sales tax on a car worth $50,000? Has the Government investigated claims that the promoter of one of the most popular schemes has made up to $300,000 a day in commission? Is the Government aware that Mr Cosmos, the President of the New South Wales Chamber of Automotive Industries, has asserted that one dealer was said to have made $3m over the past eight months? Finally, can the Minister add anything to the answer given to Question on Notice No. 1964 asked by me on 9 March. In that answer, the Treasurer stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Administrative action has been intensified to bring matters to a head as soon as possible and this action is proving successful.
When will the Minister be in a position to justify the claims made in that answer to my question on notice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have a brief comment on this from the Commissioner of Taxation because there has been some recent publicity on the matter raised by Senator Robert Ray. As was said earlier, the investigative activity has been increased and the Taxation Commissioner does say that there has been a large degree of investigation over recent months. Several assessments refuting the efficacy of the schemes and imposing tax plus additional tax by way of penalty at the rate of 100 per cent of the tax assessed have been issued on participants and further assessments will be made as the necessary information is gathered. In some of the cases the investigations have been assisted by the conduct of search and seizure exercises by the Australian Federal Police for the purpose of obtaining evidence of suspected offences under the Crimes Act 1914 and/or the Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos 1 to 9) 1930. I will have the other matters mentioned in another question and in the question today referred through the Treasurer's office to the Commissioner and I will see that an early response is given.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It concerns a rebel with a cause, brother Jack Mundey, in the current Builders Labourers Federation ballot. What role has the Department played in relation to a request by him concerning the ballot? He had some reservations about some aspects of it. What was the final outcome of his representations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a little information about the current affairs of Mr Mundey, who I understand is a candidate for the position of New South Wales State Secretary of the Builders Labourers Federation. I think a ballot was to have been conducted by the BLF on 3 September. In that sense the information I have is historical. There were reports that Mr Mundey had claimed to have been harassed by present officers of the BLF-that is, the pre-election officers of the BLF in New South Wales-following his attempts to have the ballot conducted through the Industrial Registrar and that the alleged action of those officials was in breach of the election provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act . However, at the time at which I was given advice on the matter, which was before the election, Mr Mundey had taken no action under the provisions of the Act to apply to have the ballot conducted under the control of the Industrial Registrar or to have the Registrar inquire into alleged malpractice by current BLF officers. In other words, it is not a situation in which one would expect action to be taken at the initiative of the Department. Rather, there are procedures under the Act which are available to a person who thinks he is being treated improperly under the Act to seek the assistance of the Commission. So my advice was-certainly to the point at which I had received advice-that Mr Mundey had not sought the protection of those provisions, notwithstanding their availability.

ANSWER.PARA: In those circumstances no action would have been taken of the sort raised in the honourable senator's question, and no action, I believe, should have been taken. I shall check with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to see whether there is any subsequent material, but I suspect that if there were such material I would have been given a further briefing note on it. I think that this may be a case in which there have been public allegations, no attempt has been made to use the protective provisions of the Act, and hence the election would have proceeded as it was conducted by the union. Senator Mulvihill might like to let us know what the results were.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce to the fact that off-shore tourist islands have not been included in the Budget list of users subject to diesel fuel tax rebate. Because of their isolation the off-shore resort islands are unable to obtain any of the services taken for granted by the general community, such as water, sewerage, transport and power, so the cost of power on the islands is already substantially higher than mainland electricity charges, and there is absolutely no other way to obtain it than by use of diesel generators. I point out that because the islands have no public roads it is impossible to use the fuel for any other purpose, and the rebate therefore could not be subject to abuse. In view of these facts, will the Minister give consideration to allowing off-shore tourist islands to claim the tax rebate on diesel fuel used by them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the Minister for Education regards himself, I think, as more of an expert on this area of Australia than I, but I have the responsibility here for the Department of Industry and Commerce. There is, unfortunately, no assistance, solace or hope that I can offer to the honourable senator in response to her question. As she will know, we changed our approach to diesel excise in the recent Budget and all diesel fuel will now bear a full rate of excise duty. Unlike the previous exemptions which were provided to certain users, the present position is that specified users may now claim rebates for specific categories of off-road end use. The categories eligible for rebate, as determined by the Government and announced in the Budget, are domestic use, hospitals, nursing and convalescent homes, and the agricultural, mining, fishing and forestry industries. All other end users, including the tourist industry, are not eligible for the rebate.

ANSWER.PARA: I appreciate the honourable senator's concern for the tourist industry and for the off-shore tourist resorts, but it would be inequitable to provide a rebate to off-shore tourist resorts and not to on-shore tourist activities or, for that matter, to other activities on off-shore islands. Whilst I shall draw the honourable senator's question to the attention of the Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce-in the absence of Sir Phillip Lynch-I would not hold out any hope for her that there will be a change to the classifications announced in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question without notice to the Minister for Social Security. It relates not to someone trying to rip off the system but to two people who, it would appear to me at least, were trying to use the system in an appropriate manner. Is the Minister aware of an incident which occurred in South Australia recently in which two men in receipt of unemployment benefits pooled their resources to purchase a truck in order to seek work from house to house, and promptly had their unemployment benefits discontinued despite the fact that they had not earned any income? I point out that after some publicity over the affair their unemployment benefits were restored, althought they are being kept under review on a regular basis according to the men's subsequent income. What steps are officers of the Department of Social Security required to take in cases of unemployed people seeking unemployment benefits when they are not in receipt of income but are actively seeking work in the manner referred to, or in a similar manner-that is, with the aim of becoming self-employed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sorts of facts raised by the honourable senator in her question give rise to some difficult judgments which have to be made by my Department on the administration of unemployment benefit. The basic rule is fairly straightforward. To be eligible for unemployment benefit one must be available for work and seeking work. The so-called work test is no more than that. If a person wishes to claim the payment of unemployment benefit he must be available for whatever work is on offer and he must be actively seeking that work. Of course, many people in the community are self-employed. It is unfortunately true that many of those people are self-employed but not profitably. It is not unknown for people running businesses of one sort or another-these range from the large business down to the very small one-man business-to be working without necessarily making an income. I suppose that if we search the bankruptcy lists we will find plenty of examples of that.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty arises when somebody is not employed but sets about establishing a small business or some form of self-employment and thereby puts himself outside the category of being available for work. That distinction is the one which I think gives rise to the difficulty that was apparently faced by these two individuals. I must confess that with some 400,000 plus cases on the unemployment benefit list at the moment I am not familar with either that case or, indeed, the great bulk of the circumstances. The difficulties described by the honourable senator in her question would arise from that difficult decision which officers would have had to make as to whether the individuals concerned were seeking work and were available for work or were, in fact, conducting a business as independent contractors. Obviously mistakes can be made in that area . If the facts are as outlined by the honourable senator the second look would appear to have produced the view that these men were merely seeking work and were not currently self-employed. But I will get the facts examined and drawn to my attention so that I can be sure that the administration is in order.

I have had quite a number of these cases drawn to my attention. They involve people who have lost their traditional work as employees and, being of an industrious and perhaps more imaginative nature, have registered a business name and set themselves up to attract work as independent contractors. In some of those cases the people involved are simply not unemployed in the sense that is required for the payment of benefit. I make the point in defence of my officers that in general a genuine attempt is made to pay people the benefits to which they are entitled. The difficulty arises in those cases where a view is formed that the entitlement simply does not exist under the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. At the risk of raising the Minister's hackles I wish to ask him about the methods used sometimes by his Department to detect social security fraud or wrongful payment of benefits and not about the fact that that occurs which, of course, we all deplore. Has the Minister seen the guidelines for field officers conducting domestic circumstances reviews of supporting parent beneficiaries, widows and Class A pensioners issued by his New South Wales office in June? Are these guidelines currently used in New South Wales or any other State? Do they require field officers to collect information, before seeing single parents, from State housing authorities, local councils, electricity, gas or water authorities, Telecom Australia, employers, neighbours and even their children's schools? Are there any field officer instructions which explain or provide that an explanation be made to single parents that they have the right to refuse entrance into their homes, that they can answer questions instead at the social security office or that they have the right to have a third party present during such interviews? What instructions do field officers have about allowing single parents to know what information has been collected against them so that they can refute such information if it is false? Finally, have the Minister or his Department endorsed these guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question contains a number of details which I will address when I see them in writing. Perhaps I will answer the question in more general terms now and go over the answer to see whether it needs supplementing later. Yes, I have seen the guidelines issued by my Department in New South Wales for the guidance of officers in that State who are operating in perhaps one of the most difficult areas of administration-namely, the determination of what benefits should be paid in cases where there is doubt about whether a supporting parent is living alone or is excluded from benefit because he or she is living on a bona fide domestic basis with somebody else and hence is to be treated as a married partner. It is, I think, a thoroughly acceptable principle in our social security system that we do not treat unmarried couples better than we treat married couples. The system is one which is designed to provide, basically, benefits according to circumstance and not according to whether the marriage ceremony has been gone through. Sometimes that works to the benefit of claimants ; sometimes it can work to their disadvantage. In relation to what are generally called de facto relationships, if we have a situation in which a man is claiming unemployment benefit and he is living in a de facto relationship with a woman, he can be paid unemployment benefit at the married rate and the woman is not subject to the work test. In that sense, there can be an advantage in a claim that there is a de facto relationship existing.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of the supporting parent's benefit, if there is a claim that a de facto relationship is existing-although they are not the words used in the Act I think the meaning is clear to the Senate-there can be a question of an exclusion of benefit. So it is not a one way street and the Department is not geared to make judgments which are based on its assessment of what is right and wrong but its assessment of what the law says.

The guidelines were issued for use in New South Wales. They were drawn to my attention, I must say, only when I saw a report of them in the media. Again, the instruction manuals of the Department, as is well known to Senator Grimes, are very considerable. I must say that I do not see every bit of paper that is issued by the Department in this area. Because of the degree of controversy which had arisen I examined the guidelines and there were a couple of elements of them which I queried. I sent them back to the Department and sought further consideration and advice so that I could give the matter further thought. I think I had some advice which I thought was not quite what I was looking for-in other words, it did not go into the sort of detail that I wanted-and I have again asked the Department to give me further advice.

At this stage I think the guidelines apply in New South Wales and not in any other State. My recollection of the guidelines-and it is now some weeks since I read them-is that they do include reference to the right to refuse to answer questions. The guidelines have probably been seen by Senator Grimes and his recollection may be better than mine on the particular point. But my recollection is that there is reference to the fact that at a certain point, where an officer might consider that there is a risk of an offence having been committed and hence a risk that there might be a prosecution, there should be some form of warning. I would stress that I am relying on memory and my recollection may be imperfect. But my recollection is that, yes, there is some reference to the right to refuse to answer questions.

With regard to right to enter, quite frankly I do not remember whether there is any specific reference to the right to refuse entry, but I would say that I would not particularly want to be encouraging social security beneficiaries to refuse to co-operate with officials of my Department. I think the simple fact of the matter is that, if we are to make correct decisions under the Act and if we are to make the payments which are due and not make payments which are not due, we would seek and generally expect the willing co-operation of those people who are seeking the support of their fellow Australians through the system. I say that bearing in mind that, whilst there may be odd cases of officious, difficult and unpleasant officers of my Department, in general my experience is that they are decent people trying to do a job and I believe that they are entitled to have the co-operation of the beneficiaries who seek the assistance of the Department.

I assure Senator Grimes and the Senate, however, that I do think it is important that we have guidelines which respect the dignity and the rights of Australians who seek the support of my Department. We would certainly not wish to do anything which impinged on those rights, which was vindictive or in any other way unpleasant. But I again say to the Senate that unfortunately, as this morning's newspaper recounts, there are people who do engage in fraudulent practices with respect to my Department and, unfortunately, to catch even a part of that number of people, it is necessary at times to treat people with suspicion when suspicious circumstances arise. Again I would simply say that I believe that the public servants in my Department who are charged with the administration of the Act in general try to strike the proper balance in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs : What is the Australian Government's response to the Middle East peace plan set out this week by the President of the United States of America, developing American policy towards the Palestinian communities and towards Israel? In particular, I refer to the American proposal that, after a transition period, there be an end to Israeli sovereignty or permanent control over the West Bank and Gaza and that these areas move into association with Jordan. Does the Australian Government consider that a stable outcome for these and other Palestinian communities on the border of Israel is an essential part of any long term solution to the problems of the Middle East?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government welcomes President Reagan's initiative in seeking a settlement of the Middle East dispute. The statement demonstrates the determination of the United States to build on the evacuation from Beirut and lay the groundwork for a broader peace in the Middle East. The United States initiative is based on the Camp David process and on Security Council Resolution 242, both of which Australia has supported. Australia remains totally committed to the security of Israel. We believe that this security can best be achieved by Israel reaching agreement with its neighbours. At the same time the Government believes that there can be no lasting peace or security in the Middle East without a resolution of the Palestinian problem. The legitimate rights of the Palestinians include their right to a homeland and the right to participate directly in decisions affecting their future.

ANSWER.PARA: President Reagan's statement has shown that the United States Government is prepared to address the underlying causes of the conflict and to use its great influence in the search for a just and lasting settlement. He has firm Australian support to that end. In the first instance the negotiations which we hope will follow President Reagan's statement should involve the parties principal to the conflict, and it is for them to agree upon particular means by which a comprehensive peace may be achieved. The Government regrets that the initial reaction of the Israeli Government to President Reagan's initiative was not favourable but hopes that further consideration will lead Israel to change its mind. Arab reaction has so far been cautious but will no doubt be clarified at the forthcoming Arab summit meeting. Without acceptance by all parties to the Middle East dispute-Palestinians, Arabs and Israelis-of the need to agree on further negotiations there can be no progress towards a comprehensive peace in the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It arises out of recent Press releases by him and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, announcing increased funding for nursing homes in Australia. I ask: What amount of money will be available to the Lerwin Nursing Home in Murray Bridge out of the increased funds which he recently announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I might avoid future questions by having a national Press release and a Murray Bridge Press release because I can always rely on Senator McLaren to be concerned about that particular corner of Australia. The honourable senator will be disappointed to know that my recollection of what will be specifically provided for that nursing home at Murray Bridge is quite faulty. I will have to go back and consult my papers on it. However, I do anticipate making a public announcement within the next few days of the first list of approvals following the announcement of, I think, 11 August. I have no particular recollection of that, but a large number of organisations will be receiving advice as to their requests for assistance. Those honourable senators who are interested in particular applications, as is Senator McLaren on this occasion, should not regard the failure of any application to be dealt with in the announcements over the next few days as being a sign that they will not get funding in the reasonably near future. I stress that it is simply the first announcement of what will be a series.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators who are interested in this area will know, we are moving away from the single three-year allocation to a more rolling approach. There will be announcements over the course of the next month or two of projects which will be funded during the balance of this financial year and during the next financial year. I anticipate that there will be further announcements of approvals for the following financial year early next calendar year. In a move which appears to have been generally welcomed by the handicapped organisations and by those caring for the aged, we will be having a rolling approach which will probably enable annual approvals to be given rather than one set of approvals every three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of submissions made by the Tasmanian Government that the proposed national maritime museum be located on Hobart's waterfront? What action is being taken with regard to a final decision on this issue? When can an announcement be expected? Can the Minister assure this House that the Tasmanian Government's submission will be given full con- sideration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report which the Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections produced some years ago under the chairmanship of Mr Peter Pigott. Part of the report concerned itself with the question of the establishment of a national maritime museum. I am also aware that submissions have been made by the Tasmanian Government. I believe some honourable senators will have received from the Tasmanian Government some material relating to this matter. There is as yet no Commonwealth commitment to the establishment of a national maritime museum. I think that may well be the threshold question to be settled. However, a working group has been established to consider the matter. It has consulted with all States and raised the matter with them. It has not yet received responses from all States and is awaiting some replies.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has before it a whole range of proposals concerning the preservation of our history and matters affecting the national museum. The concept of a national maritime museum is among the matters under consideration. I might say as a New South Wales senator that I am well aware that the Pigott committee selected an excellent site just off Drummoyne in Sydney Harbour- Spectacle Island-which I understand would also be taken into consideration if we were looking at the question of the establishment of a maritime museum. I am aware of the excellent presentation from the Government of Tasmania, and it and other representations are now under consideration by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation acknowledge that the proposed changes to the Perth Airport are causing a great deal of distress to residents living near the airport? Has the Government any plans to compensate the people who would be affected by increases in noise levels through the proposed changes? If so, what is the estimated cost; if not, why not? Finally, is it not time that the Federal Government gave serious consideration to choosing an alternative site away from Perth for a second international airport so that the residents of the suburbs around Perth Airport can enjoy their environment?

—Senator McIntosh has drawn the attention of the Senate to the question of the environmental impact of developments at Perth Airport. The information that I have available indicates that the final statement on this matter has not yet been brought to the Government's attention and that the Government is awaiting the appraisal of some 250 submissions which were received before 30 July this year. Consequently, it would appear that it will be some time before the Government, through the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the Minister for Aviation, can focus its attention on this matter. I think that all I can do in the circumstances is to draw Senator McIntosh's concerns to the attention of both Ministers with a view to getting an answer for him.

—I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that the complaints have been about the proposed changes to Perth Airport, not about an alternative site. My question expressed the view that the Federal Government should consider an alternative site to the existing airport and not just changes to the existing airport.
—I will also draw that matter to the attention of the Ministers .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented in an Australian Broadcasting Commission news broadcast this morning. I seek the opportunity to make a correction.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the main item of the ABC news this morning I was reported as calling for an immediate extension of the powers of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I want to make it clear for the record that I made no such call. I did make a call for the continuation of the Costigan Royal Commission with an extension of its duration, simply because I obviously want to see that body continue to do its work and not be replaced by a Fraser commission, but I said nothing as to the rather more difficult and complex question of whether the powers of the Commission ought to be extended, for example, as to the issuing of search warrants. That is an issue which is more difficult to resolve and certainly one on which my mind is very much still open. I want to make that clear for the record, lest it be quoted against me on some future occasion.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Evans proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The long history of delay, neglect, incompetence and maladministration in the Attorney-General's Department under Senator Durack.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The failure effectively to prosecute bottom-of- the-harbour schemers is only the tip of one iceberg in an ocean of incompetence and neglect in the Attorney-General's Department under Senator Durack's now five -year-old reign. In every area of the Attorney-General's activities and those of his Department-in the areas of law reform, legal administration and of criminal prosecutions-there simply has been an absence of positive achievement and a long history of delay and maladministration, which I will now do something quite specific and quite precise, in conjunction with my colleagues, to document. Let me begin, however, with Senator Durack's positive achievements, because it would be surprising indeed if he did not have at least some positive achievements to his credit after five years in that office. In the Melbourne Age last Monday Senator Durack claimed five major achievements during his five years as Attorney -General, which, of course, in itself is hardly an impressive record. One wonders what he was doing during the other 51 weeks of the years in question. But even those achievements evaporate on closer scrutiny.
