He mentions the enactment of the freedom of information legislation, the off-shore sovereignty agreement, the creation of the Human Rights Commission, the bringing to fruition of the United States anti-trust negotiations and the abolition of appeals to the Privy Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at them in turn. The freedom of information legislation took four years to get through this Parliament. It is still, in the view of many, and possibly most, members of this chamber, too weak, and furthermore it is still not in operation. The off-shore sovereignty agreement was certainly an achievement, brought about simply by the capitulation of the Commonwealth against the national interest to pressures coming from States rights quarters. The Human Rights Commission has certainly been established, does exist and may be doing some useful work around the edges, but with its present jurisdictional limitations and present lack of powers it is a toothless joke, and is so regarded by most people who take these issues seriously. The United States anti- trust negotiations took four years to bring to fruition against the initially predicted six months, which does not say an awful lot for the competence or capacity of this Minister and his Department in matters of international negotiation, particularly when one notices that that agreement leaves quite unresolved by far the most controversial and difficult aspect of extra- territorial anti-trust legislation policy, the continued capacity of parties to initiate private litigation under that legislation in the United States.

Finally, the last of these personal achievements of which the Attorney-General is so proud, is the abolition of State appeals to the Privy Council. On the face of it this is an important and long overdue development, but it is one that has taken years to reach the present stage of mere agreement. On the present track record and on the predictions that I have heard around the place, it may well take years yet actually to implement.

So much for the achievements that are claimed by the Attorney-General. What of those less substantial achievements, those negative achievements, if one likes, which I believe justify the matter of public importance that has been put down today. To assist me in doing this, given the time constraints available, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a 13-page document which tabulates in systematic form and in much more detail many of the matters to which I now seek to refer.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave then to table the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Attorney-General for that degree of generosity. I am sure it will not go unnoticed, nor will his churlishness in not allowing this documentary record to be put in Hansard, where it might well have got more attention than will now be the case. In any event let us proceed and look firstly at the Attorney's law reform record. For some considerable time, I suppose, it has been a matter of amusement to refer to what I have often described as Durack's law. It is a new natural law which goes something like this: The prospect of achieving any given law reform varies in inverse proportion to the importance of the subject matter and the quality of the supporting argument. That has been a comment amply justified by the Attorney- General's track record in matters of law reform and that of his Department, but that track record has long since ceased to become a joke.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take the question of the family law, for a start. The Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act was established in 1978 and reported in 1980. It is now getting towards the end of 1982. The legislation was introduced in November 1981 but has lain on the table. Many of the matters dealt with in that joint committee report are still not even in legislative form, let alone have been brought to parliamentary attention. The question of a reference of powers from the States is something on which the future of family law effectiveness will largely depend. This Attorney has refused to accept the offer of a reference from New South Wales. He insists on waiting until all the States agree to make such a reference of the power, an insistence, of course, which will never be honoured in the observance by certain States. In the area of the matrimonial property inquiry, I think it ought to be noted that on 13 October 1981 Senator Durack announced that a committee of inquiry would be established to examine the question of a matrimonial property regime. Eleven months later that committee has not yet even been established, let alone set running to do that particular job of work.

The question of Australian Capital Territory legislation on matters of law reform is within the Attorney-General's drafting jurisdiction and it is again something on which there has been a lamentable record. The question of a crimes compensation system was the subject of a government commitment, on 22 August 1979. Three years after that announcement of government approval, there is still no legislation establishing such a system. So far as wills are concerned-a more exotic area of the law but a very important one for individuals-Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania amended their legislation between 1964 and 1966, with New South Wales following suit in 1977. In November 1980, when the Attorney-General's Department was pressed on what progress was being made here, it was said that the Department had the matter under consideration but could not say when the work would be completed. It is now 1982 and despite further proddings and jabbings from time to time nothing further has occurred.

In the area of mercantile legislation Senator Durack announced on 22 July 1979 that legislation governing the processing of payments by cheques would be introduced 'early next year', that is, 1980. That was legislation to implement the recommendations of the Manning committee on bills of exchange. Three years have elapsed since that announcement and still there is no sign of that Bill. Let us turn to the Acts Interpretation Act, which in a more updated mode, the Attorney-General claims is another one of his achievements. Section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act was enacted with bipartisan support. It draws the attention of the courts to wider considerations that they might legitimately take into account in applying statute law. At the time of the introduction of that provision he said that he would be bringing forward a Green Paper before the Parliament rose-that was before the end of the 1981 Budget session. One of the specific options floated was the idea of explanatory memoranda approved by Parliament to accompany legislation; obviously this is an initiative of tremendous significance. But no Green Paper appeared in that Budget session, or has since. Almost 12 months have elapsed since the announcement.

The area of prosecution policy is of enormous interest and significance in the light of recent developments. It is something which will be picked up by Senator Grimes when he talks about the social security fraud case, and also by my colleague Senator Georges, when he has something to say later about the Medibank fraud system, or lack of system in prosecutions there. The Attorney-General made an announcement on 14 January this year that he would be tabling in the Senate in the autumn session the statements setting out the Commonwealth prosecution policy and the general principles which should govern it. No statement appeared in the autumn session and no statement has appeared so far this session.

I turn now to another more exotic area of law reform-admiralty law. A joint committee of various legal bodies-the Law Council of Australia and the Maritime Law Association of Australia-agreed that the colonial or imperial legislation should cease to apply. Senator Durack announced in August that the case for doing this and for ensuring that the application of Australian law was unanswerable. But rather than just getting on with the business of legislating, he has referred it off to the Law Reform Commission. Of course, when one is talking about law reform, one can hardly fail to point out, as I have done on numerous occasions, that reports of the Australian Law Reform Commission reach an absolute graveyard when they come into the environs of the Attorney-General's Department and in particular the Attorney's office. We have seen the sad fate of the Criminal Investigation Bill which, despite successive reincarnations in various guises, still fails to hit the legislative deck. Similarly, we have seen a failure of action on the Unfair Publication report, the Insurance Agents and Brokers report and now the Sentencing report, a failure which simply cannot be attributed to an unwillingness by the Government to accept all the policy aspects lying behind those particular recommendations.

So much for law reform. What about some of the other things that his Department has been up to or has not been up to in the five years of his stewardship. I think it is crucial to document some of the failings of the Crown Solicitor's Division other than those in relation to tax prosecutions so that it can be appreciated that we are not here talking merely about an isolated instance. I think it equally ought to be noted that the Crown Solicitor's Division accounts for something like half of the total personnel within the Attorney-General's Department. It is no mere back alley within the Attorney-General's Department and as such it can hardly be regarded as a suitable case for the Minister in charge to ignore. The work of the Crown Solicitor's Division extends across the whole range of civil advices, the conduct of civil actions on behalf of the Commonwealth and, of course, the implementation of prosecutions.

Let me give some examples of maladministration across each of those fields. In the area of civil action the classic case has to be the Faulkner litigation, which has been the subject of some attention in this Parliament on several occasions and which I will refer to briefly again. It is an action in contract for damages brought initially in 1974. The matter wallowed along in the Crown Solicitor's Division with no action being taken. Attention was brought to the case in 1980 by Mr Bryant in the House of Representatives. I took up the matter in 1981. I have had an extraordinary saga of unanswered correspondence in this matter ever since. On 4 December 1981 I wrote a letter to the Attorney requesting full information as a matter of urgency following a letter of the same kind I had written six months earlier to which I had received only a formal reply. Formal acknowledgement of the December letter was received on 4 January. On 31 March this year Senator Durack's office advised that a reply would be coming 'within one or at most two weeks'. On 21 April, three weeks later, I was advised that the officer responsible had gone on leave, the letter was in draft form and would be done 'as soon as possible' but no promises could be made about when. I followed it up on 22 April at the Estimates committee hearing and I finally got the reply on 18 May. This is the way matters are conducted so often within the Attorney's Department.

Then on another kind of activity of the Crown Solicitor's Division there is the preparation of agreements involving the Commonwealth. There is no more spectacular case than the Dintenfass case of which I have had quite a deal to say in this chamber. I simply remind the Senate that it concerns an agreement with the United States of America governing the location on a National Aeronautics and Space Administration space shuttle flight of a very important Australian designed experiment relating to the behaviour of blood in space. The experiment has been delayed something like seven years in its location on a flight by virtue of the Blue Hills saga which the Attorney-General himself in March 1982 recognised was the appropriate description for the way that matter had been handled by his officers.

Then we come to prosecution policy. Leaving aside the whole area of taxation about which we have heard so much, we find some extraordinary things. The Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth is particularly adept, it seems, not only at taxation prosecutions but also at trade practices matters! The Full Court of the Federal Court decided against the Commonwealth informant, the Trade Practices Commission, in the matter of Traveland Ltd this year, saying in the course of its judgment:

There are no less than 96 different combinations of elements of an offence against section 53 (c). Each different combination constitutes a distinct offence. The information and summonses in the present case failed to charge Traveland, in terms, with any one of those 96 possible offences.

Such is the level of competence of the DCS in Perth not only in tax prosecutions but also in crucially important trade practices ones as well. There is another case in the DCS office in Brisbane, that of Gilmour v. Midways Springwood Pty Ltd, which demonstrates again at that level incapacity of a similar order.

Turning to what I have generally described in the document which is tabled but regrettably not incorporated as 'miscellaneous delays and failings', something should be said about the legal aid area. Here we have had another extraordinarily drawn out saga of inaction in relation to an extremely important report on cost comparisons between the delivery of legal aid directly by salaried professionals as against through private practitioners, an exercise which was supposedly set in train in August 1981 and which has been the subject of an unbelievable saga of inattention, neglect and possibly actual interference and obstruction by the Attorney-General's Department.

There is the legal aid largesse increase administered to the firm of Galbally and O'Bryan in the context of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to which I drew attention in November 1981 and which has now, of course, assumed new interest, relevance and importance with the further revelations and conclusions about the appropriateness of Mr Galbally's performance in this respect in the fourth interim Costigan report. Here let me simply say that the Commonwealth, through the Attorney-General's Department, was party to what I think on any objective view would be described as an unjustifiably generous commitment of scarce legal aid funds-of which $800 for each non-sitting day of the Commission was perhaps the most glaring aspect-to a firm whose continued representation of the union was regarded as quite unsatisfactory by the Royal Commission and which in the Commissioner's words 'reflects no credit on Mr Galbally'.

There have been complaints by the Ombudsman, particularly in his second report, 1978-79, about failures of the Attorney-General's Department to respond quickly to requests for advice which have been made by numerous Commonwealth departments . There has been a failure to implement the United Nations Convention on the Recovery Abroad of Maintenance despite its signature by Australia as long ago as 1956 and the conclusion of consultations about the form of regulations to enable Australia's implementation of that Convention in March 1977. Formalities are complete but still the matters languish.

There it is. Many more items could be brought forward in this particular bill of indictment against the Attorney-General and against the administration under him of his Department. The total impression one gets in all of this is of an Attorney, Senator Durack, bobbing about like a cork aimlessly in the sea, periodically beset by storms but mostly utterly becalmed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your inflated opinion.

—It is not just my opinion. I make it clear that this is not simply the perception of the Labor Party. Might I remind the honourable senator for a start that Senator Durack was attacked by the Young Liberals on 14 January 1982 for his 'lethargy' in law reform. He was attacked by the Liberal Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, Mr Connolly, in a statement on 20 April this year for his 'glacial' progress in responding to a Public Accounts Committee report. He was attacked only yesterday by the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation, an all-party committee of this Senate, in its interim report for his failure to provide adequate advice in relation to the legal issues before that Committee. He has been attacked by one of the honourable senator's back bench colleagues, Mr Max Burr from Tasmania, who has called for a full investigation into the administration of his Department, an investigation which is long overdue and which would undoubtedly reveal, if it did take place, across a systematic front that the fault in that Department lies by and large not with the middle and lower level officers, or with most senior officers, who have in my experience been wholly professional and wholly competent. The failure in that Department lies, in my perception and that of many people who have perceived this from outside, in the utter failure of ministerial direction from Senator Durack and indeed the man whom the Government has appointed as the head of that Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The point of this matter of public importance is not to carp for carping's sake about a Minister whose performance is demonstrably simply not up to the mark. The point of bringing this matter of public importance forward today is to make it abundantly clear, unequivocally clear and unanswerably clear that Senator Durack's failure to prosecute effectively the bottom-of-the-harbour schemers-all those involved, whether as vendors, purchasers or promoters of those schemes-is not just an isolated instance of maladministration. It is not just an isolated instance of neglect, delay or incompetence. It is an instance of something which runs right through and which is endemic to the whole conduct of the Attorney- General's Department under this Minister, and it amounts to a devastating reason why he should resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance introduced in the Senate this afternoon and addressed by Senator Evans raises the question of the incompetence and maladministration of the Attorney-General's Department-one of the original departments of the Commonwealth, one with a very long and proud record and undoubtedly one of the major departments still in the Federal administration. It is a very large department with great responsibilities and one which over the years-including the years in which I have been its ministerial head as Attorney-General-has discharged those responsibilities with great distinction even though, of course, as in any big organisation, there may be some delays, some neglect and some grounds for criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that Senator Evans introduces a complaint about maladministration because, of course, Senator Evans has never had any experience of administering anything except perhaps a lecture course to undergraduates. It is an old saying that those who can, do and those who cannot, teach. Senator Evans, in his whole career, has been a teacher of law students. Since he has been in the Senate he has assumed the role of teacher of the Senate and time and again we have been subjected to long boring lectures on the law, on me or on my Department. Such lectures usually empty the Senate, and today has been no exception because there were fewer people in the Senate when Senator Evans was speaking than there are at the moment. It is somewhat of an irony that this man who likes to call himself the shadow Attorney-General, who is an academic, a theorist and a lecturer, has given us a lecture today about administration. At least, that is what he purported to give us. Of course, largely it was a re-run from Senator Evans of the old record about me. Although the terms of it are about the administration of my Department and so on, in fact it turns out to be the old worn record of his complaints that he has about me and about the policies that I follow. I am proud that he does not agree with them. I would be very worried indeed if Senator Evans praised any of my achievements, because he does not agree with many of the policies that I follow and I certainly do not agree with those that he follows.

Unlike Senator Evans, I will speak to the subject. He introduced a matter of public importance about maladministration and neglect over the last five years in the Department of which I am the head. In recent years the work of the Department has increased very greatly, particularly in the Advisings Division. Certainly if there has not in totality been more cases in recent years, the Crown Solicitor's Division has been concerned in the criminal area and the area of constitutional law with some very major cases indeed. I cannot give the total number of cases or files that there would be in the Crown Solicitor's Division, but the report of the Attorney-General's Department to the Senate last year shows that in the Crown Solicitor's Division more than 100,000 matters were completed in 1980-81 and 84,000-odd in 1981-82. It has a very large area of responsibility, and its work is conducted by 200-odd legal staff around Australia, assisted of course by a great many lay staff. In the Crown Solicitor' s Division alone there is a very large responsibility and, I believe, a growing responsibility. Because of the growth in the size of government in recent years the Advisings Division of the Department, which provides the daily legal advice on all the ramifications of government, has had a very great increase in demands made upon it.

I am speaking of the traditional role of the Attorney-General's Department and of the Attorney-General; namely, of giving advice to government and conducting litigation and prosecutions on behalf of the Crown. That is essentially what the Attorney-General's Department was established to do; and it has always been at the very heart and core of the Department to carry out that work. As I have said on another occasion recently, the work is that of a service department. The Attorney-General's Department acts as a lawyer on behalf of clients. Its client is the Commonwealth Government and all the numerous ramifications of the Government. The Attorney-General has the role of giving legal advice at the request of colleagues. He is in almost daily communication with them either in meetings or elsewhere. These days the Attorney-General takes very little time-in fact no time as far as I or my predecessor are concerned-to conduct litigation in court which was one of the traditional roles of the Attorney-General. The role of the Attorney-General is now so involved because of the size of the Department, the size of government and the political responsibilities that that is an impossible task.

Of course the Attorney-General's Department has two other very large areas of responsibility, both of which have grown quite spectacularly in recent years. Firtly, I refer to the new Federal courts system. It is interesting to note that in 1975 there were 30 Federal judges; today there are 74 or 75. If we went back further, for instance to 1956, we would find that there were only 15. Over most of the period of the Department's life it has been concerned only with the administration of the High Court and very small Federal courts such as the Australian Capital Territory courts or the Industrial Court. In recent years that court system has increased greatly. The size of the High Court has not increased, but it has moved to Canberra and a great deal of work and new responsibility has been involved in that transfer and in the new legislation as well as in the new building.

The Federal Court of Australia, which was established in 1977 by my predecessor , is now one of the great courts of Australia, but it is also a very large court . The judges of that court have to be attended to, with their needs for court space, offices, staff and so on. The judges have to command attention from the Department and, indeed, from the Attorney-General.

In addition, in January 1976 the Family Court was established. With 41 judges, it has now become the largest court in Australia. It had to be set up as a completely new court. Finding premises and staffing branches in every State except Western Australia have made tremendous administrative demands upon the Department. So too have the appointment of judges and the necessity to deal with them, in particular the Chief Judge, having in mind the size of the court. I mention that simply to indicate the greatly increased responsibilities which in recent years have been assumed by the Department-an assumption that I believe on the whole has been very successful.

I repeat that the Federal Court of Australia, despite the very short time since its inception, is now hailed as one of this country's great courts. The criticisms made of the Family Court have been largely misplaced and relate more to differences of view about the Family Law Act and the policy to be followed under it than to the court and its judges. It has been a most innovative court, one which has given true meaning to the phrase 'helping court', as it has frequently been described-I believe with full justification. It has initiated procedures, such as those involving court counsellors and conciliation registrars, which provide, through a court, a completely new concept of service to people who are in trouble. That has been a major achievement and responsibility of my Department and myself in recent years. To make carping criticisms of a few delays here and there, which is all that Senator Evans has done, shows a complete lack of sense of judgment about the size of the task and the dedication of the officers of my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —No balance at all.

—Absolutely not. How would he know? He has administered only a lecture course for undergraduates. Another very large area of responsibility of the Attorney-General and his Department concerns policy areas such as that of criminal law, a matter which, in the United Kingdom, is dealt with by the Home Secretary, not by a law department at all. Similarly, the Department is concerned in business and trade law matters which again, in the United Kingdom, fall within the responsibility of another department of state altogether. Industrial property law and copyright law also are the responsibility of the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: One of his most important new responsibilities has concerned administrative law reform and civil rights. Senator Evans has grudgingly referred to the Human Rights Commission but, of course, there have been very much greater achievements in that area. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has been developed. The Administrative Review Council provides judicial review of the merits of decisions. The avenue for complaints against police as provided by recent legislation is but another notable example of action in many areas. That is one of the new provinces, to use an old phrase, of law and order that have been developed in recent years and have become the reponsibility of my Department and myself. The freedom of information legislation took much time to prepare because it concerned a very innovative and controversial area. I had the responsiblity of piloting that legislation successfully through this Parliament. Senator Evans makes the further carping criticism that there has been delay in implementing it but he has not the remotest idea of the problems for the Public Service in regard to training and the development of systems in order to give effect to legislation of that kind. Those actions are proceeding. We will not bring the legislation into force until it can be administered effectively and efficiently.

Senator Evans has referred to other areas of policy. I repeat that this is another very important aspect of the Attorney-General's responsibility. In the years during which I have held that office, I have found that a great deal of my time has been taken up with policy matters rather than with the traditional activity of providing legal advice. I refer to the aspect of court administration and the great development of the new Federal Court system-another matter which occupies a great deal of my time and that of officers of my Department.

Thus, the criticism that Senator Evans has made, the criticism of the Crown Solicitor's Division that has been current in recent weeks, affecting as it does but a few officers of that Division, has clouded, in a most unfortunate and unfair way, the tremendous work and exercise of responsibility by the officers of the Department in the pursuit of all facets of its role. A tremendous disservice is being done to this country by those who-the Opposition, in particular-have been harping on failings here and there. This reduces, in the public estimation, the standing of one of the original, and most important, departments of state of the Commonwealth Government. I express my great concern about that aspect and the effect that it may well have upon the ability of the Department to recruit people of the calibre that it needs and has been able to obtain in recent years. The Department has always been able to find officers and lawyers of very high calibre. But in recent years attention has been given to ensuring the recruitment and training of young officers of like calibre. The Department has been well aware of the need for new management approaches and has taken important steps in that direction. I have referred previously to the joint management review and its implementation in the Crown Solicitor's area. But in recent years the Department has also conducted a number of management conferences and seminars for Second Division and Third Division officers. This training program was begun in October 1980. A major conference is held every year and during the year a series of training seminars for senior officers is held. Thus the Department is well aware of the magnitude of its management problems and has taken significant steps to bring itself up to date and to acquire the skills needed. The motion before us does a great disservice to a major department of state and is unworthy of Senator Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance has been brought before the Senate today because members of the Opposition-Senator Evans in particular-wish to point out that, although the problems raised in the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-especially the problems of tax evasion and the lack of vigour with which the Government has approached the prosecution of those involved in tax evasion-are important, the long history of delay, neglect, incompetence and maladministration in the Attorney-General's Department under Senator Durack is also a matter of importance. In opening this debate, Senator Evans spent time listing carefully and discussing a whole series of examples of delay, neglect, incompetence and dubious practice which in fact add up to maladministration under any meaning of the term. What have we had from the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, for the last 20 minutes? We have had, first of all, an attack on Senator Evans based on the fact that Senator Evans happens to have been an academic.
—He omitted the fact that I was a barrister as well.

—As Senator Evans says, he omitted the fact that he was a barrister and practised as such. Secondly, we had a description of Senator Durack's Department as the oldest and proudest department of government in this country. For the rest of the time we heard what can only be described as a whinge about the work load of the Attorney-General's Department being too great, about the increased responsibilities of the Department, about the increase in the number of judges and about the amount of advice the Department has to give. The Attorney was making an excuse for the incompetence, the maladministration, the delay and the neglect that Senator Evans spoke about and that I and Senator Georges will speak about. If problems such as this long litany of difficulties facing the Department because of increased responsibility are the cause of the disquiet in the community and in the Parliament about the Attorney-General's Department, I point out that the responsibility lies clearly with the Government and with the Attorney-General for having failed to administer that Department properly, for having failed to ensure that the Department had the capacity, both financial and human, to conduct its activities properly. That is also maladministration, and that is a responsibility that Senator Durack and his colleagues have to face.
—Have you anything new to say?

—Senator Teague always sits and carps because he has nothing better to do on the afternoons when matters of public importance are discussed. Senator Durack then had the hide to suggest at the end of his speech, after having failed to answer any of the criticisms made by Senator Evans, other than by excuse and by a worrying speech about the difficulty of his job and the work load of his Department, that the Opposition is being irresponsible in bringing forward in this Parliament what is obviously a problem in the Attorney-General's Department and what is obviously a problem in the administration of it by the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Evans pointed out, it is not only in those areas referred to in the Costigan report and it is not only in the area of failure to prosecute those involved in tax avoidance that the Department comes under criticism. There are the areas that Senator Evans listed and there are the areas that I will talk about. One matter to which I wish to refer is the differences in approach of the Department, particularly the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, in regard to the prosecution of justice and in ensuring that justice is seen to be done in various aspects of the law in this country. It is important to realise that we have a duty to bring this forward.

Even the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has realised this in the past, if not at present. He has said in the past that there is no way known that anything less than the highest code and practice of public administration will be tolerated in this country. At the moment the Prime Minister is vigorously protecting the Attorney and his Department, in which a major blunder has been committed. He is protecting the Minister responsible for the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth in which, I suggest, the highest code of practice and public administration, to quote the Prime Minister, is a sick joke. So long as the Prime Minister does not accept the resignation of the Minister responsible-who, of course, is Senator Durack-he is tolerating a pocket of shoddy, lying and venal administration.

The Costigan report claimed that inaction within the Attorney-General's Department has cost the Commonwealth revenue hundreds if not thousands of millions of dollars. I must suggest to honourable senators that that revenue could have eased the strain on millions of Australian families, the well-being of which has never particularly concerned the Minister responsible in this case, Senator Durack. In the failure to prosecute those involved in the bottom-of-the- harbour tax avoidance scheme and other rigged schemes in this country not only have we a situation in which the rich and the powerful are able to avoid their responsibilities but also we have a very good example, if we compare that activity of the Crown Solicitor's Office with that Office's activities in the area of social security prosecutions, of differential treatment, of double standards, which I do not believe should be tolerated in what Senator Durack describes as the oldest and proudest department of government in this country. Certainly the Australian Labor Party does not condone social security fraud but when people concerned with those frauds, usually involving only a couple of hundred dollars, if that, are prosecuted and jailed while prosecutions do not take place in cases involving many hundreds of thousands of dollars or more, one wonders about the system and its administration.

In 1978-79 there were 1,368 prosecutions against social security offenders and successful prosecutions were recorded against 1,328 of those people-about 94 per cent. The total payment which formed the basis for the alleged frauds in that time was $1.5m for the whole 1,300-odd people prosecuted. That amount of money would be considered petty cash by the people who have escaped prosecution, despite the advice of Queen's Counsel and despite the advice of the Australian Taxation Office, and who have run off with at least hundreds of millions of dollars. At the same time the might of the Crown Solicitor's Office has been brought down on these 1,300 people who received an average of approximately $1, 200 in overpayments. Many received much less.

Most of these people were unemployed, over half were married or in a de facto situation and most pleaded guilty though less than half seemed to be aware of their guilt or had not committed the offences because they needed the money. A total of 17 per cent stated they had acted in ignorance and 20 per cent gave no reason. Most of them were not represented by lawyers in private practice and 3 per cent received prison sentences. The Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth carried out 152 prosecutions. In Western Australia-famous for protecting the habitat of the shonky company directors we have been hearing about-one social security recipient was imprisoned for an overpayment of $148 and two others were imprisoned for more than 260 days each. The Law Reform Commission report from which these figures can be obtained unfortunately has no analysis which gives a clue as to how many of these prosecutions related to beneficiaries who were Aboriginals, non-English speaking or virtually illiterate, but I think it likely that these groups formed a high proportion of the people charged. Incidentally, the report of the Law Reform Commission suggests that the cost effectiveness of these prosecutions warrants scrutiny.

Getting away from the prosecution of these people who can be considered the small fry in the ripping off of government funds, we come to the most shameful episode in this Government's record of prosecuting people. I refer, of course, to the Greek conspiracy case, as it was called, in which 176 Greek-Australian pensioners and six doctors were arrested in 1978 and which was dropped after four years of the most expensive committal hearings in this country. Estimated costs vary from some $10m to many more millions of dollars than that. There were aspects of that case in which the Minister's Department was involved, which I think warrant scrutiny and demonstrate the sort of maladministration about which Senator Evans spoke.

When Senator Durack became Attorney-General in September 1977, there was a question of a reward for Mr Chris Narkis, an informant in the case. That was under active discussion with various departments but in particular with the Crown Solicitor's Office of the Minister's own Department. Mr Barry Leader of that Office, who rates some mention in the Costigan report, had been involved in talks which led ultimately to Senator Durack giving Mr Narkis a pardon and others in the Government giving an assurance of a reward commensurate with results, a reward estimated as varying from $30,000 to $200,000. It is important to know whether Mr Leader or any other of the senior officials who were involved in those discussions warned the Attorney-General that such a reward gave a financial incentive to framing a case against those so-called conspirators. If Senator Durack did not know what was going on in his Crown Solicitor's Office, he should have known, and if members of that office did not tell him it is clearly and example of maladministration in that Department.

As the final transcripts of the conspiracy case demonstrated, the conspiracy was in fact against the Greek pensioners themselves. Mr Narkis was described by the magistrate as one whose credibility was zero or next to zero, and the magistrate recommended that proceedings be taken against ex-Detective Chief Inspector Thomas for conspiracy to pervert the course of justice or for perjury or for both. When this matter was raised with Senator Durack-the question of action against Thomas some two and a half months after the magistrate had made that statement-it was replied to by the usual answer, that the Attorney-General did not know what was happening.

Almost 400 sitting days and 320,000 pages later, after the start of this case, the case collapsed-at great cost. Someone in that Crown Solicitor's Office must have known, in view of the questions that were repeatedly asked in this place and repeatedly asked in the community about the conduct of the case-indeed, the question asked by Senator Wright 10 days after the case when I first spoke about it, about the wisdom of proceeding on a conspiracy charge in such a situation- surely should have alerted the Attorney-General and the Crown Solicitor's Office as to what could happen in that case. That apparently did not happen. It is a demonstration of incompetence and of maladministration that nothing was discovered.

It seems to me that if we add to this conspiracy case in Australia the situation which arose in Greece, where Greek Australians were charged under Greek law with offences under Australian law, and the agony through which this Parliament had to go to get information about that case, and the fact that the Opposition had to go to Greece and get the court records there-which apparently the Attorney-General's Department could not get despite the fact that representatives of his Department had gone there-this demonstrates a lack of concern about true justice in this case. It is to be compared with the manner in which the Attorney-General's officers sat on their hands over the tax evasion cases and the manner in which Mr Costigan describes the cavalier behaviour of those officers in Western Australia and other places. If this single case, the Greek conspiracy case, as compared with the actions in the normal social security prosecutions in this country, does not demonstrate a malaise in the Department by itself, combined with Senator Evans's long dissertation on the large numbers of difficulties which have arisen in this Department, it should do so, and if it does not cause concern for the Government, for members of the Senate and of the other place and of this community, it is a sad thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is another re- run of the matter of public importance raised by the Opposition yesterday and a fortnight ago. We have just heard Senator Grimes moralising about the Greek conspiracy case. In effect, what he is saying is that we are damned if we do and damned if we do not-because in the Greek conspiracy case we allegedly rushed into the prosecution too soon without giving it serious consideration, and yet, as I shall show later in my speech, according to Senator Grimes's colleague Senator Walsh, because we took 15 days before we suspended officers of the Attorney-General's Department in connection with the Costigan report, we were not acting quickly enough.

SPEECH.PARA: It fascinates me to hear Australian Labor Party senators moralising, because if the ALP were genuine about its morality in this matter, it would expel the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union from affiliation with the party. Instead of doing that, the Victorian secretary of the ALP has announced publicly that that affiliation is not in jeopardy. Let me quote a part of the report which was tabled yesterday in the Senate, and it is a part of the report which Mr Costigan had previously kept secret. Before doing that, however, I should like to comment on the secrecy of this report. Every night on television we have been seeing the Leader of the Opposition in the other place, Mr Hayden, like a harlot baring her breast, exposing to the Press titbits of the secret parts of the Costigan report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I believe that the remark made by Senator Lewis about the Leader of the Opposition in another place, and a member of another House of this Parliament, was against Standing Orders, and I believe that the honourable senator should be asked to withdraw.
—Senator Lewis, if you expressed--

—With respect, Mr Deputy President, I do not have time to argue about it. I did not say that he was a harlot. I said that he was like a harlot baring her breast. He keeps exposing titbits of the secret report.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I think that Senator Lewis should be called upon to withdraw his remark unconditionally.
—Order! I feel that it is a reflection upon another honourable member, and I ask the honourable senator to withdraw.

—All right, Mr Deputy President if you so rule, I certainly withdraw those remarks. I was talking about Senator Grimes moralising here. Let me comment on that part of the secret report which was exposed yesterday as a result of what Mr Hayden has been demanding and leaking to the Press. Mr Costigan at paragraph 10.02 states:

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage of the investigation I am satisfied that the Union, at least in Victoria, Newcastle, Queensland and South Australia, if not in Sydney as well, is an organised criminal group following criminal pursuits.

One cannot get anything blunter than that. Yet the ALP continues to allow this union to remain affiliated with it and to take its moneys. Furthermore, that union has an effect on the determination of the policy of the ALP, and it helps in the selection of ALP members of parliament because it elects delegates to its various organisations. If the ALP were genuine in this matter, it would be doing something about it.

Let me comment on what Senator Evans has had to say today. The wording of this motion is Senator Evans's wording. It is clear that he is piqued that his pet projects have not been given the priority that he would have wanted to give them . Yet he comes here grizzling about the actions of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in not giving priority to his proposals. Why should the Attorney-General give priority to Senator Evans's proposals? With all due respect to Senator Evans, I suggest that he is naive. So far as an administrator would be concerned , he is an ivory tower academic. He comes in here with his carping criticism about the administration of the Attorney-General's Department when clearly he knows absolutely nothing about the administration of any organisation and certainly nothing about the administration of the Attorney-General's Department. I suggest to the Senate that he could not run a corner store.

On the other hand, it is clear from the Costigan report, as I said in the debate yesterday, that the Ministers are innocent of any charge. Paragraphs 1.28 and 1.32 of chapter 3 of volume 1 of Interim Report No. 4 of the Costigan Commission clearly show that proposition I have just put to be true. It is also clear that Senator Walsh, who uses his vitriolic tongue to attack people both inside and outside this Parliament, has made it clear that, having read this report, he does not think there is anything in it so far as the Ministers are concerned except for a period of three weeks. He claimed that it was three weeks . In fact, on investigation I discovered that it was 15 days. Senator Walsh says that the Attorney-General received the report and waited for 15 days before he suspended the officers.

That is Senator Walsh's entire criticism. Let us analyse that entire criticism. In fact, the Attorney-General did not receive the report and have it for 15 days ; the Department had the report for 15 days. The Department received the report on 3 August and on 18 August the officers O'Sullivan and Bercove were suspended. That happended 15 days later and not three weeks later. That was the decision of the permanent head and not of the Attorney-General. Much to Senator Walsh's surprise, decisions on suspension in fact are not made by the Attorney-General but are made by the permanent head. I remind the Senate that there are such things as statutory authorities in systems of government and that there are certain offices that are independent statutory authorities.

Having said that, let us look again at Senator Evans and his carping criticism of Senator Durack. Let me analyse what some other people have said about the matter. For example, Mr Trevor Hawkins, the head of the bureau of the Melbourne Sun, on 4 September 1982 said:
Few will argue that Senator Durack is not a hard-working and diligent Minister who has a rare command of his portfolio.

Those who listened carefully to this debate earlier this afternoon would agree totally with those sentiments. I suggest to the Senate that the Attorney-General this afternoon confirmed beyond any shadow of doubt what Mr Hawkins said in the Melbourne Sun-that Senator Durack 'has a rare command of his portfolio'. Let us look at some of the things that have happened while Senator Durack has been Attorney-General of this nation. Let us look at the off-shore legislation. This legislation is due to be proclaimed later this year. I put it to the Senate that the legislation is a unique achievement in the history of Commonwealth and State relations. The reason it is unique is that the Commonwealth had exclusive power in this area. It is clear that the ALP would have ridden rough-shod over the States in implementing whatever proposals it had. In fact, what happened under the present Government was that the Commonwealth worked in conjunction with the States and finally came up with a solution which was satisfactory to the States as well as to the Commonwealth. I put to the Senate that that is what federation is all about-the sharing of power and responsibility among constituent governments of the nation. One of the landmarks of the Attorney-General's period in office has been the amendment of the Acts Interpretation Act which requires courts to take account of the purposes or intent of an Act when interpreting the meaning of legislation, the statutory interpretation provisions. The importance of this proposal cannot in any way be underestimated. One of the highlights of my term as a Senator has been supporting that legislation.

I turn to the administration of the courts. During Senator Durack's five-year administration as Attorney-General he has appointed the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, four justices of the High Court, 10 judges of the Federal Court of Australia and 11 judges of the Family Court of Australia. There has been not one word of criticism of any one of those 26 judicial appointments. All of those appointments have been right and proper and have been acknowledged by both sides around Australia. Apart from that, the Attorney-General was responsible for the High Court of Australia Act which, in fact, requires the Attorney-General of Australia to consult with Attorneys-General of the States before appointing a High Court justice. Also, that Act gives independence to the Australian High Court.

The Attorney-General has been involved in a call for a single system of courts. He has indicated that he would give full support for the Commonwealth having these proposals developed, examined and debated as soon as possible at the Australian Constitutional Convention. He has been looking at conferences in relation to the sentencing of people around Australia. During this year he signed the anti-trust agreement-a landmark agreement with the United States of America-designed to resolve conflicts which might arise between Australian national interests and policies and the implementation of the American anti- trust laws. This was absolutely a landmark agreement and an enormous amount of work was involved in the preparation of it.

I turn to look at the freedom of information legislation. Those honourable senators who were present will recall the enormous amount of painstaking time and effort which the Attorney-General put in to make sure that the freedom of information legislation was satisfactory to this Parliament. Again, the Attorney -General is to be congratulated on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not mentioned tax avoidance once yet.

—I have been asked about tax avoidance. Let me say that the Attorney-General and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of this nation have done far more about anti-tax evasion and anti-tax avoidance legislation than any other government has ever done in the history of this nation. In the years 1972 to 1975 the Labor Party had opportunities to take action in this area and it did nothing whatsoever about it. A list of all relevant legislation-hundreds of pages of legislation -in relation to tax avoidance has been presented to the Senate. Yet people on the Opposition side are suggesting that we have not done enough. The Attorney-General was responsible for all that legislation. The Human Rights Commission, which was established by Senator Durack, is coming into operation. I turn to the Australian Security and Intelligence Organisation legislation. Legislation arising from the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security is coming into operation. The Attorney-General has done a vast amount of work and he is highly praised for having done so.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me mention the problems of the public servants who are being criticised by the Opposition for their part in this matter. These snide remarks from the Opposition must surely be going down very badly with them, as they would be with the young people of Australia. Perhaps the old people of Australia, too, are also sick to death of mud-slinging being involved in politics and the sort of mud-slinging which is going on here today, which went on yesterday and which is continually going on in an endeavour, some way or other, to involve the Government in these matters. Instead the Opposition should be looking at the Costigan report and the criminal activities of the painters and dockers union and showing some leadership, courage and morality in doing something about it. That is what the Opposition should be doing instead of engaging in this carping, mud-slinging criticism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are to take at face value what Senator Lewis has had to say about the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in the eulogy which he has just presented we must accept in stark contrast his performance in other areas. One could say that his incompetence in certain areas to which the Opposition has devoted itself-if what Senator Lewis is saying is correct-must be deliberate. This is a theory to which I am beginning to be attracted-that the incompetence of the Crown Solicitor's Office reflects the incompetence of the Minister. One must be reminded that the Minister is not only the Attorney- General; he is also the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. For that reason he has a further responsibility to accept that he is a very important officer of this place and that his behaviour should be beyond reproach. His behaviour has not been beyond reproach. He must accept the responsibility for the performance of his Department, and it is my belief that his general attitude to his duties is now reflected in the performance of the Crown Solicitor's Office. It is in the area of income tax collection that the Attorney-General has failed the people of Australia. His failure to see that the Crown Solicitor's Office actively and promptly pursued areas of default makes him culpable.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been mentioned by two previous speakers on this side that I would refer to another area of default by the Minister and by the Crown Solicitor's Office, but I have to limit my comments. It is a matter to which I can refer only briefly. It is being investigated by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. A reference to the Public Accounts Committee deals with Medi-fraud and overservicing within the Department of Health. Because it is a reference and because I am a member of that Committee I cannot refer to any evidence that has been received by the Committee which is not public; nor can I in any way come to any conclusion which can be anticipated as a conclusion which the Committee might reach. But it is only fair to advise the people of Australia that what is beginning to emerge is that the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office has been at fault in this area of income collection. It is beginning to appear, and it is on the public record, that doctors have overserviced or defrauded to the extent of many millions of dollars. Here is another area of neglect which can in some ways be related to the Crown Solicitor's Office because it has not engaged promptly in prosecutions which would have minimised the problem. That is a fault. A fault is beginning to emerge not only in that area but also with regard to Customs and excise.

The Crown Solicitor's Office is not properly carrying out prosecutions which have been brought to it by the Australian Federal Police. That evidence is beginning to emerge in the area of collection of excise, and many millions of dollars of taxpayers' money, money that society has a right to have access to, is not coming to the Treasury. The Crown Solicitor's Office must accept responsibility for that. It is far too tardy. There is evidence that from the moment a matter is brought to the notice of the Crown Solicitor's Office it is often 12 months to two years before action is taken. All of the efforts of the Federal Police or the various departments which seek to have prosecutions enacted are negated. For that reason the Attorney-General must look to his Department and accept responsibility for it. What has happened under the administration of the Attorney-General is the devolving of responsibility from the Crown Solicitor's Office in Canberra to the deputy crown solicitors offices in the States; there is a sort of extension of federalism. It is the Attorney- General's responsibility that he was not aware that the Crown Solicitor in Canberra was unaware of what was happening in the deputy crown solicitors offices in each of the States, in particular in Western Australia.

So what happens now? What are we faced with? We are faced with the situation of the Attorney-General knowing nothing because the Crown Solicitor knows nothing and the deputy crown solicitors in each of the States are afraid to act. What sort of department is this? It is a department which is responsible for prosecuting those who defraud. But nothing has been done and it is now exposed by the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union that there is company fraud on a massive level. Let me take honourable senators back to 1970, when the Senate appointed the Select Committee on Securities and Exchange. What the report of that Committee revealed was what the Costigan report is revealing now, that is, massive company fraud, massive speculation and people guilty of fraud and share manipulation. But nothing was done by the Attorney-General's Department. Why is the Attorney, Senator Durack, culpable in this area? I think he entered the Parliament in 1971 . Let me find the exact date when Senator Durack entered the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —1 July 1971. You need a bit of help, I think.

—Yes. Senator Durack was appointed to the Securities and Exchange Committee on 17 August 1971. About a month after he entered this Parliament he was appointed to that important Committee. He was privy to all the evidence that came before it. He was privy to all the evidence that showed massive manipulation of the Stock Exchange in Perth. He was privy to the evidence of all those witnesses, some from Western Australia, who were brought before the Committee, some of whom perjured themselves. He knew of the massive share manipulation in Western Australia. It was from that environment that he and several others in this place came. He knew of the massive theft from the Australian people through the stock exchanges. He knew the environment, he knew the evidence and he knew the report. Having become Attorney-General one would have expected that something would have been done. But nothing was done and what we have now is a repetition of the disclosures--
—What about the national commission the Government set up?

—Yes, and when did the Government set it up? Is it operating yet , 12 years later? If I recall correctly, the Attorney-General has only recently put through the Companies Act 1981. That Act was proclaimed on 1 July 1982, 12 years after all the massive distortion with which he was familiar was disclosed. The National Companies and Securities Commission, which took 12 years to appoint , has just received the legislation that it needs to operate. It took 12 years. I wonder how long it will take the proposed crimes commission to be appointed and what sort of legislation the Minister will give it. Could I say to you, Senator, that when I look back at your performance on the Committee and having appreciated what has happened over the past month or two, I am beginning to believe that your role on that Committee was to delay it, to divert it and to defuse it. Subsequently, you sat on another committee. The other committee to which I refer--
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair and not address his remarks across the floor.

—I take that advice. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, let me remind the Attorney-General that he was a member of the Senate Select Committee which was appointed on 23 April 1975, on the Corporations and Securities Industry Bill 1975. That Committee came to an end when, through the actions of the present Attorney-General and his colleagues in the Opposition, the Labor Government was dismissed from office. I was the Chairman of that Committee.
—You had an unworkable Bill and you knew it too.

—I was the chairperson of that Committee. Senator Durack and some very eminent colleagues of his were also members of that Committee. Their role was to delay and finally to succeed in burying the securities legislation. That legislation has only just emerged. With hindsight I hold Senator Durack responsible for that.
—You were the Chairman of the Committee.

—I know. I was fully aware of what was going on. I was the chairperson for only four months, or perhaps it could have been seven months, because the Labor Government was dismissed. For a period of seven months, there was a deliberate delay and Senator Durack was part of that delay. The only way in which I can describe his behaviour is that he was guilty of deliberate and calculated lethargy.
—That's a bit thick, isn't it?
—That is what it is. Although it may be thick, it fits.
—It's a pretty serious accusation.
—I am making it. If Senator Durack has an objection to make, let him make it. If Senator Chipp wants to object to what I am saying, he will have time to do so at some later stage.
—I'm sorry to interject.

—The matter is now serious, Senator. We have massive default and evasion and a massive level of criminality. The Attorney-Genral's Department is responsible for making prosecutions and it has failed to carry out those prosecutions. Therefore we must hold the Attorney-General responsible. The Attorney-General has refused to accept responsibility. Although this matter of public importance is directed towards the Department, one cannot separate-no matter how much the Attorney-General may wish to do so-the Attorney-General from the Department. If the Department is at fault, the Attorney-General must accept responsibility. The fault has been massive to the point where only one action is acceptable to this place, that is, the resignation of the Attorney-General. But he will stick it out just as his colleagues do in Western Australia, Queensland and in the National Country Party. That very action diminishes this place. Senator Durack has introduced a new ethical position for Ministers of the Crown. He has introduced into this place some of the corruption which exists in the areas which he should have done something about. I am surprised that he should not accept that.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of public importance which is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The long history of delay, neglect, incompetence and maladministration in the Attorney-General's Department under Senator Durack.

It is not my wish or intention to talk about the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, as a person or indeed about the many aspects of his administration which other speakers have discussed. There are good and bad aspects in every Minister' s administration. I intend to specialise in one aspect that has grown up in this country under his administration. He is not the only person involved. The whole of the Government has to be involved, particularly the Treasurer (Mr Howard), the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and other Ministers. Unfortunately and unhappily the debate about ministerial responsibility in this Parliament is becoming almost academic. I do not suggest that it is unimportant. A Melbourne Age columnist, Claude Forell, summed up the situation exquisitely this morning when he said:
Moreover, it is clear that Westminster precedents have become optional guidelines or debating points rather than a firm basis for Australian political ethics.

One can look back and consider the totally unjust sacking of Senator Withers. One can consider the sackings of Messrs MacKellar and Moore over almost petty little things. Yet we have seen the survival of people such as Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon-if one wants to extend it, one could include Senator Durack and Mr Howard-who have presided over mammoth inefficiency and corruption and who go unscathed simply because it is politically impossible to sack a National Country Party Minister. I do not propose to go into that nonsense. It might suit academics to talk about ministerial responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a bit too late for it, isn't it?

—It is too late for it and I agree that it is just not on. I wish to concentrate my remarks on the question of organised crime which has flourished under this Government. In Chapter 10 of Volume 2 of the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, Mr Costigan describes a criminal octopus of almost fictional proportions which is frightening in its extent and in the massive damage which it inflicts on society. The descriptions that Mr Costigan uses-I understand that he writes every word with his own pen-would have done credit to any Raymond Chandler or Mickey Spillane novel. But this is not fiction. No matter how members of the Government might wish, quite properly, to defend their colleague, I would be very disappointed if they submerged this dreadful story that is now being unwoven by this courageous man, Costigan, in Melbourne. This octopus is preying on Australian citizens, particularly those who cannot afford the burden-because every dollar that these creatures skim off the top is a dollar that a pensioner or someone placed in unhappy circumstances does not get-with a well organised efficiency which is conspicuously lacking in those on whom we rely to fight crime in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder what the ordinary citizen feels about politicians today when he or she reads about billions of dollars being ripped off the Government by these criminals. He or she must think: 'What are politicians doing? They are getting huge salaries; they lead good lives. Here we are being ripped off while the politicians do nothing'. What sort of confidence do ordinary people have left in the public service and in bureaucracies? What sort of confidence do they have in the Australian Taxation Office, the police forces and the courts? All of these institutions are being eroded and corroded in the public mind. Where does the blame finally rest? It has to rest here in this chamber and in the chamber across Kings Hall. It has to rest with politicians. This is where the ultimate source of power is.

Mr Costigan described large interlocking criminal schemes involving drugs, prostitution, illegal gambling, tax avoidance, tax evasion and loan sharking. One of the most worrying aspects of the report is that the people involved are not part of one tightly structured organisation. They are from different groups who possibly never meet face to face. There are the investors who supply the capital. According to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) there are some knights of the realm among them. They do so at arm's length knowing full well that they are party to secret crimes. There are the financial and managerial experts who assemble the funds and put them to use in an organised manner. Assisting these groups are the shyster lawyers and accountants who provide assistance for the schemes and assistance for the criminals when they run foul of the law enforcement agencies.

What are the law societies of this country, the Australian Society of Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia doing if they are not policing the behaviour of their members? Members of those societies -lawyers and accountants-are assisting white collar crime to the extent of billions of dollars. Yet those societies have the effrontery to call themselves professional organisations. They are professional all right; but criminals attribute that adjective to themselves when they become proficient at their profession. Finally, there are the criminal operatives at the bottom of the scale who carry a cosh or a gun, the drug pushers, the enforcers and the couriers. The irony is that the members of this last group-the cosh merchants, the killers and the drug pushers-are in some way the least dangerous to society, but they are the ones who make the headlines, such as 'murderer arrested' and ' 20 years gaol for drug pusher'. They are the ones who go to prision and yet in some ways they are the least dangerous.

The Commissioner mentions that some justices of the peace may be corrupt enough to subvert the ordinary processes of the legal system for the benefit of criminals. In other words, Mr Costigan is saying that maybe some justices of the peace are on the take. I go further and ask: Who is safe? Is anybody in a position of power in this country safe when the amount of criminal money floating around is of the magnitude suggested by Mr Costigan? We are not talking about hundreds of thousands of dollars. I have been rather amused today by the fact that certain people who have spoken in this debate and those who are about to speak, sniggered at my statements over 10 years that criminal activity in this country is profiting to the extent of billions of dollars a year. I have consistently spoken of profits of $750m a year going to organised crime in this country. There have been sniggers from both sides of the House whenever I have said that. People have said: 'He is at it again. He has an obsession about it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's rubbish. We've supported you. That's not true.

—Look at Hansard, Senator Tate, and see which Opposition senators have interjected while I have been raising these matters. But those people are not sniggering today. If I have made any mistakes in the past 10 years it is because I have underestimated the amount of criminal activity that has been allowed to flourish in this country under two governments, particularly the present Liberal-National Country Party Government. If that amount of illegal money is floating around, which sort of policeman, judge or politician, no matter what his intregity may be, is safe? Are all Cabinet Ministers safe? Mr Costigan has gone part of the way down the track by suggesting that at this stage there is some evidence that certain justices of the peace are on the take. This morning's newspapers reported the revelations of the Costigan Commission as though they are new. They are not new, but unhappily, as always happens in this country, we wake up too late. I hope that those who are now jumping on to this band wagon will not lose sight of the important issues at stake. We need to look at the nature and extent of the problem and then consider the measures necessary . It is a major growth industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: May I, without offending the listening audience, describe with over simplicity my understanding of what constitutes a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. Let us assume that Mr A and his wife, B, decide to form a company and call it AB Company Pty Ltd. Let us remember that the company is now a separate entity from Mr A and his wife. I will make it simple and say that the company trades for one year and makes a profit of $100,000. The tax payable on that profit of $100,000 is about $42,000. So, when the Commissioner of Taxation puts in his assessment, that company will have net assets of $58,000-namely, $100,000 less the tax to be paid, which is $42,000. Then Mr C, the promoter, the white-collar criminal about whom we are talking today, arrives on the scene and says to Mr A and his wife, B : 'I will give you $80,000 for that company'. They cannot believe their luck. Father Christmas has come early. They have been offered $80,000 for something that is worth $58,000. They accept because they will be $22,000 better off. But Mr C does not buy the company. He gets Mr D and Mr E, who are painters and dockers or a couple of criminals, or Joe Smith and his wife Jessie to buy the company from A and B. As soon as that happens Mr C, the promoter, strips the company. Let us assume that the $100,000 I mentioned is in the bank. Mr C simply draws the money out of the bank as a consulting fee. He has done well. He has paid $80,000 for something for which he receives $100,000, so he is $20,000 in front. The only remaining evidence is held by D and E-the painters and dockers- or Joe and Jessie Smith. They then burn the records or, as the expression goes, send them to the bottom of the harbour never to be seen again. What is outstanding is the $42,000 in tax that has never been paid. If one adds three or six noughts to my little example of $42,000, one has millions or billions of dollars being avoided in tax by this extraordinarily simple device.

It was operated so successfully over nine years or more that the money became too hot to handle, too much profit was going around, so the money had to be laundered. No longer could it be laundered in Australia by a lucrative win at the races or whatever other laundering measures are available for chicken feed illegal money. An international launderer had to be found. Mr Costigan has found that launderer, as has almost simultaneously Mr Justice Stewart, who is conducting a royal commission into drugs. That international launderer was, of course, the Nugan Hand bank, that infamous group which dealt in heroin, obtaining it from Laos and Vietnam and sending it to Australia, then to New Zealand and then to San Francisco, which sold arms to both sides in Kampuchea, and whose directors had unsavoury connections with the Central Intelligence Agency and God knows what. Talking about time bombs in the political world of this country, I believe that future exposures about Nugan Hand will contain more than any others.

This is a serious problem. We would support very strongly an extension of Mr Costigan's powers. If the Australian Labor Party wishes to move for that it will have our total support. One thing I do ask my colleagues from the Labor Party to do is not to turn an intractable eye to the establishment of a crimes commission . Clearly our current law enforcement procedures, our departmental structures and our political setup have failed to stop crime flourishing in this country. Surely a new approach is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am about the nineteenth speaker on this subject. I find it a little difficult to appreciate how it has developed over the various episodes. This is the third occasion on which we have had a tedious, ill-founded and unsubstantiated attack on the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), whose performance by any standard has been both remarkable and admirable. Honourable senators may rest assured that I do not support and I do not know anyone who does support or condone any of the people who are revenue spongers in this country today. I think that this matter has got out of perspective. The political opportunism of it has taken over from the seriousness of it. It will need consideration from the community at large-everybody, including politicians, businessmen and housewives-if we are to do anything about it. I am interested to note that we are discussing a matter of public importance . I think the importance of the third re-run of this matter can be gauged by the fact that we have only to look up to my left at the moment to find that we are being adequately reported by one journalist. I think that in itself should tell- -
—It might be because of the speaker.

—I think that this should tell Senator Evans, with his lack of understanding of this matter, of the degree of importance that everybody else sees in this matter. What he is doing is trying to gain himself a bit of notoriety. Now that Senator Evans has deigned to come back into the chamber, I would like to know just what he said when he started. I would like to know how Senator Evans used his time when he spoke on this matter of public importance. I think I could defy anybody here to tell me what information he provided today that was new, different or important. I do not think Senator Evans in fact has any appreciation of the fact that people with a high capacity for real work, like Senator Durack and others, do not necessarily have to spend their time just yacking. May I remind Senator Evans that it is what people say that counts, not how much they say. Here we are not paid like lecturers for the amount that is said and I think that occasionally Senator Evans fails to appreciate this point.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans, having failed so dismally on two occasions already to make his points against the Attorney-General, I am somewhat surprised that he now turns his attack on the Attorney-General's Department. I do not think it is a very brave or courageous act to turn on the Department at a time like this when departmental officers are unable to be present here or to answer the sorts of allegations and aspersions he is, by innuendo, casting in their direction. The Attorney-General's Department, according to its last annual report, has a staff of 1,177 people. That is a very substantial number of people. I think it is ridiculous to brand them all under the headings of incompetence, maladministration, neglect and delay. These accusations have been made in the name of stupid headline grabbing. They are designed to feed a Press with scraps it might look for and to put up a smokescreen against the real issues.
