I know and deal with many officers of the Attorney-General's Department. They have considerable ability, capacity and integrity. They would be rightly and justly indignant at being lumped into a hotch-potch motion such as this which is full of ridiculous accusations and insinuations. In fact, I would back the integrity, dedication and ability of many of the officers whom I know against the people who make the accusations. I think it is worth bearing this point in mind. Senator Durack by any standards is an excellent administrator. We know that. He handles his duties very well. Nobody answers questions in the chamber more fully and more accurately. In the time I have been in this chamber I have never once seen Senator Durack either retract or qualify one answer or one statement that he has made. That is a remarkable performance. Senator Durack came into this place following a very successful professional career in the real commercial outside world. He is highly regarded, he has been successful and he has a proven record in the administration area.

I think when we start to talk about administration it is not unreasonable that we should start to consider that those who attack his administration could possibly be deemed at some stage to be required to provide an alternative. What sort of administration do honourable senators think that the Australian legal system could expect from an alternative government? Could Australia expect an Attorney-General with such an outstanding knowledge of the law? I think not. Could it expect an Attorney-General with the years of experience in commercial practice in the real world. I think not. Could it expect an Attorney-General with the demonstrated administrative ability that Senator Durack has put together in his years in the real world? Could it expect an Attorney-General who has the established and proven respect of the entire legal system? Australia can be assured that a Labor alternative would be a rather feeble shadow of what we have become accustomed to of late. I would not like to think that the alternative would be some sneering patronising approach that goes with being a man among boys and a boy among men. I think that if that happened we could expect a continuation of the one-track mind operating in an intellectual vacuum of academic law.

An average person like me has little to do with the law and lawyers. But I think we all understand what Senator Durack has done in the areas of the law that affect ordinary people and ordinary business. I certainly fully understand what things like judicial review, defamation changes and freedom of information have meant to ordinary people. I understand what Senator Durack has done in respect of family law, anti-trust law, copyright and things of that sort. I think we all have to bear that in mind. It is a typical baby and bath water situation. I am absolutely amazed that anybody could criticise Senator Durack to this extent.

All the things that Senator Durack has done are very important and are particularly well acknowledged by the community. I really cannot understand why Senator Evans would, if he has the capacity that he claims he has, go to such extraordinary lengths here today to demean himself by trying to belittle the very real things that Senator Durack has done, achieved and established. The things that have come through while Senator Durack has been Attorney-General are noteworthy and worthy. No matter what Senator Evans says, he cannot take away the things that have been achieved. I am only sorry that Senator Evans is so sensitive now that the claims he has made have been shown, on the third occasion , to be so absolutely threadbare.

I think we all know Senator Durack is a very proper man. I have found that he always fully investigates, he appropriately attends to the job at hand and he operates certainly according to the law. It concerns me, as a non-lawyer, to hear certain speakers say that Senator Durack should have ignored or got around section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and that he should have had access to tax documents. I know Senator Durack well enough to know that that is not on. This is why the people of Australia trust him. This is why they know they can trust him. I have not yet had the same assurance from the Opposition nor from the shadow Attorney-General. I would like to have it and so would the people of Australia. I reject the blanket accusation made about the Attorney-General's Department and I again reject the accusation against Senator Durack. I request the Press to report accurately that the Opposition again has pathetically failed to besmirch this excellent Minister. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the course of the debate on the matter of public importance which has just concluded Senator Georges, who unfortunately seems to have left the chamber at this point, made some statements of a personal nature which were directed at me and which I reject and deeply resent. He was a former colleague of mine on two Senate committees. We served on the important Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange which was presided over by our colleague, Senator Peter Rae. We also served together on the Senate Select Committee on the Corporations and Securities Industry Bill 1975 which looked at a Labor Government Bill on securities and companies. I found it very surprising indeed and very hurtful that Senator Georges saw fit to attack me in the way he did with the imputations he made against my character in the course of the debate. He indicated that in his view I was some sort of a stooge on those committees, to delay them and to prevent any effect being given to the committees' reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Georges also spoke in terms of some gross delays which he said occurred from 1971 when I joined the Securities and Exchange Committee and said that nothing was done until July this year. The fact is that the Senate Securities and Exchange Committee, chaired by Senator Rae, which I think was established in 1970, reported to the Senate in July 1974. In fact that was an interim report although it was the most substantial report that has been submitted to the Senate. That Committee had an enormous task of investigation of the areas of abuse in the securities system during the years of the mineral boom in the late 1960s and early 1970s. I played a very active part in the Committee's work and I gave quite a considerable amount of assistance to the officer who was drafting the Committee's report. I was in full agreement with the major recommendation of the report that a national companies and securities watchdog commission should be established. I resent very much indeed the suggestion that in some way I was there to frustrate the work of that Committee.

The Labor Government saw fit to introduce its own version of a national companies and securities system in a typical bureaucratic and utterly complicated piece of legislation which was referred to another committee of which Senator Georges was chairman for a period. That committee was very concerned to ensure that a system that would not make use of the existing expertise and resources was not foisted on the Australian business community but that a system would be established which would be constitutionally effective. That committee did not complete its work because of the double dissolution in 1975. The then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Howard, began work on a system of control of companies and securities which would be effective constitutionally. That resulted in the establishment of the National Companies and Securities Commission, legislation for which was proclaimed in February 1980 , and the Commission was established in March 1980. It is true that the new uniform companies legislation did not come into effect until this year but the Commission was set up and has been working for two and a half years.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, it would appear that the Attorney has completed his personal explanation by denying the motivation that has been alleged of him. He is now debating the matter and it is improper under the Standing Orders for him to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be brief. I just refer to the allegations which were made by Senator Georges of delays and deferrals. As Senator Durack has mentioned , I was the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange. I refute entirely that there were delays. I refute entirely that Senator Durack was involved in causing any.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think that either Senator Rae was not listening or he has misunderstood. He should have clearly understood. What I referred to were delays subsequent to the tabling of the report. No reference was made to the report itself, to its presentation or to Senator Rae's work on the Committee. It merely alluded to-
—Order! Senator Georges, what is your point of order ?
—It is that he has no personal explanation.
—I hear that. I am prepared to make a ruling. Senator Rae, I am listening to what you are saying. Would you please come to the point of your personal explanation or finish whatever you are saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows:

Mr President, the purpose of this Bill is to discharge the responsibilities of the Commonwealth in relation to visits by foreign warships. The Senate will be aware that in recent months the Government of Victoria sought to exclude certain categories of foreign warships from its ports. Somewhat earlier the Government of New South Wales expressed reservations about visits of these same categories of warships to the Port of Sydney. There have also been attempts by some organisations to hinder or put difficulties in the way of such visits. The Government has made quite plain that it will not accept interference with these visits. Visits to Australian ports of foreign warships are an important aspect of Australia's international relations. They have obvious and important implications for our defence and security.

Constitutionally the powers in respect of such matters rest with the Commonwealth. It is the Commonwealth, not the States, that is responsible for the maintenance of defence and international arrangements with other countries. Quite properly the Commonwealth has exercised exclusive authority in this area. It intends to continue to do so. To ensure that there is no uncertainty as to the legal position applicable to the visits of such ships, it is believed that legislation in the form now introduced is essential.

In addition to asserting in practical terms the exclusive authority of the Commonwealth, the Bill will perform two other functions. It will make provision in formal terms for the authorising, on behalf of Australia, of entry to our waters by foreign warships where such entry is desired. The need for authorisation to precede any such visit has long been recognised as a matter of international law and practice. Secondly, the Bill will provide a legal framework for appropriate action to be taken to safeguard approved visits from obstruction or interference. At the same time, the Government expects that there will continue to be co-operation with the relevant State authorities in regard to the visits of foreign warships. In the vast majority of cases over many years such co-operation has been forthcoming.

The Bill specifically adverts in its objects clause to the co-operation and assistance of the States and their authorities in facilitating access to Australian ports for visiting warships. The Government has reiterated in recent statements the importance it attaches to visits to Australia by the warships of allied and friendly countries in the context of our overall defence arrangements . These visits are of the greatest importance, whether they occur in the course of joint exercises, for resupply purposes, for crew recreation or as a practical demonstration of goodwill. We believe that foreign warships should be as free to visit Australian ports as Australian warships are to visit the ports of our friends and allies. The Government has no doubt that its views in this matter are endorsed by the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. It is also relevant to quote from the joint communique issued by the representatives of the Governments of the United States, New Zealand and Australia at the conclusion of the 31st meeting of the ANZUS Council held on the 21st and 22nd June 1982:

'In particular (the Deputy Secretary and the Ministers) confirmed the high priority each partner placed upon a regular and comprehensive programme of naval visits to each other's ports, as well as to friendly ports in the Asia/Pacific region generally. They recognise the importance of access by United States naval ships to the ports of its Treaty partners as a critical factor in its efforts to maintain strategic deterrence and in order to carry out its responsibilities under the terms of the Treaty. In this regard the Australian and New Zealand members declared their continued willingness to accept visits to their ports by United States naval vessels whether conventional or nuclear powered.'

In the light of statements made by the Premier of Victoria and earlier by his counterpart in New South Wales, it is believed that this undertaking may not be capable of implementation without the passage of this legislation. The Government accepts that concerns have been expressed, quite understandably, with particular regard to ships which are nuclear powered or ships which could be carrying nuclear weapons. So far as nuclear powered ships are concerned, the Government's position continues to be that expressed by the Prime Minister in his statement to the House of Representatives of 4 June 1976 on this matter. Subject to compliance with appropriate safety procedures, visits of nuclear powered ships can proceed without significant risk of adverse consequences. With regard to visits by ships which could be carrying nuclear weapons, as has been repeatedly made clear, the position is that the foreign governments concerned will not confirm or deny that a particular ship is carrying nuclear weapons. Again, if I may quote from the ANZUS communique: '(The Ministers and the Deputy Secretary) noted and accepted that it is not the policy of the United States Navy to reveal whether or not its vessels are armed with nuclear weapons.'

To do so in particular cases would over a period of time provide valuable information to potential enemies about the capabilities of the naval forces concerned. The Government accepts this position and will not be seeking disclosure as to whether a particular visiting ship is or is not carrying nuclear weapons. In relation to the safety of nuclear weapons which may be carried on visiting allied warships, the precautions and procedures that are known to be taken by the navies concerned are such as to preclude the possibility of an accidental nuclear detonation. The risk of accidental explosion of the conventional explosive in such weapons is judged to be as small as the risk of an accidental explosion involving conventional weapons carried by our own naval vessels. Such an accident has never happened.

Against this background I turn to the terms of the Bill. As I have already mentioned, the Bill includes an objects clause stating that it is intended to establish procedures for the discharge by the Commonwealth of its constitutional responsibilities and powers. The clause also declares the intention that in furthering the object of the Act the co-operation and assistance of the States and their authorities be sought and utilised, so far as it is appropriate and practicable to do so, in facilitating access to Australian ports for warships visiting Australia. However, the Bill is expressed to operate to the exclusion of any State or Territory laws that would prevent or obstruct any act or thing that a warship or person is empowered or permitted to do by the Bill.

Central to the operation of the legislation is the power given to the Minister for Defence to grant approval for a specified foreign warship, or class of foreign warships, to have access during a specified period to Australian ports or to specified Australian ports. Such an approval may be made subject to conditions. It is envisaged that, in practice, all such approvals will be subject to compliance with conditions relating to navigation and safety, and health, quarantine, customs and immigration requirements. Provision is also made for the Minister to give directions to the commander of a foreign warship in respect of which an approval is in force. Directions may be given about the movement of the ship or its crew or about the loading or unloading of goods. Directions of this nature would essentially be supplementary to the conditions attached to an approval, and could be necessitated by circumstances arising after an approval is given. Where an approval is in force, a foreign warship covered by the approval will be entitled to enter, remain in and depart from an Australian port covererd by the approval. In addition, goods may be loaded on to or unloaded from the ship and services may be supplied to the ship.

Under clause 9 of the Bill, the Minister for Defence is empowered to give directions to facilitate access by a foreign warship to an Australian port, where a relevant approval is in force. These powers would be exercised only as a last resort where access by a foreign warship was being frustrated or significantly hindered by a refusal or failure to provide the goods, services or facilities normally required for that purpose. These might include the provision of pilotage or tug services, the availability of berthing facilities, or the supply of services such as water or electricity. Clause 9 provides that a direction may be given only where the Minister is satisfied that giving the direction is necessary to secure the entry, stay or departure of the ship, or the safety of the ship, its crew or other persons, or is necessary or convenient for the effective operation of the ship. Provision is made for compensation for loss or damage sustained as a result of compliance with a direction. Provision is also made for payment for the provision of goods, services or facilities, or other things, pursuant to a direction.

The Bill will establish offences of preventing, hindering or obstructing the entry of a ship to, the berthing of a ship at, or the departure of a ship from, an Australian port in respect of which a relevant approval is in force. Other offences are provided relating to failure to comply with a direction by the Minister for Defence under clause 9, and of preventing, hindering or obstructing other specified activities relating to a ship. As I have already said, the Government believes that visits to Australian ports by the warships of our friends and allies have the overwhelming support of the Australian people. The Government is confident that this legislation, prompted by threat to the continuance of such visits, will have similar support. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I seek leave to amend the terms of my motion to read as circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid upon the table the following papers relating to the consideration by the Attorney-General, the Attorney-General's Department, the Treasurer, the Department of the Treasury and/or the Australian Taxation Office of possible legal action, civil or criminal, against those participating in bottom-of-the-harbour or similar tax avoidance and evasion schemes, subject to the deletion from such papers of the names and identifying characteristics of individuals to the extent necessary to satisfy the requirements of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act:
1. Federal Commissioner of Taxation's minutes relating to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes (Treasurer's Press release 27 June 1981, page 7)

2. Advice from counsel (unnamed) provided to Taxation head office, and comments from Deputy Crown Solicitor in relation thereto, in respect of company stripping case reported in April 1976 (Treasurer's Press release 27 June 1982, pages 14-15 )
3. Legal advice provided to the Government that existing law was insufficient ( Treasurer's Press release 27 June 1982, page 16)
4. Australian Taxation Office's 'further reports' about company stripping ( Treasurer's Press release 27 June 1982, page 17)
5. Advice from officers of Taxation Office, Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and Attorney-General's that existing law deficient (Treasurer's press release p. 21)

6. Legal advice 'unanimously subscribed to by the Crown Solicitor, the Acting First Assistant Parliamentary Counsel and his officers, senior officers of the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, and the Taxation Office' (Treasurer's press release p. 35)
7. Opinion of Lockhart Q.C. supplied between 1976 and 1978 to Sydney office of Deputy Crown Solicitor (referred to on Nationwide, 1/9/82 and in Senate 7/9/82)

8. Advice from Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor to Sydney Deputy Crown Solicitor in 1977 regarding a bottom-of-the-harbour case referred by Sydney to Perth ( referred to on Nationwide, 3/9/82 and in Senate 7/9/82)
9. Memoranda written by officers of Sydney Deputy Crown Solicitor in response to Perth advice (referred to on Nationwide, 3/9/82 and in Senate 7/9/82)
10. Legal opinion circulated last week (September 1982) by Treasurer to Government backbenchers relating to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.
11. Minute from Federal Committee of Taxation dated May 1978 (quoted by Treasurer in House, 25 August 1982)
12. Opinion of Mr Brinsden Q.C. provided to Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office December 1974 (Costigan report p. 35)
13. Opinion of Mr Brinsden Q.C. provided to Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office June 1975 (Costigan report p. 36)
14. Opinion of unnamed Sydney Q.C. provided to Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in early 1976 in relation to Norfolk Island matter (Costigan report pp. 40-41)
15. Report of police investigators into Perth matter November 1976 (Costigan report p. 43)
16. Opinion of Mr Traill Q.C. in July 1978 (Costigan report p. 76)
17. Opinion of Messrs. Ormiston Q.C. and Spry in 1978, provided to Federal Commissioner of Taxation (Costigan report p. 75)
18. Opinion of Melbourne Q.C. provided to liquidator of Keirad Pty Ltd. (quoted in House of Representatives by Hon. Lionel Bowen, 17 August 1982)
19. Advice by Crown Solicitor to Australian Taxation Office in April 1979 ( Costigan report p. 64)
20. Advice by Crown Solicitor to Australian Taxation Office in September 1980 ( Costigan report pp. 67, 85)
21. Solicitor-General's advice to Treasurer July 1982 (Treasurer's statement 29 July 1982)

22. Any document containing the opinion of Mr Gleedman, Mr O'Sullivan or Mr Massie of Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office regarding possible prosecutions arising out of the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme discussed in chapter 3 of the Costigan report, volume 1.

The motion is moved with the support, I understand, of the Australian Democrats and, I hope, of the Independent Senator Harradine, if not yet with the support of the Government or individual Government members. I make it clear at the outset that this motion, which requires the Government to table a series of 22 specifically designated papers, or groups of papers, relating to the Government' s knowledge or consideration of the prosecution of those participating in bottom -of-the-harbour schemes, is not moved with any desire to make it a vehicle for what might be described on the other side of this chamber as another rehash of the issues that have achieved so much prominence in the last three weeks. Rather my desire, and that of the Opposition and those who I hope will support the motion, is to enable the Parliament and the community as a whole to form its own view of what must still be described as the most colossal, in terms of cost, single failure of public administration in Australia's history.

Senator Durack has refused to resign as a result of this colossal blunder-if that is an appropriate word for it-saying that he was not culpable or negligent for failing to ask questions about the progress of prosecutions in bottom-of-the -harbour matters or for failing actually to take steps to advance those prosecutions. He said, rather, that he simply relied, as he usually does, on departmental advice and that he is not to be held personally responsible for any failing that might conceivably have been involved at the departmental level. Similarly, Mr Howard, the Treasurer, has taken the same kind of position; that it was all someone else's fault, it was not his. The matter got lost somewhere in that interdepartmental jungle which lies in the terrain between the Australian Taxation Office and the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney- General's office across the way.

If they will not resign, if they will not accept the force of the proposition that has been advanced so strenuously by the Opposition, not to mention the country's media over the last few days, that the Westminster conventions as they operate in Australia demand their resignation on the material now available on the public record, the next step, as the Opposition perceives it, is to ascertain who, then, was responsible. Was it simply those two or three people right down at the bottom of the departmental hierarchy in the Attorney-General's Department who sat on their hands for reasons of either negligence or possibly worse motives than that; was it at a more senior level within the Department, given that the Central Office of the Crown Solicitor's Division did after all advise the Commissioner of Taxation in 1978 that in its institutional view prosecutions would not lie; or did responsibility extend in a direct way higher up the tree still to the Ministers themselves?

There must be someone in the system who not only gets the blame for what went wrong but also can be seen to deserve that blame. The only way that that blame can begin to be established and rightly located is by the tabling of all the information, all the relevant documents, that will enable an even better judgment to be made of the situation than we have been able to make so far. It is only when all the relevant documents in this unhappy matter are tabled that we will know what opinions were available to whom and when they were available. It is only then that we will know what advices were given by whom and to whom and when. It is only then, when we have had an opportunity to scrutinise these documents, that we will actually know or be able to judge what the quality, respectively, of those advices and opinions was and whether there was any real justification for the failure of the Attorney-General's Department to advise these prosecutions. It is only then that we will know whether it is arguable that reasonable men-indeed even reasonable lawyers, if there is such a breed- were capable of differing about the possibility of such a prosecution or set of prosecutions prevailing.

The Opposition has taken the view so far that the events in this matter speak for themselves, that the culpability of the Ministers-particularly Senator Durack-is obvious. The Government has refused to accept that view. I acknowledge that the same position has been taken by some others so far, including perhaps Senator Harradine, who would no doubt welcome an opportunity to satisfy themselves further and more directly about the merits of this particular matter. I believe that access to these documents will enable, if not the whole truth to emerge finally, at least us to get some distance down that particular track.

The papers sought are set out in the terms of the amended motion. The amended motion substitutes a detailed list of 22 specifically designated papers, or in some instances groups of papers, for the original formulation of the motion which, as I gave notice of it yesterday, referred simply to all papers relating to the consideration of this matter by the relevant Ministers and officials. We have taken the view on further reflection that perhaps it was imposing too much of an unreasonable burden on the Government to ask it to sift through the potentially enormous volume of materials that presumably exist in this general subject area within the departments and to produce those documents accordingly. We have taken the view that it is, all in all, a more reasonable approach to adopt to identify with some precision the particular documents which we think should be made available, put on the public record and made subject to detailed scrutiny. We believe that this will make it very difficult indeed for the Attorney-General or anyone else in the Government to refuse the production of these documents on the ground of the unreasonable width or breadth of the request.

So, although there are substantial and ample precedents in this place for a motion in terms simply of seeking access to all documents or papers in existence relating to a particular matter, we have chosen the path of moderation and reasonableness-not that we seem to have had much credit for it from the Attorney -General in his performance a few minutes ago-and we ask only for a series of specifically identified documents. The documents in question in this list are those which have been referred to by Government Ministers themselves, either by Mr Howard in his lengthy Press release of 27 June or in subsequent statements, by Senator Durack in one or two other instances or which, if they have not specifically been brought to public attention by the Government itself, have come to public attention in the last two or three weeks by other means. Thus it is that we are seeking the production of a series of opinions from learned counsel relating to cases going back to the mid-1970s which have been the subject of so much discussion, including in particular the test case in the Perth office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor-we also seek a number of more recent opinions including those which have been circulated to Government members in recent days-in order that we and the public at large can better form a view as to where the blame lies, where the merits lie and where the truth lies in this matter. We are seeking access also to a number of departmental minutes of advice which passed from the Australian Taxation Office to the Treasurer and from officials of the Attorney-General's Department to the Minister.

We seek these documents to the extent that in these cases, as in others, those papers do not reveal the names of individuals. I make it absolutely clear that the text of this motion and my intention in moving it are not to bring by this means to public light the names of those individuals who are under active scrutiny at the moment with the possibility of prosecutions lying. We appreciate the force of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act in at least requiring- or at most requiring, if I may put it that way-that the names and other identifying characteristics of individual taxpayers, or those who should be paying tax, be deleted. The terms of this motion recognise the requirement of the law and the policy that lies behind it, and acknowledges the force of both that law and policy. We do not seek a revelation of names by this means.

What we do seek, of course, is the substance of the opinions, the substance of the advice that flowed as to whether particular prosecutions could lie at a particular time, the advice as to what the state of the existing law was. That advice can be perfectly well communicated consistently with section 16 of the Act and consistently with matters of principle to which it is appropriate to have regard. It is not our desire in any way to prejudice the possible success of future prosecutions in this area by given untoward publicity to the position of any giving individual. It is our desire to get to the bottom, to strike a phrase, of the maladministration that has on the face of it so obviously occurred in the departmental consideration of these matters and in the decisions at the ministerial level to proceed by way of new legislation, belatedly rather than expeditiously, with the prosecution of those who clearly, on the face of it , could have been prosecuted.

I make the further point in relation to the papers that are here sought that the particular papers referred to in this motion are by and large those which have already featured substantially in either questions or contributions to debates in the Senate or the House of Representatives. By and large we have sought already the tabling of every single one of the documents referred to. There may be a handful of exceptions but certainly that is true as a generalisation. As a result, the Government should by now be in absolutely no doubt as to what it is that we are seeking the tabling of and why it is that we are so seeking.

There can be no real justification for the Government's claim, made again in proceedings a few minutes ago by Senator Durack, that more time is needed before the Government can formulate a response as to whether it will be prepared to accede to the production of these particular documents. We were prepared- certainly I was initially prepared-to accede to the Government's request, as I understood it, that it have another 24 hours following the moving of this motion by me now in which to consider its position before we finally debated this matter. I am profoundly unhappy with the indications given by Senator Durack a few minutes ago that the Government may well want considerably more than 24 hours to consider its position. I make it clear from this side of the chamber that unless he is prepared and indicates, as I understand he was proposing to in reply to my speech, that it is only a matter of 24 hours, I will certainly feel disposed to press this matter to fruition today. I would request the Senate to proceed with full consideration of this matter and not to adjourn it today. There simply can be no excuse for any further delay in the Government's consideration of this matter beyond the 24 hours until the matter can be debated tomorrow, as was originally foreshadowed by the Minister. I would be grateful if those on the opposite benches could quickly establish from the Minister what the proposed position is, because certain things have been communicated to the Whips and to me about a 24 hours delay. If it is proposed to change that, then, as I say, I shall be disposed to press on with this matter right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —May we have a couple of moments, Senator?
—Certainly. I have a few more things to say, which will give Senator Baume an opportunity to check the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I anticipate, from what the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said earlier this week, that one line that the Government may be disposed to take in response to this request for the tabling of papers is that the Government may be prepared to table papers if the papers in question satisfy criteria laid down in the Freedom of Information Act passed by this Parliament but, of course, not yet proclaimed into effect. At first sight that may seem to be a rational and generous offer on the part of the Prime Minister, but in reality it is very far from that. I say that for three reasons.

In the first place, the criteria for the production of official documents laid down in the present Freedom of Information Act are very far from commanding universal acceptance. Had the Opposition acceded to the terms of the Freedom of Information Act and actively supported the language of that Act, there might be something to be said-not much, but something-for the position that the Prime Minister seems to have carved out. But it must be well known that the Opposition has taken the view all along that the Freedom of Information Act is far too restrictive a code to be the last word in terms of open government and access to government papers in important matters of public administration. For that reason , among others, we take the view that the mere adherence or otherwise, on the face of it, to Freedom of Information Act standards cannot possibly be a good enough ground for a final determination as to whether these documents should be produced.

The second point I make is that the Freedom of Information Act is not yet in operation, and in particular the appeals structure associated with that Act is not yet in operation. I mean the limited review role given to the Ombudsman and the much greater review roles given respectively to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the proposed Documents Review Tribunal. It is the case that when the Freedom of Information Act is in full operation an applicant for the release of documents who is dissatisfied by a government's decision, who responds unhappily to a government's decision to deny access to documents, will have a right of review and a right to seek redress for that initially adverse decision, in the first instance by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, or in certain cases the Documents Review Tribunal, with the Ombudsman exercising an additional review role as well.

None of those redress mechanisms is available at present, and should the Government be minded to say flatly that it refuses access to these documents on the ground that they do not satisfy in the Government's opinion the criteria in the Freedom of Information Act, there is simply no way yet in existence for that opinion of the Government to be independently objectively tested. So that is a second reason why it is inappropriate to apply Freedom of Information Act criteria to the decision as to whether the Government will release these documents.

The third point I make in this area is that freedom of information criteria are in any event not absolute criteria. Even as they exist in the Act now, they can always be waived by the government of the day. They give the government grounds, if it so chooses to rely on them, for refusal of access to documents, but they do not demand that documents satisfying those criteria be refused. In a fully flourishing freedom of information legislation environment it is always open for the government to ignore completely any constraints on its capacity to deliver documents, or not to insist on any such limitations, and be freely willing to make these documents available. I simply make the point that the barriers in question are essentially artificial. For those reasons, they should not be erected in this instance by the Prime Minister. It is not a reasonable position to take, whatever the initial plausibility of it might be.

Having talked long enough for a flurry of Whip-like activity to take place around the chamber, perhaps I might be given some indication, by way of interjection, of whether the Government has now accepted the 24 hours suggestion .

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is intended to list the matter for tomorrow.
—And for the matter to come on for debate?
—No, I have been advised that it is intended to list the matter.
—Perhaps I might be given leave to add further to my remarks in the event that subsequent advice is different. I could speak on the motion to adjourn.
—Just stamp your foot if you do not like what you hear.

—I shall be stamping on something more than my foot in a moment if Senator Chaney persists with that attitude. I conclude by saying that the Opposition is sensitive to the justifications that might be advanced for caution in the release of certain of these documents. We do not want to prejudice effective prosecutions. We certainly do not want to be in the position of causing any breach of the legitimate requirements of section 16, that much over relied upon section of the Income Tax Assessment Act. But we believe that the documents should be tabled, subject to the conditions that we are now acceding to-namely, that there be deleted from such papers any names and identifying characteristics of individuals to the extent necessary to ensure that those rules are not breached. In those circumstances, with those conditions, there is simply no justification for the Government refusing access to these documents.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: It is only by access to these documents that it will be possible now, given the attitude that the Government has taken, for an objective view to be reached as to where the merits and the truth lie. If the Government has anything to hide, I can understand its continued reluctance to make these documents available. If the Government believes, however, that its Ministers and senior officials have acted throughout reasonably and with a proper sense of responsibility to the public at large, the Government should not hesitate for one second to put these documents in the public domain to enable the truth of that perception to be established once and for all.

Basically, the Australian Democrats vigorously support the motion of Senator Evans. For reasons that have been discussed all afternoon, documents need to be produced so that the Parliament, which should be the supreme authority in these matters, can have the information about tax evasion rather than continue to allow that state of affairs to exist where the information about tax evasion has been limited to the Public Service, the bureaucracy or, in some cases some Ministers. We have said time and time again that the Parliament is entitled to know that information, which was one of the reasons we joined Senator Evans and others in championing and supporting the Bill brought in by the Government for freedom of information.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that I say that when a House of Parliament demands the production of confidential documents there may be some who would accuse it of grandstanding . If a group of anti-government forces, or whatever the case may be, for a moment wanted the production of documents against a government's wish, the accusation of possible grandstanding could well be levelled against it. I suggest that in this case the accusation is not sustained because we are not talking about a penny-ante cheap political point. We are talking about something worth thousands of millions of dollars. —I am constrained to mention to you that we are debating a motion about the resumption of this debate. I really should ask you to keep your remarks pertinent to that motion.

—A lot depends on this. Senator Evans has already given notice- threatened is too harsh a word; a gentle soul like Senator Evans seldoms threatens-that unless the Government reintroduces this debate within 24 hours he will take action now. I would have thought that every word I have said is pertinent to the question before the chair, namely, that the debate be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting. It is absolutely relevant. I come to the point. I suggested to the Attorney that surely, by negotiation between the Attorney, Senator Evans, myself as Leader of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine, if material is included in these 22 documents that is so sensitive that, in our combined judgment, it would prejudice a successful prosecution against a tax avoider, then I would hope that we would agree-I hope by a consensus-that that document either should not be tabled or should be disguised in some other form. That seemed to me to be an absolutely reasonable point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney went on to say that to make a decision-I do not know; I have not gone through the nature of each of the 22 documents-may well take longer than 24 hours. I apologise again to Senator Evans. I have not had a chance to get his reaction to this. But as I understand it, at this stage that seems to me to be a reasonable request from the Attorney, particularly with regard to counsel's opinions about people against whom it is proposed to lay charges. I would be deeply grateful if for once in this place we could have a spirit of consensus. If the Labor Party could agree to negotiate with the Government in company with Senator Harradine and me on what documents could be extremely sensitive and what documents could not be, that would be an eminently sensible solution to what is now becoming a difficult situation.

As far as the Democrats are concerned, we will support the thrust of the Labor Party's amendment. If co-operation is not forthcoming from the Government we will take the further inevitable step-which we would hesitate to do-of calling public servants to the bar of this chamber, which I am extraordinarily reluctant to agree to do. But that will be the inevitable conclusion if we do not get co- operation from the Government. As I am informed by the Attorney up to this point , the Government realises that it has very little option but to produce the documents. But the argument espoused by the Attorney, that there may be difficulty in terms of possible criminal charges by prematurely disclosing certain information, certainly makes some sense.
