SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the somewhat dramatic debate today dealing with the deficiencies in the Attorney-General's Department and tax evasion, I suppose one would say that the debate on the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill seems small fry. However, I stress that this is a piece of legislation that indicates another decline in the Government's area of responsibility. Though the Opposition decided to agree to the Government's general package in the Budget, nevertheless it does have a great deal to say about what is happening to the airline industry in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this legislation is to provide for increases of some 20 per cent in air navigation charges on domestic trunk lines and regional airlines and a 12 per cent increase for general aviation. As it is part of the Budget package we do not oppose the Bill. However, I think the Opposition has an obligation to point out that the latest impost will increase cost pressures on the domestic airlines at a time when the industry in this country-as indeed elsewhere throughout the world-is clearly in a state of serious downturn and when domestic traffic is almost stagnant. I think one has only to travel on the airlines to appreciate the decline in service. One has only to listen to passengers generally to appreciate the concern of the travelling public about what is happening to Australia's airline industry. The increases which are proposed in this legislation will add at least 1 per cent to the overall operating costs of the airlines. That means, of course, that the airlines will be seeking to increase their domestic air fares to recover the additional air navigation costs . Doing that will be very difficult for the airlines, suffering as they are from cost pressures and a decline in air traffic movement generally. It will exacerbate the current crisis that is facing our domestic airlines today.

The latest air navigation charges form part of a Government proposal to increase revenue. It is the most recent in a series of attacks by the Fraser Government on the domestic aviation industry. The Government's handling of our aviation industry, which is faced with an economic downturn, is characterised by increasing costs on the one hand and a lack of planning and co-ordination on the other. The decline in standards of service and safety is obvious to every airline passenger. In this circumstance the general public suffers most. Fewer people are able to travel. The ones who do travel are faced with greater costs, greater inconvenience and fewer safety standards. The Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill, or any of the other aviation related legislation brought before the Senate by the Government, does not address itself properly to any of these problems.

Surely the Government must be aware of the decline that is taking place in the industry. Certainly those members of parliament who travel by Trans-Australia Airlines must be concerned about what is happening to our Government airline. One could almost get the impression that there is a deliberate attempt on the part of the Government to reduce the effectiveness and the capacity of our Government-owned airline. Every time I travel I find that services have been cancelled or reduced or that they run late. From that experience one can only gain that something is radically wrong with the Government's airline and with the Government's concern, or lack of it, for what is happening to TAA. The Fraser Government's mismanagement of the situation is having a detrimental effect. It can be seen that the number of air passengers carried in 1981-82 increased by a meagre 0.8 per cent over the previous year 1980-81. Clearly, Australians are voting with their feet by not patronising the services offered. There has been a marked decline in the services operating from our capital cities to our national capital, Canberra. There would not be many members of parliament or members of the travelling public who have not noticed the very serious decline in Canberra services.

General aviation is already struggling to survive. It is struggling under the burden of increased sales taxes which were imposed in last year's Budget and this year's Budget, and from increased fuel and wage costs. Heaven only knows that the increase in fuel costs will have another effect of increasing the problems facing our domestic airline industry. All of these factors combined will bring about a dramatic fall off in demand for the services of general aviation. There have already been widespread retrenchments in the industry. The increased sales taxes, the increase in petroleum charges and the increased navigation charges, which are provided for in this Bill, will exacerbate the industry's plight. One must surely express concern about what appears to be the complete indifference of the Government to this problem.

The air navigation charges which are altered by this Bill cover expenditure in the areas of airport facilities, safety and meteorological and air navigation services. It is essential, therefore, that the provision of these services is responsibly planned and that those services are efficiently provided. But neither of these criteria is being met by the legislation or the Fraser Government. Let us look at what I am saying. The Government and its conservative predecessors have not applied themselves to any sort of comprehensive or desirable national airport program over any period. Decisions on airport development are made on an ad hoc, unplanned basis. The main factors in the decision making process seem to be the date of the next election and the narrowness of the margin by which the Government holds a seat.

I refer to the indecisiveness of the Government in respect of Sydney Airport. Scant regard has been paid to the priorities expressed by the industry, to the impact of the air fare structure to future costs being generated by airport investment or by the provision of the services that are involved. One can only ask, a year after the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, where are we in respect of our domestic airline industry in this country? I have referred to the problems facing Sydney Airport. This is a prime example of the lack of forward planning and of the Fraser Government's incompetence. Only recently has the Government expressed concern at the airport needs of Sydney. Those of us who travel to Sydney will appreciate that sometimes, because of traffic movement into Sydney Airport, aircraft have to fly around Sydney for 15 or 20 minutes before they are able to land. This situation is allowed to exist under a government whose Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, is supposed to be involved in a campaign to conserve fuel. Practically every plane that flies to Sydney is forced to get into a queue and spend time and waste fuel before it can land at Sydney Airport. This is due to a lack of forward planning in respect of Mascot Airport.

The newly appointed Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) has suddenly discovered that there is a problem with the current Sydney Airport. All I can say is that it is about time this was discovered. Back in 1970 I was appointed, as a representative of local government, by a conservative government to examine the needs of Sydney Airport. At that stage we were concerned with the matters such as aircraft noise, aircraft traffic and the need for forward planning in respect of providing a second airport in the Sydney region. Information was available to us 12 years ago regarding that aspect. Yet the new Minister has suddenly discovered-he has been around for long enough-that there is a major problem. Where has he applied himself to this problem other than to say that something has to be done about resolving the impasse that exists between the views of the New South Wales State Government and the Federal Government.

For some 15 years conservative governments have fiddled around with the airport needs of Sydney. They have preferred to politicise the issues involved rather than seek a co-operative and sensible solution to the problem. I know that Government members will say: 'Why did it not happen between 1972 and 1973?' Let us look at what happened in those three years. We cannot put every problem that exists in government administration back to those three years. We must recognise that during those three years we had to face three elections as a result of the intransigent position taken by the conservatives in the Senate. Under that sort of atmosphere and environment the Whitlam Government attempted to look at a whole variety of problems in many areas that had been neglected by the Commonwealth. In respect of this matter the Whitlam Government sought the co- operation of the then Liberal Government in New South Wales, the Askin Government. The Whitlam Government never received any co-operation from that Government.

Now that this conservative Government is back in power in Canberra it suggests that the Wran Government is holding up a decision in respect of Sydney's airport problems. The Wran Labor Government in New South Wales faces a political campaign from the Federal Government which seeks to sheet home the blame on the State for the problems of airports in both city and country areas in New South Wales. What we need is a genuine attempt at Federal and State co-operation; it is not taking place. The opportunity is therefore available to us to debate that subject when discussing this piece of legislation. One can only hope that some initiative will be taken. I notice that the honourable member for Barton in the other place, Mr Bradfield, has suggested a near country area in the outer suburbs of Sydney as the place where a second airport ought to go. Certainly that is the view of all the residents in the St George, Botany, Marrickville and Sutherland areas. Those living in the areas around the present airport support, to the very last man and woman, the New South Wales Government's view that there ought to be no further extension of Sydney Airport and that there ought to be, as there is in every other capital city in the world, a second airport provision . It is about time this Government got off its backside and really set about making a decision in that respect in concert with the New South Wales Government .

Let us look at the other hallmarks of the Fraser Government's maladministration of the aviation industry. The past years have been marked by understaffing of the Department of Transport, the degradation of the supervision of air safety standards, the ignoring accorded the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, the Walter ultra-large fire tenders fiasco, the crippling shortage of air traffic controllers that led to the closure of the Brisbane Airport, the chaos that has been caused in air services to Canberra, our national capital, and a massive 220 per cent increase in air fares since 1975, just to give a few examples.

We ought to remember that it was the decision of this Government to increase the short haul fare structure to seek a growth in traffic for the long haul trips. A dramatic fall off in passenger movements on the short haul routes has resulted from that decision combined with a determination by many business firms to move their personnel from first class travel to economy class. So in fact the Government has not been able to profit from those decisions that were made in 1981. The Government's response to these problems has been to move aviation from being part of a portfolio embodying other components of transport, thus encouraging further disintegration, as we see it, and disorganisation. I think we are at the stage where we need a Minister to handle aviation on its own. The Australian Labor Party argues that there should be a co-ordinated and across-the -board approach to aviation. Such an approach should include different grades of air fares, including cheaper no-frills fares, to enable a wider range of people to travel, a national airports authority to plan, develop and operate our major airports-surely that is a desirable objective-and an approach which gives country dwellers a fair go and which ensures that those who pay are those who can afford to pay. I think the Government has to accept that there is a problem of growing intensity in our domestic airline industry.

In summary, the Bill continues the upward pressure on aviation industry costs. It will force air fares higher and higher under the policy being pursued by this Government, which sees it as a revenue area. It will create greater problems for the general aviation industry, including passenger movement. All we can say is that when there is a change of government we will ensure that there is an improved efficiency in the provision of services to the Australian aviation industry and, most of all, that the travellers in this country, after many years of conservative administration, will get a fair deal. I can assure the Government that there is a great deal of criticism, even from its own back bench and certainly by most members of the travelling public, about the deterioration of services-this is characteristic of the airline industry-that has taken place over the last six months. Just as we have been critical of the deficiencies in the administration of the Attorney-General's Department, we join the chorus so far as the aviation industry and the Department of Transport are concerned.
Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill 1982 follows the introduction last year of a similar Bill which raised quite considerably the charges on a range of aviation operations in line with the Government's intention to recoup from the industry itself 100 per cent of the costs. I wish to refer to one part of the Bill in particular, not because some of the charges in other areas are not inequitable, but because the charges in this area are grossly inequitable. This is the reason the Australian Democrats will be opposing this Bill. I refer to the general aviation charges. What we have here in terms of increased charges on general aviation is yet another impost on a group of people in our society who have enough difficulties at the moment without this Government adding excessively to their costs. I refer particularly to the people who live in remote parts of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The 12 per cent increase proposed in general aviation charges comes on top of increased sales taxes connected with small aircraft and increased avgas charges and wage costs. All of these charges are increasing at a time when the Government professes to be concerned about people affected by drought. It may not be generally known that the general aviation industry is of crucial importance to Australia's outback. The large rural areas of South Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia in particular will be hit excessively hard by the increase in general aviation charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —On top of the 20 per cent last year.

—On top of the 20 per cent increase last year. The cost increases in other areas-for example, the regional airline sector-will also hit those areas very hard. But then, of course, they have already been hit so hard that to get around the west of Queensland one has to go on a milk run flight. It takes one longer to get from Brisbane to any of the major outback centres than to get from Brisbane to Singapore. The isolation of many people in outback areas will be increased by these increased charges because the general aviation sector has to pass on those charges to the very few passengers and the equipment and goods it carries to rural areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I should give some examples. I will come to the National Country Party' s stance on this matter a little later. The typical owner-operator of an air charter service or air taxi service in these areas would run the only charter service for some considerable distance-probably hundreds of miles. Therefore, the air taxi service operates as the ambulance for the area and the major communications source for the area. It operates as a life stream for small western towns. Over 90 per cent of the people who use those types of operations are people who have no access to government funded public transport systems. They do not have access to bus systems or railway systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or decent roads.

—Or road systems that are in any way comparable with the type that the people of urban Australia are used to and demand. Those people are already suffering difficulties from living in remote and isolated areas and they deserve much better treatment from the Government not only in high profile ways, such as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) outlined recently in relation to drought relief, but also in other ways. This treatment needs to be applied across the board; it should not be highly selective. We should not give with one hand and take away with the other.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Government's air navigation charges, as they run through the system, an outback owner-operator would have to pay in the region of $3,000 to register a twin-engine aircraft and roughly $2,000 to register his back-up aircraft, which would normally be a single-engine aircraft. This fee was levied and argued for at the time to offset infrastructure charges. The startling fact is that rural users are precisely the people who use these government facilities least of all. An outback owner-operator who is flying of the order of 600 flying hours in an operational year could typically look at under 20 hours of operation on a government aerodrome or within a government flight information area. Added to that he would operate up to 10 hours under the air traffic control systems which are currently, of course, in larger centres. These flyers would use government services and facilities rarely. Certainly they would not be used to the extent to justify the types of charges which are currently being proposed or which have been levied on them.

The big costs in aviation occur at the larger international airports with the expenditure on modern technology, radar facilities and air traffic controllers, who are highly qualified people. To the rural operator these airports are a Star Wars operation compared with the 2,000 feet of gravel he has to land on and take off from. Indeed, the only time that many operators in the outback, particularly farmers who operate aircraft on their properties, ever see a government aerodrome is once in every 100 hours when they have to land on one for a flight service check. When one talks to rural owner-operators one is told that they have absolutely no objection to the user-pays principle. Their objection is that they are paying for a service that they are not using.

It is inevitable that the charges imposed on these operational businesses will be passed on. It is reasonable to assume that an owner-operator in my own State of Queensland-I believe that the figure would be similar in other States-could look to carrying 150 to 175 passengers per year. On that calculation the Government charges would be in the vicinity of $20 extra per passenger. This is not the nominal increase that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) spoke about in his second reading speech. On a commercial flight the increases would add a couple of cents per passenger, but on the air taxi service we are looking at $20 per passenger. Again, that is an impost on the rural areas which are currently undergoing tremendous hardships.

In the outback of Australia the aeroplane is not a toy. It is not an operational vehicle to take up at weekends for joy flights. It is an essential element, an essential part of the whole operation of a decentralised system. It is not a substitute for the car or the truck. It is very often a matter of life or death. The use of air taxis, which often fly outside their licences as they are allowed to do on mercy flights, in fact provides many of the western Queensland towns with a safety net which is all too often forgotten. In my State of Queensland, for example, it is not possible to take by road a seriously injured person from somewhere such as Charleville, Cunnamulla, Thargomindah or Quilpie-those remote centres-to the centralised hospital system that operates in the States with good quality and top class medical attention. The costs are picked up by the State government and often a doctor will recommend that the patient, who may not even be suffering from a serious complaint, be taken by aircraft because of the state of the roads. Those aircraft provide that safety net. If one cares to go and talk to the people in those towns, one will find that it is of vital concern to them to know that if their children are injured they can get them into hospital in rapid time.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a price.

—The price is picked up by the State governments. But, unfortunately, in many areas the cost often is carried on. Of course, in many areas the aeroplane is used as an agricultural tool for sheep mustering, fence checking, keeping track on water supplies-especially in times of drought-and the operation of crop dusters. As I have said, many farmers use their aircraft solely on their properties. They are not interested in going off their properties except when they are required to do so every 100 flying hours to comply with the regulations governing inspections. I am talking about a person who probably looks after his plane, has built his airstrip and who in Queensland often has to operate on his own on a sighted flight plan as the beacons are so often down. He never flies to a government aerodrome and yet is charged these exorbitant charges under the pseudonym of 'the user pays'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that these costs ought to be borne fairly and evenly across the community. We believe that as a part of any reasonable decentralisation program light aircraft should not be seen as one of the luxuries that people might enjoy in rural areas, but as one of the necessities to support rural Australia. We also believe it is important that Australia looks at defraying the expenses of these operations not only in the way that the Government has done. For example, in Canada the Department of Defence pays for the use of radar beacons and associated defence equipment. In Australia we source none of those charges back to the Department of Defence. We source them all to general aviation, commercial aviation or regional aircraft. I do not understand why the Department of Defence here ought to be excluded when in Canada the Department of Defence picks up those charges as a defence necessity. After all, it would be a defence necessity to have that type of equipment right the way across Australia even if we were not operating commercial aircraft at all. Therefore, I think it is reasonable for the Government-not as a subsidy or a handout but as part of the costs that must be borne by it for operating defence-to ensure that parts of the charges be shot home to the Department of Defence.

Over and above that, I believe that the people who operate in general aviation could very well look to the government for a massive decrease in those charges on the basis of any fair minded inquiry into what the general aviation sector actually uses. From inquiries that have been made so far it appears that anyone will admit that that should be so. Anyone who has ever been to meetings with people in general aviation will know this. Government spokesmen have admitted it at such meetings, yet they come into the Parliament and vote against it. They stand up in western Queensland and talk about general aviation but they will not vote against the legislation. The same happens with Government spokesmen in South Australia, New South Wales and Western Australia. They talk about the fact that charges to general aviation are vastly in excess of anything that the users could be reasonably said to be using, yet they vote the very opposite in this chamber. I have spoken against these charges at a large number of meetings in Queensland. I will vote against them and so will the other Democrat senators.

TALK.START.PARA: -We have just heard Senator Macklin talking and I am very pleased to hear that he recognises the role of light aircraft in western Queensland. He talks like a new found convert. I hope the conversion keeps up. As one who has lived in that area for many years, and who does venture out only occasionally to see what is going on, I am very mindful of the role that light aircraft play and of the role of the air traffic control system that they use. Of course, not all the aircraft use the system all of the time in those areas but they all use it some of the time. They may fly from their own airstrips but every time they contact flight service or get into an air traffic control area they use the system. Any time they get lost the whole ramifications of the search and rescue facilities are there. I am mindful of the fact that they do not use it all the time but they certainly use it some of the time. For that reason, as a senator for that area and as a member of the Government transport committee, I have fought against the full cost recovery being levied on general aviation. At this stage, as I understand it, only 15 per cent of cost recovery is levied on general aviation. The rest is borne by the community--
—In 1981 it was increased by 20 per cent; it is 12 per cent under this Bill.

—I think-I am sure the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) will correct this-that regional airlines bear 25 per cent of cost recovery and general aviation bears 15 per cent. That is something that I have consistently fought for and will continue to do so. The community recognises the benefit of these things. It is my understanding that that is recognised in the legislation and that general aviation does not bear the full cost recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I address myself to some of the remarks made before dinner by Senator Gietzelt in relation to the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill. He rightly drew our attention to the question of safety in air standards throughout Australia. No doubt it is a matter of great pride for Australians that we are amongst those nations with the highest record in standards of safety in the world. This has applied for many years and is something which we hold as very dear and as a very important part of our aviation policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a little disappointed to hear Senator Gietzelt remark that he thought the standards were in decline. Certainly, I do not believe that he is able to bring forward evidence to demonstrate that at all. That aside, it is a matter of great concern to the Department of Aviation, certainly to this Government, that the highest standards be maintained in the safety area. That is something for which we all strive and fortunately, over the years, we have been successful. Senator Gietzelt spoke of the non-existence of a Ministry of Aviation and sought the establishment of one. He may have missed the changes in the administrative arrangements that occurred on 7 May of this year when, in fact, the Department of Aviation was created.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was using old notes.

—Perhaps he was referring to notes made when the Bill was previously before the Senate. A Department of Aviation has now been established and, I believe, has been greatly welcomed by the community generally.

SPEECH.PARA: As regards the general issue of standards of service available on airlines, it is true that in recent times concern has been expressed in various places about this. It is hard to know whether that is a function of change in the use of various kinds of aircraft or due to the kinds of pressures to which Senator Gietzelt has referred. My impression is that the whole aviation industry is in a state of change as a result of the introducion in recent times of new aircraft. Naturally, we are all adjusting to new standards of service, not all of which can be claimed to represent movement in a downward direction. In fact, my experience generally is that there has been an improvement in the standard of service available to the travelling public. I do not consider that, as Senator Gietzelt would have us believe, it is a response to change brought about by cost pressures. Rather, it is a function of structural change in the industry.

Senator Gietzelt referred us to the problems of the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Indeed, I believe he suggested that there appeared to be no comprehensive policy on the part of this Government for the establishment, renewal, refurbishment or redevelopment of the various airports throughout Australia. Clearly, he has not had access to a news release issued by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) on 17 August, the night the Budget was presented . That release highlighted, in quite a comprehensive way, the various airport redevelopment projects that were under way. I refer, for instance, to the major works being undertaken, at a cost of some $270m, at Brisbane Airport. Also, a new international terminal complex is being constructed, at a total cost of $42m , at Perth Airport. A parallel taxiway is being constructed, at a total cost of $3m, at the same airport. Construction is well under way at the international terminal complex in Adelaide. The total cost is to be $11.2m with expenditure this year of some $10.7m. At Townsville Airport works for international services will be completed at a total cost of $4.5m. In addition, the expansion and improvement of the Townsville domestic terminal will cost $3.6m.

Further works are under way at the Adelaide Airport, at a total cost of $8.9m, for the introduction of the new wide-bodied aircraft. In Adelaide the total expenditure during this financial year is to be of the order of $20m. At Melbourne Airport $3.6m will be expended and in Perth $3.9m. At Coolangatta $1. 8m will be expended and in Hobart $3.5m. A number of other airports are being redeveloped and refurbished. I refer to work on operations buildings, the upgrading of runways and the construction of international airports. I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that this does not in any way demonstrate an ad hoc approach to the problems of airport development. Rather, it represents a comprehensive program, given the resources available to the Government for this purpose.

Senator Gietzelt referred in passing to problems at the Sydney Airport and sought to pin them all on the Federal Government. He ignored especially the negotiations that have taken place and the difficulties that have arisen over the relevant period. It is true that the Commonwealth Government acknowledges the problems at Sydney Airport and that there might be difficulties ahead as traffic density in the area worsens. It is estimated that the cost of delays, translated into airline operating expenditure and the value of travellers' lost time, is now of the order of $30m a year. The Commonwealth has been prepared since 1979 to proceed with measures to remedy that problem by the construction of a closed space parallel runway at Sydney Airport, but the State Government, the Neville Wran Labor Government of New South Wales, has refused to co-operate in that respect. The Commonwealth is also prepared to work in conjunction with the New South Wales State Government to identify a second airport site against a possible future need. I hope that the proposals for resolving that vexed question will be put before the Commonwealth in the not too distant future. Those are problems that Senator Gietzelt in his glib fashion has sought to attribute purely and simply to the Federal Government. They clearly involve other questions of a broader kind.

Senator Macklin gave us a sermon about the problems facing general aviation. As one who, over a long period, both since entering the Parliament and before, has been closely in touch with general aviation and acknowledges its worth to the community, I believe I can contribute some thoughts on very important aspects of it. First, it is significant to note one or two of the points that Senator Macklin made and compare them with what might be regarded as a rational approach . He first made out a rhetorical argument that general aviation ought to be supported in general terms without its contributing in any way to cost recovery. He argued that there were remote areas of Queensland-perhaps other remote areas as well--

TALK.START.PARA: —And New South Wales, he said.
—I do not believe he mentioned that.
—I mentioned New South Wales, also South Australia and Western Australia.

—I apologise. I felt that he emphasised the position in Queensland. My State of South Australia has remote areas, as have Western Australia and other States. They are very well served by general aviation. A consideration of the degree of cost revovery from various sectors of the industry might throw some light on the problem on which Senator Macklin has focused. According to the formula of allocation there is, for international airlines, 100 per cent cost recovery. From domestic trunk airlines 90 per cent of costs are recovered. For regional airlines the figure falls substantially, to 25 per cent of the estimate. The figure for general aviation is 15 per cent. Across the board the average is 53 per cent.
—That is not relevant.

—The trouble with the Australian Democrats is that nothing is ever relevant when one quotes the facts. They simply cannot acknowledge facts. They are strong on rhetoric but weak on facts. A very significant point is to be made here. General aviation as demonstrated by these figures, is shown to enjoy a significant subsidy paid by other sectors of the airline industry. Senator Collard clearly demonstrated that point in his brief contribution to the debate on this Bill. Let us take the issue a little further because clearly Senator Mason is not satisfied with that argument. Senator Macklin made a substantial issue of the fact that people using outback services were not actually using the airport facilities which might be available in larger towns. The fact is-perhaps Senator Macklin does not know this-that there is a remission of air navigation charges for airport usage in respect of airports not owned by local authorities or by government. In that respect clearly there is a further subsidy for the use of such airports to other sectors of the air passenger community.
—That is not unreasonable, is it?

—Of course it is not. That is demonstrated by Government policy. Clearly the Government has designed its policy to assist those in outback areas. In addition to that there is a 15 per cent remission in addition to the original 50 per cent remission for aircraft operating in the agricultural sphere. So a very significant contribution is made in favour of light aircraft using outback facilities and servicing agricultural areas.

SPEECH.PARA: A further argument can be advanced by showing that compared with last year there are some significant changes in the degree of increase or otherwise in charges for the various sectors. In 1981 there was a drop of 5 per cent in the rate of recovery from the international sector. That has now levelled out and no increase or decrease is applicable for this year. An increase of 12.5 per cent applied to domestic trunk airlines last year; the figure is 20 per cent this year. But in the area of regional airlines there has been a decrease compared with the previous year; the figure has gone from 25 per cent to 20 per cent. In the area of general aviation there has been a most significant lowering from 20 per cent to 12 per cent, in the rate of increase. Does this not demonstrate the clarity of the Government's policy in seeking to assist those who are in the greatest need-those in the remote areas, those who do need the services of general aviation in the way that Senator Macklin seeks to make out in his argument in not very specific terms.

The final point I want to make in response to the debate refers to the matter to which Senator Macklin alluded at the end of his remarks; the operations of military aircraft and military airports. In fact, military aircraft do use civil facilities free of charge but it is also true that civil aircraft use military airports free of charge. I will enumerate those examples. Clearly the Canberra Airport is a prime example, not only for regional and general aviation but also for domestic trunk routes. There is also Townsville, which is an outback centre, Williamtown and that outback centre to beat all outback centres, Darwin. Obviously there is a quid pro quo here, a trade-off between the two very large sectors of defence and civil aviation. I believe that that deals effectively with the points raised by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in this debate. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need some clarification from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Senator Messner). From his winding up remarks on the second reading, I understood him to class Townsville Airport as an outback airport. I have been through Townsville Airport on many occasions. It is an international airport which is on the seaboard of Queensland. Whilst I would have agreed with the Minister had he said that Queensland under the jurisdiction of Bjelke-Petersen could be classed as outback and not up with the times, I cannot agree with him that Townsville Airport is an outback airport. Perhaps he may not have meant to say that. As my colleague Senator Colston points out, Townsville is the second city in Queensland. No doubt many people in Queensland, particularly those who use Townsville Airport, will be most disturbed having heard the Minister tonight term Townsville Airport an outback airport.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister to clarify another matter. How much of these increased air navigation charges is embodied in the Government's payment of $442,000 to a corporate image company in respect of altering the logo of Trans Australia Airlines? Is the Government running so short of funds that it has to increase these airport charges to try to recoup some of that money? The Minister, as the Minister representing in the Senate the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt), has told me, in answer to a recent question of mine, that the Government has been prepared to pay a corporate image company a retainer of $15, 000 a month to change the logo of TAA. Is one of the reasons why the airport charges are being increased to try to recoup some of the $442,000?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to Senator McLaren for bringing to my attention my terminological inexactitude in regard to Townsvile Airport. I am glad to acknowledge also that Senator McLaren has had the opportunity of passing through that airport on many occasions, as have I. I regard Townsville as a very significant city in Queensland, and I apologise to those who may have misinterpreted my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: What I wanted to say was that Townsville is the centre of service for a vast outback area of Queensland and, indeed, the Northern Territory and parts of Western Australia. In that respect, it represents a very significant part of the servicing of that area. The point that I was seeking to make is that, the airport being a military airport, civil aircraft can use it free of charge and, as a result, there is great advantage to people in regional outback areas of Queensland. Consequently I am grateful to Senator McLaren for bringing that point to my attention so that I am able to clarify that for the people of Townsville and of areas of outback Queensland.

On the second point, naturally I do not have at my fingertips the information which Senator McLaren requires. I shall refer the matter to the Department, and I hope that I can bring back some information to him in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise another matter. It concerns the construction of the so-called international airport at West Beach in South Australia. I understand that it is to be opened some time in November to coincide with the forthcoming State election. Mr Tonkin is no doubt hoping that this will give a big boost to his prospects of re-election in South Australia. What I am concerned about is what effect these increased airport charges will have on international flights coming into West Beach Airport, what increase will be embodied in the international fares, whether, in effect, this could put a damper on the traffic through West Beach, and whether what the Federal Government is doing will have some hamstringing effect on Mr Tonkin trying to use the opening of the airport at West Beach to bolster his campaign to be, as he would hope, re-elected in the forthcoming election. Coinciding with that is the opening of the Hilton International Hotel in Adelaide. If these airport charges deter people from coming to Adelaide, this whole matter could blow up in Mr Tonkin's face.

SPEECH.PARA: Like Senator Messner who is in charge of the Bill, I am somewhat concerned about that, because I should have thought that nothing that the Fraser Government would do would be to the detriment of the Tonkin Government, in view of the fact that Mr Tonkin said in 1979 that he fully supported the Fraser Government's policies. Now he is trying to divorce himself from all those things . I hope that the Minister will give me some answer on that matter. I put it in a nutshell: Will these increased airport charges have any effect on traffic through this international airport which, as I have said, Mr Tonkin hopes will be opened on the eve of the announcement of the forthcoming State elections in South Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, it is clear that unfortunately Senator McLaren was not present during the second reading debate.
—I was listening in.

—Senator McLaren must have been distracted because he missed the point I made that there will be no increase this year in the rate at which international flights are to contribute to the cost of running airports. Naturally, there will be no effect as far as air navigation charges go on air fares for flights from Adelaide to overseas. Looking at it the other way round, Senator McLaren may have been suggesting that there were costs other than air navigation charges which may be affecting the cost of air fares for flights from Adelaide to other places. Naturally that is a question of commercial judgment on the part of the airlines that will be operating out of Adelaide. I can add nothing further to that. If Senator McLaren is interested, I will certainly make inquiries about the situation from Qantas Airways Ltd and get a reply for him as quickly as possible.

—I was interested to hear the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) say during his reply that the Federal Government is extremely proud of its developments in the general aviation area and in other aviation areas in this country. He mentioned, as did Senator McLaren, the developments at Adelaide and Townsville airports and so on. I wonder whether the Minister would be good enough to say when-I have brought up this question before-airports in South Australia which carry quite a considerable amount of traffic, such as the airport at Mount Gambier, will be upgraded. I understand that Senator McLaren travels through Townsville a lot. I have just come back from Tamworth where the facilities are extremely good, far outdoing anything that the people at Mount Gambier would even dream of and certainly far and away better than the Nissen hut from which the airlines are operating at the moment. I understand that Hamilton Airport, which services an area with a population somewhat similar to the population of Mount Gambier, also has far better facilities. I wonder whether the Minister is prepared to say whether any part of the increased charges brought in by this Bill are likely to be spent on upgrading what is the gateway to South Australia's south-eastern tourist area.

—I recall that in the debate on a similar Bill on a previous occasion-perhaps it was a year ago-our attention was drawn by honourable senators to problems at the airport at Mount Gambier. Certainly, as a tourist centre of South Australia of the quality and size that it represents, it is a most important airport facility .
—It is a quite revolting airport. It might be important but it is in an appalling state.

—I am sure that the people of Mount Gambier do not think it is revolting. But there are problems with the terminal building, whereas the airport itself is of a very high standard. It allows the landing of very significant aircraft in the area. As to the question Senator Haines raised during her remarks, it is a matter of concern to me as a senator for South Australia that this matter should be reviewed by the Government. I will draw her concerns to the attention of the Government and indicate her very real interest in a resolution of the problems at Mount Gambier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Mount Gambier has been raised, perhaps I ought also to put in a plea on behalf of the people there. I am the only senator in South Australia who is actually domiciled in the country. In fact, I have a regional office in Mount Gambier. I have much concern about it. Whilst the Australian Democrats may sometimes travel through Mount Gambier, I have an office and a staff member there. I am very concerned about the Mount Gambier Airport. I have taken up this matter on many occasions. In view of what Senator Haines has said tonight, I have now acquainted the Democrats with the fact that I have an office there to service the people. The Government member does not deem to live in his electorate of Barker and does not even deem to have an office there. He prefers to be domiciled in King William Street in Adelaide.
—Who is this?

—That is Mr Porter. It is left to the Australian Labor Party to service the country people, irrespective of what the Democrats may say. I too have a very vital interest in Mount Gambier. I hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), in seeking some information about the matters Senator Haines has raised, will take into consideration the fact that Mount Gambier Airport is a very important airport. Whilst the Government may say , as it has often done when I have raised the matter, that it is up to the local council to go into the local ownership scheme before it will expend any money on the airport, I think that with the money the Government will raise now through these increased airport charges it could well afford to expend some money on the airport at Mount Gambier, particularly in view of the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) often flies to that airport in a VIP aircraft and then gets a Commonwealth car or a charter aircraft to transport him from there to his property at Nareen.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very important airport not only to the people who live in the Mount Gambier area but also to the leader of the Government parties, the Prime Minister. I hope that this Government will give due consideration to finding more money to upgrade the terminal. I think the strip is all right. I have flown to Mount Gambier quite often, probably many more times than Senator Haines has ever gone there, having lived in the Portland area for many years before I migrated to South Australia. I am well versed with the problems that exist in the south-east of South Australia. I conclude by saying that I hope the Government will give due consideration to finding extra finances to upgrade the terminal at Mount Gambier.
