That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The intention behind the Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill 1982 is to amend the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1973 in accordance with the recommendations contained in the 1982 review of the Remuneration Tribunal, to amend the Ministers of State Act 1952 and the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973. The Opposition supports the general thrust of the Bill before the Senate. However, I give notice that at a later stage I will be moving several amendments on behalf of the Opposition. But first I should like to raise some matters arising from the Bill in relation to the Tribunal's consideration and consider some comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). Before I go on to consider these comments from the Government I should stress again-I want to make this very clear-that the Opposition supports the thrust of the Tribunal's recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: I pointed out that the Senate, in examining this Bill, has to take into consideration that movements in the salaries of parliamentarians have remained below the movements involved in the cost of living and below the movements in the rate of increase of average weekly earnings. The proposal inherent in the legislation is for a 7 per cent increase in the salaries of members of parliament to become operative on 1 October next in accordance with the Tribunal 's recommendation. This effectively means that the rate of increase is cut back over a 12-month period to about 5 per cent, and that cut back is to take place in a year in which it is expected that the cost of living will move by something like 11 per cent. That figure is the Government's own estimation in the Budget Papers. The Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill 1982 is clearly taking a step which puts the salaries of members of parliament and others affected by this legislation in a secondary position to that which applies to the rest of the Australian community.

The legislation also makes provision for adjustments in other allowances provided for members of parliament, in the salaries and allowances provided for senior public servants and for members of the judiciary. We in no way quibble with the proposals which are before the Senate. However, I think it ought to be pointed out that earlier this year, which was the last time I spoke to the Senate on the matter of the Remuneration Tribunal's proposals-I find this very much a matter of inconsistency on the part of this Government-we had before us proposals for a 14 per cent increase in the salary range of members of the Second Division of the Public Service. I would remind the Senate that when the Labor Government in 1973 brought in the Remuneration Tribunals Act, the purpose of that legislation was to take out of the area of public disputation the question of salaries and allowances for members of parliament, the judiciary and other senior public servants. It used as its yardstick at that time the suggestion that salaries of members of parliament should be related to the Second Division of the Public Service.

When we dealt with this matter earlier this year, there was not a word from the Commonwealth Government, from Mr Fraser or Mr Howard or Mr Newman, that is the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Administrative Services, about that substantial increase in salaries which in fact had the effect of putting Second Division officers of the Public Service on a salary range of approximately $43,000 and therefore it showed up the comparative difference which had grown up over the years between those who had received the same salary in 1973, that is, Second Division officers, and members of the national Parliament. There were some 2,000-odd members of the Second Division of the Public Service-I think we ought to just pause and reflect on that-who received a 14 per cent increase without any interference from the Fraser Administration. But when it came to dealing with the salaries of something less than 190 members of the national parliament there was all the fanfare and hypocrisy which is so much a part of the posturing of the Fraser-Howard Administration. I think that is why we find in the determination of the Remuneration Tribunal some expression of concern at the attitude which was taken by those three members of the Fraser Administration.

The Government has approached the Tribunal in a way that has never been tried before. It has used the hearings of the Tribunal as a way to gain publicity for its own discredited and disorganised wages, salaries and economic policies. I think Mr Hayden dealt with that point very adequately in the House of Representatives when this matter was being debated. The Government effectively made three very public submissions to the Tribunal, one in writing by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman; one in writing by the Prime Minister and one verbal submission by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, who now, of course, is the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party and someone whose whole administration of taxation is seriously in question by the Parliament.

These circumstances were, to say the least, as the report of the Tribunal remarks-I use its word-unusual. In other words, the Tribunal found the intervention by these three senior members an unusual event. All of the Government's submissions had the intention or the strategy of gaining publicity for a government's commitment to what it terms maximum wage restraint-I emphasise that-but it said not one single word of criticism about the increase of 14 per cent for Second Division officers early this year. Of course these submissions were made by members of a government, the great majority of whom not only receive large salaries as Ministers of State and members of parliament but also, in a great majority of cases, are in receipt of extra income from outside the Parliament in the form of income from their grazing properties or from the businesses and other activities with which they were associated prior to their becoming members of parliament. We find the attitude taken by these three senior members of the Government hypocritical and unacceptable to the degree that it attempts to suggest double standards in respect of a small handful of people. It attempts to suggest that this salary increase for parliamentarians will have some melodramatic impact upon the whole question of wages and salaries in Australia. The Government has not been concerned with the real economic effect of its submission. It has been conceived from the point of view of how it will look to the public. In the Tribunal's words:
The submissions are concerned essentially with the appearance rather than the substance of our determinations and recommendations.

Those are the words of the Tribunal. In other words, the Government wants to be seen to be doing something positive for the economy when in fact it is not doing that because the sort of money that is being saved is quite small compared with its attitude in respect of other persons covered by the Remuneration Tribunal. Let us look at the whole question of wage restraint. The Tribunal in its report- again I am being very careful to quote precisely what it said-stated:

The Rt. Hon. the Prime Minister wrote personally to the Tribunal stating the view of his Government that it is necessary to achieve a moderation of the rate of wage and salary increases in the community in order to avoid an immediate rise in unemployment, to reduce inflationary pressures, and to avoid further damage to our international competitiveness. He stated the Government's view that the decision taken by this Tribunal would significantly affect such matters .

Does the Government really believe that by a gesture of reducing the amount that normally would be made available from 14 per cent to 7 per cent, applicable from 1 October, meaning an effective increase of 5 per cent, it will help with unemployment, reduce inflationary pressures and avoid any further damage to our international competitiveness? The Government not only is pulling the wool over the eyes of members of parliament but also is trying to do so with the Australian community. Later, when this view was accepted, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer welcomed the decision of the Tribunal. Again, to use the Prime Minister's expression, this proposal represented a clear example of restraint. There are several problems with this thesis. Firstly, the agreement of members of parliament to take the 7 per cent pay rise means that they will get an increase of nearly $50 a week. That will not provide any incentive and in no way will assist that 60 per cent of the Australian work force-the wage and salary earners-where wages are average weekly earnings. The wage and salary earners will see that what we do is completely irrelevant to the economic difficulties that they are facing as a result of the economic policies which are being pursued by this Government. Secondly, as the Tribunal has pointed out, so-called wage restraint by members of parliament will have no economic effect. In its report the Tribunal stated:
In money terms, the change in the remuneration of offices within our jurisdiction is not of relevant significance to the national economy.
The possibility of our review being treated as a precedent for other decisions could, were such matters dealt with merely on a logical basis, be excluded.

Thirdly, the Government has sought to suggest, falsely in my view, that wage increases represent the main cause of Australia's economic problems today. In effect the Government is seeking to apportion blame to one section of the community-the wage and salary earners-for the very complex and difficult economic problems that we face. The Government seeks to blame that sector of society which has the least power, influence and income. But it never questions its own approach, the approach of employers or its own failure to arrest the problems of inflation, unemployment and the general decline in the economy.

The Government has no effective or consistent wages policy. It allows real wages to be continually eroded by inflation, increasing prices, health insurance charges, State charges as a result of the Government's Budget policies, interest rate hikes, tax increases and, as we well know from the events that have occurred in the last several weeks, amazing and extensive tax rorts. The Government ignores all of these problems, it concentrates only on wage and salary earners who have no opportunity but to seek redress by way of wage and salary increases through the effectiveness of their trade unions and the industrial tribunals in State and Federal jurisdictions. The Government has a policy of ad hockery and disorganisation only. It rejects any approach which may confront the real and widespread problems of the economy such as unemployment, inflation, a stagnating manufacturing industry and reduced levels of investment. None of these matters will be in any way affected by this hypocritical action taken by the intervention of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Administrative Services.

The Government has rejected out of hand the suggestions of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in recent days that an employment fund be created out of contributions from wage and salary earners, industry and the wealthy. In return the ACTU has offered to support a process of orderly and equitable wage fixation but the Government, off the cuff, through the Prime Minister and the Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Brown, has rejected this considered, reasoned and restrained approach. Alternatively it has suggested that by 190 members of the Parliament being treated in this way the problem is largely resolved. What an absurd suggestion from a government that has turned its back on the degree of taxation scandals that have been allowed to continue by the Australian Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department over the last seven or eight years.

This Government is the same Government that piece by piece took apart the basis of the wage indexation system which was set up by the Whitlam Labor Government. It has destroyed the Tribunal's work over the years to maintain the sort of parity which was accepted at that time to be a fair and equitable way in which these matters would be dealt with by the national Parliament. The Opposition takes the view that a wages policy must be seen and dealt with in the same broad context of economic policy. An orderly, regular and equitable system of wage fixation is needed. Such a system is a key element of a planned economic and social policy based on a process of co-operation between unions, employers and Government. Such an approach is embodied in the Australian Labor Party-ACTU prices and incomes agreement. This represents a much more genuine attempt to deal with the problems facing this country than the sort of hypocritical gesturing and posturing by the Fraser Administration. We would welcome a positive and creative contribution from the trade union movement to an economic and wages policy of the kind made by the ACTU in its proposal in recent days. The Government can only rest on publicity oriented statements such as those it has made in relation to the report of the Remuneration Tribunal. Whilst we accept the thrust we point to the utter hypocrisy of this Government in the way in which it has dealt with the tribunal and its findings.

I wish to refer to the amendments which we propose to move. The first amendment seeks to amend clause 6 of the Bill to delete the section providing an allowance for all justices of the High Court of Australia who maintain their principal home outside Canberra. I remind the Senate, and particularly my colleagues who I hope are allies on this matter-the Australian Democrats-that the Parliament in its wisdom, correctly said that justices of the High Court should, on appointment, reside in Canberra. Why did the Parliament make that judgment? Because it believed it was essential for judges of the High Court not only to be domiciled in Canberra but also to begin to take on a national outlook, to come out of the cloister or the parochial areas in which they had previously worked- whether that be in the Public Service, the private sector or some other jurisdiction. The Parliament believed that they should come out of those environments, live in Canberra and look at matters from a national point of view . I would have thought that the Australian Democrats would consider these matter to be national issues-as indeed the Australian Labor Party does-and not State issues. I would have thought the Australian Democrats would look at these issues not from a narrow parochial point of view but from the point of view of national politics. The judges of the High Court hitherto have been regarded by other people's definitions-not my own-as State righters, as people who were expected to take a point of view that was related to the State point of view as distinct from the national point of view. We have seen a transformation of the High Court . As a result of the Government's guidelines the High Court has taken on a national characteristic-a national view. I think that was a correct position to take. The consequence of that is a strenghening of the national viewpoint over a whole ambit of legislation and interpretation of law. The Government decided that as from 1 July 1980 an allowance would be paid only to those who had been appointed prior to that date. So the Government's intention was that people appointed to the High Court of Australia should come on the understanding that they will be domiciled in the national capital. The Australian Labor Party supports that concept.

I believe everything that the High Court has done in recent times has justified that unanimous view of the national Parliament, one which the Opposition and the government of the day supported. However, when I look at the submissions which were made by various organisations, public servants, private citizens, judges and so on, to the Remuneration Tribunal, I realise that there was obviously a submission of some sort made by the Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs. I do not know whether he made the suggestions that are now embraced in this Bill. Two recent appointments have been made-Mr Justice Deane and Mr Justice Dawson.

The Government's intention with the passing of this Bill is not only to increase the interstate allowance but also to encourage the justices to live in the States in which they were previously domiciled. So rather than coming here and strengthening what I believe to be a very desirable philosophy and outlook, we will now have four judges of the High Court receiving this allowance and living elsewhere. It is not a great sum of money but I believe a principle is involved here-the need for the judges to carry out what was the express wish of the Government. We find the Government accepting this; in other words, going through the back door to undo the legislation which previously existed. We should automatically have a judge with a national perspective not only residing here but I would suggest also socialising here and therefore looking at things not from the narrow point of view of Sydney, Melbourne, Perth, Adelaide, Darwin or Hobart but from the point of view of how they affect Australia as a nation. That is the way in which the High Court should operate.

I believe in the devolution of power. I am not a centralist just for the sake of it; neither is the Labor Party. We support the principle of the devolution of power but we believe with respect to Australia as a nation certain fundamentals ought to exist. Yet on looking at the Government's proposals, which adopt the recommendations of the Tribunal, there is no evidence to suggest other than there must have been a submission made by Sir Harry Gibbs, or some private arrangement made with the justices concerned. If that was the case the Parliament should have been told and the Government should not have gone about it through the back door, as is suggested in the clause that I have referred to. I do not think the Senate should undermine the basis I have referred to or the truly national outlook which is now a feature of our High Court. This should put an end to all these tax avoidance and evasion schemes which were so much a feature of the way in which the High Court previously operated.

The Labor Party has a number of other amendments which seek to transfer to the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly the power of disallowance in respect of decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal relating to that body. In other words, we are saying that as the Remuneration Tribunal has recommended-and the Government has accepted-that the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly shall have the power to disallow any of its salaries or allowances, we suggest that, again concerning the question of devolution of power, the same principles should apply to the Australian Capital Territory Assembly and that there ought to be a uniform approach; in other words, if it is good enough for Norfolk Island, surely the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly in the national capital should similarly have that right. So, in the Committee stage we will be moving an amendment to achieve exactly the same purpose in respect of the Australian Capital Territory. I think it is appropriate that the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly should accept responsibility for deciding whether it will accept the determination of the Tribunal in exactly the same way as the Parliament accepts responsibility for its own conditions, salaries and allowances. In that context we will be moving a series of amendments which have been circulated. It would appear as though there were a great number of amendments in the two pages which have been circulated. In fact we are dealing with only two substantive matters; the first relates to the allowance of $9,125, which is to be paid to the judges who wish to remain in their States of domicile ; and the second seeks to apply to the Australian Capital Territory Assembly the same principles involved in the Norfolk Island Assembly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill 1982 is, in my view, a very important Bill which implements a responsible report by the Remuneration Tribunal. It is very important at this time that we should have wage restraint because if we are to recover from our present slump and reduce unemployment we must reduce the rate of increase in real wages. Last year average weekly earnings increased by 17 per cent, yet the real productivity increase was only 1.2 per cent. We just cannot go on like that. We are trading with the rest of the world at an annual deficit of about $9,000m. Interest rates have to be kept high so that we can balance the books with capital inflow. Jobs are being destroyed daily. The trite old saying 'one man's pay rise costs another man his job' is only too true today. These points were put to the Remuneration Tribunal and I am delighted that it accepted them. The Remuneration Tribunal states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer put forcibly to the Tribunal--
I do not think it means forcibly, but forcefully--

the Government's view that there is now a direct relationship between the level of wage and salary increases and the growth of unemployment and that the decisions of this Tribunal will have a significant influence on such matters.
It went on to state:
. . . we believe we should give effect to the main thrust of the submissions which have been made to us.
That it does basically with a recommended increase of about 7 per cent in salaries. I am delighted by that, but what worries me is what the Tribunal states elsewhere in the report. It continues:
. . . later in the present year, we shall keep under review the salaries within our jurisdiction.

That worries me because I think if we are to have any influence-I will come later to the point Senator Gietzelt was raising about whether what we are doing will have any impact-and if we believe that by restraining salaries in these areas we will make an impact on the growth of real wages in Australia, we must be seen to be sincere. If we give the impression that later in the year we will have another look at salaries and put them up again that will destroy any possible impact such restraint will have. I believe we must make it quite clear that this is our lot for this year. This is all we are going to get and all we are going to ask for. There must be no question of a further increase later in the year. I am writing to the Remuneration Tribunal on those lines. I think it is vital that this Parliament sets an example. We must make quite clear that this is the lot for this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Tribunal can still reopen the matter if it so wishes.

—The Tribunal may reopen the matter. I am urging it should not do so. The Tribunal is an independent body and it may reopen the matter. I am trying to make it quite clear that in my opinion and, I hope, in the opinion of the majority of members of parliament that should not happen. We should be satisfied with what we have got. I will come in a moment to the question of what happens if the example is not taken up. Both Senator Gietzelt and the Tribunal made the point that the restraint in this limited range of parliamentary salaries, First Division officers and judges on their own will not have much impact. Certainly it is a small example. However, it cannot really affect the wage structure of this country. What we must do is to see that this restraint extends to all Commonwealth employees. The Commonwealth Government now has 478, 000 people on its payroll. It is quite absurd for the Government to be preaching wage restraint to private employers while at the same time granting generous pay increases for its own employees.

SPEECH.PARA: The groups which come on the Commonwealth's payroll fall into four categories. The first group includes people with whom we are dealing in this Bill tonight- members of parliament, judges, first division officers and so on. I do not want to deal with this group in respect of which restraint has been shown. The second group is made up of the remaining public servants whose salaries are set by government regulation. I think the Government must make it quite clear that it would limit pay increases to them to not more than 7 per cent in 1982-83. The third category consists of other Commonwealth Government employees such as the employees of Telecom Australia and Australia Post whose pay is determined by their management but with access to the conciliation and arbitration system. However, their pay levels are subject to ministerial disallowance. The responsible Minister should not approve any wage increases of more than 7 per cent in 1982-83. Finally, the fourth category is made up of members of the Defence Force whose pay levels are set by the Government and they too should have to show the same restraint. Of course, if this goes on and the example is not taken, we cannot possibly disadvantage all Commonwealth Government employees and in subsequent years there will have to be a catch up for what has been forgone if the example is not taken.

I believe that at this stage it is vital that we should set the example, and set it throughout the whole range of Commonwealth Government employees. This Government has a chance to give a clear lead in this crucial area of wage policy . We have to make it clear that wage restraint is in the interests of the whole community. The Australian Council of Trade Unions recently, for the first time in public as far as I am aware, recognised that wage restraint is very important to the unemployed. The Whitlam Government deliberately used the Commonwealth Public Service as a pacesetter in wages and conditions. The result was the 1974 wage explosion. We should use the Commonwealth Public Service and all people on the Commonwealth payroll as pacesetters in wage restraint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support for the Bill. Despite all of the criticisms that Senator Gietzelt expressed on behalf of the Opposition, he indicated nevertheless that the Opposition would support the Bill even though he intended to move amendments during the Committee stage. I thank my colleague Senator Hamer for his observations. We have support for this piece of legislation from all sides of the Parliament and for that the Government is grateful. I welcome the contents of this Bill. I welcome the restraint on the part of the Parliament which is embodied in the provisions of this Bill. I welcome restraint by the Parliament on the question of its own salaries and emoluments. I particularly welcome restraint by the Parliament at a time when the Parliament and the Government are seeking restraint more widely in the community. My colleague Senator Hamer expanded on this matter during his remarks .

SPEECH.PARA: It is proper that we should seek this restraint. It is proper that we should do so with Australia in the economic situation it is today, with the prospects being difficult as they are around the world. Senator Gietzelt has chosen to belittle the value of some of the calls for restraint or to belittle the value of the approach which the Government has taken. Senator Gietzelt does not believe that it can be effective. The Government has a different view. The Government believes that there is an effect from the representations which we have made to the Remuneration Tribunal, from the response by the Tribunal to those representations, by the efforts of people like Mr Howard before the Tribunal. May I say that Senator Gietzelt chose to belittle some of the people who went before the Tribunal on the basis that they had other sources of income. Mr Howard, of course, as Treasurer depends upon the income he receives from the Parliament as do many of the rest of us. It is not fair to impute to people like that motives which really are not proper. Mr Howard went before that Tribunal to put a view on behalf of the Government, a view which we hold quite firmly. We believe that our representations and the determination which was made have had and will continue to have a useful demonstration effect.

In the portfolio which I administer we have recently had a report from the Academic Salaries Tribunal. The Government has yet to respond to that report. But it is interesting to note that the Academic Salaries Tribunal has elected to make an award which has in itself demonstrated a conscious recognition that restraint is appropriate at this time. I would hope that that example of the Academic Salaries Tribunal will be copied in other places. We have seen large corporations in this country asking their senior executives to take little or no pay rises at this time. This is another flow-on from the demonstration effect of what is being done here in the Parliament on behalf of the nation. We in fact may never agree on the merits or otherwise of the approach that has been taken. But I put it to the Senate that the approach by the Government on that is motivated by a desire to help Australia and that our approach to the Tribunal recommending that we should receive less is made on the basis that the nation will be better for those efforts.

Senator Gietzelt was good enough during his speech to outline what he wants to include in his amendments. It might be appropriate if I responded to the two sets of proposed amendments now even though they will be moved at the Committee stage. If I deal with them now, it may be easier for us when we come to the Committee stage. First of all there is the question in relation to the allowance for judges of the High Court. Part II of the Bill implements the recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to the salaries and allowances of the judiciary. Of course, Senator Gietzelt proposes to move an amendment to clause 6 of the Bill which seeks to change the basis of eligibility for the Canberra allowance payable to justices of the High Court of Australia. The Act as it stands provides for the annual allowances to be payable to a judge who held office on 1 July 1980 and who has continued to have his sole or principal place of residence outside Canberra.

The Government has had this matter before it for a couple of years. I think Senator Gietzelt will acknowledge that in the 1981 report of the Remuneraton Tribunal a recommendation was made that a change should be made. The Government at that time chose not to proceed. In 1982, again the Remuneration Tribunal has recommended that the limitation for this allowance to justices appointed before 1 July 1980 should be removed. Once again, the Government examined the recommendation and reassessed it. We have looked at the matter again in the light of the Tribunal's repeated views and in the light of a number of representations which we have received. State governments, particularly those in some of the less populous States, have put a view that there can be some advantage to justices continuing to have a place of residence in such a State. There is a view that having a justice of the High Court with a place of residence in one of the less populous States is not without its merit. I am not going to go through the merits or otherwise of that. What I am aware of is that the Remuneration Tribunal on two occasions now has recommended that the limitation should be removed. We have had a number of representations from the States and various other people and we have in fact taken these into account. The representations have come not only from the States but also from the Law Council of Australia, from bodies representing the legal profession and from individual legal practitioners. In the light of these representations the Government now believes that it is appropriate to adopt the recommendation. It is one of those issues which we took some time to determine. We considered it- not hastily but over a couple of years-and on balance we now think it is appropriate to adopt the recommendation. We have included in the Bill a proposal which will allow us to adopt the recommendation. The proposal of Senator Gietzelt is not to adopt the recommendation. The Senate will make its choice. But I indicate that the Government will not accept the amendment which is proposed. The Government wishes to proceed to adopt the recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal and I hope that the Senate will see its way clear to support the Government on this matter.

The other group of amendments relates to whether a power of disallowance should rest with the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly rather than with this Parliament in matters relating to the House of Assembly. The analogy suggested between Norfolk Island and the House of Assembly is not an exact analogy. Honourable senators may wish to consider several facts. They may wish to consider that the people of the Australian Capital Territory, by way of a referendum, rejected self-government. The Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly is a body with advisory power only. The Norfolk Island Assembly is a body which has its own legislative powers. The parallel does not follow.

We think that the power proposed by Senator Gietzelt would be inappropriate and inapt. The Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly is merely an advisory body and has no legislative power other than to determine its standing orders. The provision which is proposed would in fact extend the power of the House of Assembly in a major way and almost, as it were, just as a throw away gesture. The amendment, if passed in the Senate, would raise questions relating to future governance of the Australian Capitral Territory. I mention for the guidance of the Senate that the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has on many occasions stated his belief that no developments will be made on the constitutional issue until he has received the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission's inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory's finances. That inquiry is under way. When the results of it come to hand the Minister for the Capital Territory will have to take into account a whole range of questions which go to the governance of the Australian Capital Territory. We believe that it would be inappropriate to accord to the House of Assembly any legislative power in advance of the Government's consideration of the Grants Commission's report. I remind honourable senators that there are regular occasions on which the amendments proposed by Senator Gietzelt could be considered again. Once we have the report from the Grants Commission and once it has been considered, it may be more appropriate to look at this proposed extension of the powers of the Australian Capital Territory.

We have an indication that there is support for the legislation and I thank honourable senators for that. It is not the Government's intention to accept any of the amendments proposed. We will oppose them in the Committee stage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators have before them the amendments which the Opposition proposes to move in the Committee stage. The Opposition seeks the deletion of paragraphs (a) and (b) of clause 6. Consequently what would remain would be the reference that the additional allowances paid to certain justices of the High Court of Australia be $9,125. In the second reading debate the Government made its position clear, but it has ignored what I believe to be a fairly fundamental principle. First of all, the Opposition does not in any way suggest that the appointments to the High Court should be criticised. We are happy with the appointments. In fact it would certainly be my judgment that the Government has made some very good appointments to the High Court. However, without getting involved in any way in the question of personalities, circumstances do exist in which persons operating in a State sphere and giving advice to a State are on occasions appointed to the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: As we know, a great deal of the legislation dealt with by the High Court relates to differences between a State view and the Commonwealth view. Often circumstances arise in which persons involved in the jurisdiction of a State suddenly find themselves elevated to a position on the High Court. In other words, the environment changes dramatically but their experience and previous professional involvement have been in a different jurisdiction. It seems to us to be logical for persons elevated to the highest judicial position in the land to be in a position in every way, shape and form to look at questions of law interpretation-whether they be matters of difference between State and Federal jurisdiction or between individuals and institutions or governments-from a different viewpoint from that which they previously held. As far as practicable they should be encouraged in their new environment to have a national outlook and to look at things from the point of view of how they might affect the whole nation and not how they might affect a particular State.

I do not resile from the fact that States have a point of view to which they are entitled. But on many occasions members of a State parliament have come into the national parliament and had their views changed as a result of their experiences in debates that take place within the national Parliament. They get a wider view; their experience is broadened, their outlook is broadened and they start to look at things from a national viewpoint-from an Australian viewpoint, and not from the more restricted viewpoint which was understandable in the jurisdiction in which they previously worked. A great deal can be said for judges-this was the view that the Government took and that the Opposition supported-of the High Court to be domiciled in Canberra; to live and absorb the atmosphere of national issues, national politics and national affairs, and to socialise in an atmosphere in which they will appreciate the changed environment and the change in emphasis that is now their principal area of responsibility.

There is every reason for the Opposition to take the viewpoint that it is a negative position to have judges who have spent three or four days in Canberra returning to the environment in which they previously practised, whether is was in the private sector or in the public sector, and looking at issues from the point of view of their previous experience and not that of their new area of responsibility. No evidence has been presented-Senator Baume did not present any evidence-to show that there are any advantages. The Remuneration Tribunal produced none-not that it was obliged to. It was merely obliged to make recommendations in respect of the evidence before it. No one that I am aware of has been able to say that what is proposed will give us judges of a higher quality; that their judgements will be better if they commute back and forth, to and from, their respective States. I understand that of the last two appointees one was from Victoria and the other from South Australia. Senator Baume referred to the smaller States.

I do not believe that it would be in the community's interest for the judges to spend seven or eight hours of a given day travelling between Perth and Canberra, for instance. Their task is to sit in judgment on matters before the High Court in the national capital. We have built a High Court building. We have taken High Court judges away from their respective States, although I understand that some cases are still heard in the various capital cities. But, overall, the objective in building the High Court in Canberra-I believe the building to be a monstrosity-was to enable the Court to operate here, to feel the Canberra atmosphere, to obtain the national, the Australian viewpoint. Consequently, I move:
(1) Page 2, clause 6, paragraphs (a) and (b), leave out the paragraphs.

This would delete the provision which states that judges may have the option of residing at their previous place of domicile. They would then be required, to justify receiving the allowance, to live in the Canberra district.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to Senator Gietzelt's suggestion that reasons might be offered for the position that the Government is taking. The present position merely draws a distinction between two groups of High Court judges-those who were appointed before a certain date and those who were appointed after a certain date. At present different standards of treatment apply to each. Under the portfolio that I administer the Department not infrequently must look for people to accept positions of national importance, which may involve their moving to the national capital. For the people whom I have approached a quite major family disruption is involved. I suggest that we draw a distinction between that person and the rest of his or her family. In many cases there are family roots and obligations which would keep the rest of the family where they are. If that is not easily possible we sometimes find-I have spoken to some of them-that they decline to take the post. Often, for very good reasons, they are not willing to move their family in toto to Canberra. We require, of course, the very highest calibre of person for the positions of justice of the High Court. I am ad idem with Senator Gietzelt on the points he made about the need for judges of high quality. The Parliament should take actions which will make it possible for people of the very first rank to feel able to accept appointment to the High Court. This is essential to maintenance of the best state of health of the polity and the nation as a whole. I refer Senator Gietzelt to paragraphs 28 and 29 of the 1981 report of the Remuneration Tribunal, which set out its reasons for proposing the course that the Government is now taking. They include the following:

SPEECH.PARA: If justices appointed in the future will not receive the allowance, persons who ought to be appointed to the Court may be deterred from accepting the appointment. A newly appointed justice will, in many cases, be compelled for financial reasons to move his home to Canberra. In some cases a person asked to accept appointment to the Court might be prepared to move his residence to Canberra and might even wish to do so. In other cases, family or other commitments, or simply personal choice, might lead a person who clearly ought to be appointed to the Court to refuse to accept the position if that entailed the moving of his home to Canberra.

I might add that some years ago, when my mother and father sold their home, the purchaser was, and still is, a justice of the High Court to whom we are still exceedingly grateful, and he obtained a very good home. In paragraph 29 of the report the Tribunal went on to say that there were considerable advantages to the community if some members of the Court continued to live outside Canberra, and it set out the reasons. That is the Tribunal's view. Senator Gietzelt has put the alternative view. The Government took some time to make up its mind. We believe that, on balance, the course we are now taking is a proper one. I understand that there will be differences of opinion but the Government does not accept the amendments that have been proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be able to understand more clearly the explanation given by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume). As I understand it, the Minister is saying that if a judge moves to Canberra, or has done so in the past, he is to receive a certain allowance.
—If he retains his home elsewhere. The essential thing is that his home be outside Canberra.

—Yes, but if a judge comes to Canberra in the performance of his duties he attracts a certain allowance. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw Senator Button's attention to clause 6 (b) of the Bill, which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: '(b) whose sole or principal place of residence was at the time when his appointment, or his first appointment, as the case may be, to any such judicial office took effect, and has at all subsequent times been, at a place outside, but not in a part of New South Wales that is adjacent to or in the vicinity of, the Australian Capital Territory' . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, prior to the 1980 determination two judges, Justices Mason and Wilson, qualified for the allowance because they wished to remain at their original place of domicile. So the Government said: 'Well, from here on in no further allowances will be paid because judges will be required to live in Canberra'. SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said that we ought to have a yardstick, a standard, which is to apply to judges of the High Court. As I understand it, that is not the view that the Government has taken with respect to the senior members of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. According to a Press report recently, when the whole Department was to be moved from Melbourne to Canberra, some two-thirds of the senior staff elected not to live here. We have here a double standard. The Government says to some people whose careers are affected: 'Your position requires you to come to Canberra; you are required to leave your families and environment and all the other attributes and attractions that kept you in Melbourne'. Two-thirds of the staff have elected not to do that. In respect of the High Court, the Government is setting a different standard by saying that the judges can take any option they like; they can decide to live wherever they like as long as it is not in a particular area of New South Wales or in the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Adjacent to the Territory.

—Yes, I presume not Queanbeyan or anywhere like that. For instance, Senator Hamer would not qualify for the allowance seeing that he lives just outside the boundary. So there are different standards for people who serve in responsible positions.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Senator Gietzelt's amendment) be omitted .

I indicated in the second reading debate that I would move the amendments now circulated to all honourable senators. They are all consequential on taking certain steps to apply to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly the same principles that apply to the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly; that is to say, the legislation provides for a new principle and that is that the Norfolk Island Assembly shall have the right to accept, amend or otherwise the matters affecting salaries and allowances of members of the Assembly. The Opposition has no quarrel with that because we believe that that is delegating to the appropriate authority the responsibility of making the decision in respect of members' own salaries and allowances. However, for the life of us we cannot understand why the Government has two different standards. I appreciate what the Minister for Education, Senator Baume, has said-that Norfolk Island has certain obligations and responsibilities in its own right and that there is a limitation on the way in which the Australian Capital Territory Assembly operates. Nevertheless, the principle is the same. The Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly is only one step short of being a self-governing organisation. I think that everyone appreciates that in due course it will reach the stage of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. I suppose that the people took a conservative view. They did not agree in the referendum to assume their full responsibilities in the area of self-government. But I do not see that that necessarily is an argument why the Assembly should not have the right to make a decision in respect of these matters. It would be only an advisory decision, because the decision would finally rest with the Government accepting or rejecting that decision. Decisions of the Assembly are subject to ratification by the appropriate Government authorities in the national Parliament.

However, as we support the principle of devolution of power, we believe that it would be an act of responsibility to give the Assembly the right to have a say in respect of the allowances paid to its members. That is the purpose of the amendment. This was a matter raised in our party room as a reasonable approach. We saw no reason as a party not to support the concept. We believe that it is a step in the direction of finally convincing the residents of the Australian Capital Territory that they should accept total responsibility as a self- management organisation. If the national Parliament gives them added responsibilities and delegates them certain powers as proposed in our amendments , we shall be taking the essential step which in the long run, and perhaps in the short run, will have the effect of their agreeing finally to taking the same position as the Northern Territory, Norfolk Island and the other territories previously under our control and management. The purpose of the amendments is to achieve exactly the same obligations and responsibilities for the Australian Capital Territory as apply in respect of Norfolk Island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I set out some of the arguments earlier. There is a fair amount of common ground between the Government and the Opposition on this matter. The difference may be one of the appropriate timing. I indicated earlier to Senator Gietzelt that the Australian Captial Territory at a referendum had rejected self-government. The honourable senator referred to that. But there is at present work under way which bears upon the governance of the Australian Capital Territory and looks at the correct way of managing its finances. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) has indicated that he will be looking at the results and will be working from that on questions of constitutional development. There will be a stage at which we shall then be on quite common ground, I think, in seeking to advance that constitutional development and to pass down the decision making power. It is our contention that while the investigations are under way through the Grants Commission it is not an appropriate time to pass this extra power across to the House of Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory. I indicated earlier why we think it is not appropriate at this stage. I appreciate the points made by Senator Gietzelt. I think that the difference between us is one of when these things should be done. We would like to see the present investigations and the present work completed and then look at the question again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to enter into this debate but I was provoked to do so because of some of the remarks made by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) in his reply to the second reading. People listening to this debate would have thought that this is the only government which has taken any action to implement restraint in salaries paid to members of parliament and Ministers. Despite the fact that my colleague Senator Gietzelt pointed out that the Whitlam Labor Government had refused any increase at all, Senator Baume saw fit to overlook that fact in his winding up speech, and that is of some concern to me. We must give credit to the Whitlam Government, which decided that we would not accept any increase. Later Senator Baume said that the Government had agreed to the recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal in this instance. But it should also be remembered that the Government did not agree to the recommendations of the Tribunal some 12 months ago. The Government decided that it would alter the Tribunal's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other thing I want to say to those who may be interested in this debate is that there are many misguided people in the electorate who are of the belief that members of parliament do not pay income tax on their salaries. Those people ought to be reminded that we, like every other wage earner, pay income tax. That is something which ought to be brought out for the enlightenment of some people, because members of parliament are continually criticised as being people who are paid far too much for the work that they do. In my experience, back benchers are not paid too much. Ministers who have a double income may be overpaid. We know that most Cabinet Ministers in the present Government have other sources of income. In the Opposition, the only people who get extra income are the Leader of the Opposition, and the Deputy Leader. Those on the front bench have all the extra work load of shadowing Ministers but get no extra pay over and above what a back bencher gets. People who criticise members of parliament ought to be made aware of that fact.

upon which Senator Walsh had moved by way of amendment:
