SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that, when this debate was last in progress approximately a fortnight ago, I had been referring particularly to three reasons that the Australian Democrats had put to the Senate why they would support the amendment moved by the Australian Labor Party to the effect that the Bill should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. The reason why I was concentrating on the Democrats' reasons was that, as we know, they approach these matters with an open mind. If they can be convinced that their concerns are not well founded, presumably they will be prepared on this occasion to change their minds and support the legislation which would thus be to the benefit of the agricultural community of Australia as a whole. In particular the reasons that they put to the Senate on that last occasion were that, firstly, they were concerned about the minor inaccuracies in an information kit that had been provided by the Government to assist members of parliament.
—Minor inaccuracies?

—'Minor inaccuracies' was the terminology used. As I indicated on the last occasion, I am sure that such minor inaccuracies will be clarified by the responsible Minister later in the debate. The second reason that the Democrats put to the Senate was that they were concerned that this Bill would in some way inhibit fundamental research in institutions of higher learning. As I pointed out, there is no reason at all why that should follow, this Bill being designed, in fact, to induce further funding for the benefit of plant variety rights. This time the funding is to come from the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The third reason why the Democrats were concerned that the Bill should not be passed was that the Government was unable to make accurate projections on the economic consequences of the Bill. As I indicated on that occasion, that is an impossibility. I suggested that a better course of action would be to look at the overseas experience. If one does that and looks at the 25 countries that have legislation of this kind, one will find that the legislation has been beneficial in improving varieties, yield and such aspects as disease resistibility.

I indicated on the last occasion that there were two principal purposes for which the Bill was introduced. The first, which I touched upon a moment ago, was to generate private investment in the seed breeding industry. I had looked, in fact, at the United Kingdom. Since the introduction of the legislation in that country so many more plant breeders were producing that there was a decided widening of seed varieties and there were increased yields. The second purpose upon which I had touched was the lack of access from an Australian point of view to certain protected overseas seed varieties due to the absence of similar plant variety legislation as that which exists overseas. I was in the process of listing a number of plant varieties to which Australian breeders do not have access because of not having similar legislation in Australia.

My colleague Senator Archer had listed in much greater detail-in fact, had incorporated in Hansard-many plant varieties to which Australian growers do not have access because of the absence of this type of legislation in this country. Senator Archer mentioned varieties of grape, nectarine, peach, cherry, plum, ornamental plants, rape seed, beans, peas, perennial rye-grass, sweet-corn, strawberries, apples and blackcurrents. As honourable senators will recall, the list takes up several pages of Hansard and there is no need for me to repeat it. These are the important plant varieties that we cannot get into Australia at the moment because of an absence of legislation of this kind.

I touched upon the working party of the Australian Agricultural Council which had listed many varieties of plants to which our growers do not have access. I was about to mention that the working party had little doubt that the list would grow if Australia did not have a PVR scheme and that Australian rural industries would be disadvantaged by lack of access to many of such commercial overseas varieties. Some gauging of the extent of such disadvantage is apparent from the fact that, to the end of 1980, the United States of America had granted protection to 774 varieties of 53 different seed propogated crops plus thousands of asexually propogated crops under its 1930 Plant Patent Act. I mention 1930 to indicate how long ago the United States moved to introduce legislation of this kind.

Agricultural crops in the United Kingdom to the end of 1978 were in excess of 424 varieties. There was a similar figure for decoratives and a further 58 fruit varieties. It is worth noting that, in April 1980, protection of the United Kingdom was in fact, extended to seven additional crops comprising beetroot, cauliflower, gooseberry, flax, linseed, rape seed and oenothera. In actual fact, in Britain at the moment we are seeing an extension of the varieties to which its plant protection legislation will apply. France has granted protection to 1, 177 varieties of 67 crops. Belgium has granted protection to 59 crops. In New Zealand, some 126 plant variety grants had been issued by September 1981.

In fact, a huge number of plant varieties are protected throughout the world. I have mentioned only half a dozen of the 25 countries to the varieties of which breeders in Australia do not have access because of the failure to implement similiar legislation in this country. I understand, in fact, that a recent survey by a senior member of the Victorian Department of Agriculture on the operation and effects of the New Zealand plant variety legislation-I remind honourable senators that it was introduced in 1973-has found that one of its main benefits has been the greatly increased in-flow of plant genetic material from many overseas sources.

On the last occasion I referred to the British plant controller, Mr Murphy. In his paper entitled 'Plant Breeders Rights and the Improvement of Plant Varieties ' he observed the improvements in pastoral and horticultural productivity derived from the introduction of plant varieties from overseas. It is interesting to note that in the early stages of the operation of the British Act in the United Kingdom companies were established to do nothing more than evaluate overseas bred varieties. Mr Murphy, however, noticed a change in commerical operations after some years. In his paper, he stated:

It is interesting that many of these companies which started off by introducing foreign varities developed their own specialised breeding programs and they are now producing varieties bred in the United Kingdom.
He continued:

Our experience, I think, is that only by establishing a plant breeders rights system do you actually encourage companies to even consider introducing varieties and investing any money in the evaluation of foreign varieties. This in turn can lead them to establish their own private breeding programs.

I have mentioned the number of plants and seed varieties currently registered in only a few of the 25 countries which have similar legislation. It would be naive for us not to accept that many seed varieties within that international bank would be adaptable and profitable in Australian conditions.

A number of concerns have been expressed about the Bill and it is, therefore, appropriate that I deal with the more significant of such concerns. The first is a fear that the legislation will detrimentally affect public breeding programs. Up to this point, research and development of new seed varieties in Australia have been principally carried out by the public breeding programs, State agricultural departments, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and, to a lesser extent, the universities. There is no reason why this Bill should have any effect whatsoever upon public expenditure on plant variety research.

As I have said, this Bill is attempting to attract a new source of investment funds. It is worth noting, however, that, given the Australian dependence on public moneys for research, there is always the danger of a reduction in funding allocations. To broaden the base of community financial support would appear to be wise. Overseas experience tends to support the view that the introduction of PVR is irrelevant to public plant breeding programs. In some countries, such as Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany and the Netherlands, there is more concentration on basic breeding research, handing this on to private breeders for possible commercial use. I thought that that fundamental research was the point that Senator Macklin was emphasising in his speech. In actual fact, in the countries I have just mentioned, that has occurred with PVR. That may not be a bad thing.

Professor Campbell, at a seminar in Canberra in 1977 on international genetics, referred to the failure of Australian wheat breeders substantially to increase yield rates. On the other hand, in countries such as the United States of America, South Africa and Switzerland there has been an increase in public breeding at the same time as they have had PVR. The experience in New Zealand would appear to indicate that public breeding organisations have welcomed PVR and are using them to obtain rights to many newly-developed varieties. According to a Department of Primary Industry information paper, a co-operative effort has been developed between public and private breeding organisations in New Zealand. I should think that Senator Macklin would applaud that. This touches upon a further reason why PVR should not cause concern to Australian public breeders. The reason is, of course, that the Bill in fact allows government funded agencies such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization to participate in the scheme. The development of new varieties by public breeding organisations will be eligible for registration under the Act. They will therefore be able to receive a return on the sale of their patented variety. Moreover, the public breeding programs will have the initial advantage over private commercial firms of having had a presence in Australia over many years and their expertise and knowledge of Australian conditions would give them a head start in research and development of new seed varieties.

The second concern expressed in relation to the Bill is the likelihood of the industry falling under oligopoly control, with consequent inferior quality, higher priced seeds flooding the market. The oligopolies are usually seen in the form of the dreaded multinational companies. Like any industry in a free market situation where rapid growth is occurring, there is always the chance of takeovers. However, I would stress to the Senate on this occasion the provisions in the Bill that provide that the registration authority has a charter to ensure that a reasonable supply of varieties is placed on the market at reasonable prices, so the concern expressed in this area is not well-founded. Poor quality seeds which are susceptible to disease or require substantial chemical inputs would not survive as a commercial proposition for very long. Those who raise this issue of quality and price tend to forget that only new varieties will be included in the scheme. If new varieties prove to be inferior or the price does not reflect their yield potential, farmers, horticulturalists and orchardists will not buy them. Existing seed varieties would therefore retain their competitive edge.

The third concern expressed is that the granting of plant variety rights is likely to lead to an increase in seed costs for farmers and gardeners. I remind the Senate of what the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has said on the matter. It has said that if increased private involvement in plant breeding results in the development of improved plant lines through time, and hence an improvement in plant productivity, then the net result will be a decline in the effective cost of seed; that is, the increase in the value of output from far better varieties will more than offset the increased cost of seed.

The final concern which has been mentioned is the impact on Third World countries of the granting of proprietary rights over new plant varieties in Australia. I find this concern difficult to understand. If indigenous varieties are replaced by new and more effective varieties, it appears to me to be to the benefit of lesser developed countries. If the existing product is more efficient , it simply will not be replaced. One of the great concerns of Third World countries is to develop as much as possible self-sufficiency in food production and new and efficient seed varieties. This is, therefore, an important step along that road.

The Bill is sensible and forward-looking. It will help to encourage a more competitive, efficient and productive plant breeding industry in Australia. There will always be reservations about innovative legislation in this country, even if it has successfully been utilised elsewhere for decades. But experience elsewhere shows that reservations changed to solid and positive support. Of the situation in New Zealand, Mr R. R. Heading, Principal Improvement Officer of the Plant Standards Branch of the Victorian Department of Agriculture, said:

I cannot help getting the feeling that in both Government and industry there is very great support for the whole concept of plant variety rights. Once in action the whole thing settles down and particularly the plant breeders are more than ever conscious of the need to maintain very high quality in the varieties they produce.

After a long wait this legislation will place Australia in step with the international plant breeding community. It will enable Australian plant breeders to gain better access to varieties previously denied them, and will provide consumers with a greater range of high quality fruits, vegetables and ornamental plants. It will contribute to ensuring that we are not left behind in a world of change.

The Bill now proceeds with the general support of the Australian Agricultural Council, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation , the Australian United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association and the Australian Seed Producers Association. The Bill deserves the whole-hearted support of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendement moved by Senator Walsh on behalf of the Opposition that the Plant Variety Rights Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committe on National Resources. The plant variety rights legislation before the Senate will enable plant breeders' organisations to obtain ownership or property rights over the seeds and cuttings of newly developed plant varieties. Patented seeds will remain the property of patent holders for a period of 15 years to 20 years. The owner of the new plant variety will have the power to determine who or which outlets will be able to sell the seeds of the new variety and to charge growers a royalty fee if they use the seeds. Not only will retail outlets need the authorisation of patent holders before selling patented seeds but also farmers who might wish to sell their neighbours a few bags of seed will be covered by the same law.

SPEECH.PARA: Industrial patents are a familiar example of a property right which allows patent holders to charge users royalties. The plant variety rights scheme however, differs from the industrial patents scheme in two ways: Plant patents will be able to be obtained from discoveries, and breeders will not have to make known to the public detail of the breeding and selection process that led to the new patented variety. The commercial consequences of plant variety patents go far beyond the control of seed sales and the inclusion of royalty fee in the price of seed. Companies holding plant patents can use their power to control the sale of seeds to stop independent seed producers-that is, farmers who grow seed for sale-from growing patented seed for sale on the open market.

The greatest impact of plant patents will be on the current free exchange of seed and genetic information. Just as normal research and development by companies is a closely guarded secret, so will genetic information become a similarly closely guarded secret because of this legislation. Right now with public breeding programs for public benefit there is a free flow of information and techniques. If patenting becomes law this flow will become one way-from the public sector to the private companies. I suggest-I can prove this assertion- that that flow will be from smaller companies to larger companies. I believe that seed prices will rise.

This restriction will flow on to the role of public seed breeders. It is inevitable that the expensive basic research will be pushed on to public bodies while the more lucrative exploitation of that research will be left to private enterprise. I disagree with Senator Hill on this point. Subsequently I will show where he is wrong in comparison with the major countries. Instead of proposing this Bill-this is where I disagree with Senator Hill-we should be extending the public programs to cover other crops. Some public breeders are opposed to plant variety rights. If the amendment moved by the Opposition is carried I hope that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources will hear from people such as Mr S. S. Gladstones, who is the principal plant breeder in the Western Australian Department of Agriculture. Mr Gladstones has strongly attacked plant variety rights. His view, as a plant breeder, is that public breeding programs are more efficient, and that interstate, let alone overseas, developed varieties will often be of little value and commercial breeding cannot do the job, firstly , because of the small size of the Australian seed market and, secondly, because plant variety rights encourage cosmetic rather than substantial changes. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a summary contained at page 11 of a paper prepared by Mr Gladstones entitled-'Western Australia's and Australia's plant breeding needs and likely effects of plant variety rights'.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
Summary

Improvement of crop and pasture plants by breeding is an outstanding and essential investment, both to the farming community and to the nation. Improvements in yield or quality due to breeding are normally without added cost to the producer, and are thus pure profit. Cost-benefit analysis indicates that there should be a greatly increased input into agricultural plant breeding and associated research.

Breeding and testing for Western Australia need to be done predominantly within Western Australia, in the environments where the varieties are to be grown. With diminishing exceptions, varieties bred elsewhere cannot be expected to give continuing improvements in yield and profitability for Western Australian farms.

Private or corporate breeding, under PVR, cannot be expected to do the required job in Western Australia or, for most of the important self-pollinating crops and pastures, in Australia as a whole. The commercial seed trade is, and will remain, too small to support any worthwhile breeding effort in these species on the basis of royalties from seed sales. What private breeding does take place will remain confined to limited parts of eastern Australia, and will be predominantly of the minimum-input, 'cosmetic' type.

If introduced, PVR will greatly reduce progress by public breeding by undermining the basis for collaboration among States and institutions, and by imposing extraneous requirements on public as well as private breeders to meet the special needs of PVR. Commercial lobbies can be expected to seek the reduction and perhaps eventual elimination of competition provided by public breeding programmes.

For most farmers in Australia, and for almost all farmers in Western Australia, no advantage of any sort can be demonstrated for PVR. Costly, major disadvantages are certain, especially in the long term.

It is therefore essential that PVR legislation, if introduced at all, be clearly confined to those crops (e.g. horticultural and ornamental) for which advantages to Australia can be proved. Cool-season annual crop and pasture plants should be explicitly and permanently excluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —A key factor in the debate over plant variety rights is the difference in farm techniques between Australia, Europe and the United States of America. Overseas farmers purchase new seed every season. Here farmers purchase a few bags of seed and build up their own seed stocks for future use. Because of this, one company-the Shell Oil Co.-will not come to Australia. The market is just too small. I wish to quote from a Mr G. J. Hollamby, who is a senior plant breeder at Roseworthy Agricultural College in South Australia. Mr Hollamby recently addressed the PVR issue in the context of the winter cereal industry. He stated that Australia could not have a domestic market sufficient to support even the present level of plant breeding compared with United Kingdom where 90 per cent of seed is purchased annually. In Australia less than 4 per cent of the crop is sown and then bought as seed. Even with heavy promotion Mr Hollamby considers that 20 per cent would be the maximum and that consequently accompanying legislation might be needed to compel farmers to buy seed.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Bill becomes law farmers will be presented with a multitude of cheaply bred, heavily promoted cosmetic varieties with little information on local suitability. The Government says that farmers are not fools, but no farmer can be expected to critically evaluate new varieties during the initial years when he is increasing seed. Still less can he quickly evaluate a pasture variety whose merit may depend on its ability to persist over many years. It is clear to backers of plant variety rights that the big oil companies and chemical multinationals such as Shell, which I have mentioned, would want to change the habits of Australian farmers, that is, to get farmers to buy seed from the company every year.

The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) referred to the long period of public debate which has taken place on the Bill. That length of time makes it even more inexcusable that there has been no economic evaluation of the impact of plant variety rights. In the only current economic study on plant variety rights by Mr David Godden of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture it is shown that plant variety rights is not needed economically. Mr Godden says that plant variety rights will not work unless Australian farming practices change substantially. Mr Godden, who won the Australian Agricultural Economics Society's masters prize for PVR, went on to say of small seed companies:
These firms tend to disappear after plant variety rights.

After an extensive study that was Mr Godden's view. So much for the Minister's claim that these firms will not be disadvantaged. Mr Godden points out a tendency to oligopoly. I struggle with that word. It is a difficult word to get my tongue around and it leaves a bad taste in my mouth as well. An oligopoly is an industry which is dominated by a few large transnational corporations. Finally Mr Godden concluded that the effect of plant variety rights will be to encourage imported varieties rather than domestic breeding.

To be patentable under the law new variety rights must be distinct, uniform and stable-distinct in that they are new and different from already identified varieties; uniform in that every plant of the variety must be much the same for the purposes of identification so that the PVR system is administratively possible; and stable in that the variety must maintain its uniformity over a number of generations. These distinct, uniform and stable characteristics, referred to in Europe as DUS provisions, are provisions which are based on distinctiveness. Breeders are forced to reduce characteristics that are not distinct-for example, characteristics of yield, disease resistance and product quality. I will again refer to Mr Gladstones who points out that English breeders, who have had experience under public sector breeding, have claimed that the rate of yield is halved after plant variety rights legislation is introduced. The characteristics that I am referring to have nothing to do with consumer needs. Increasingly it is genetic variety not uniformity that is seen as a solution to crop vulnerabilities. PVR would block off this as an alternative.

Perhaps the most sinister aspect of plant patents is that they are being pushed by huge multinational corporations which also have large interests in insecticides, fertilisers and other chemicals. I make no apology for criticising multinational companies such as Shell Oil, Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz because they are typical of the companies involved. There will be two problems. These companies will make sure that the seeds which develop are dependent on their chemicals. This has happened in the United States of America. The very size and concentration of the industry could endanger agricultural diversity. On page 221 of a report on overcoming world hunger by the Presidential Commission on world hunger in 1980 this was stated:

Closely interrelated with patenting laws are distressing trends within the seed industry. Patenting laws, strongly supported by some large seed companies, have encouraged concentration within the industry. The number of seed company takeovers particularly by large pesticide, fertilizer and drug companies, has increased dramatically over the last few years. This could well lead to oligopoly pricing and the potential that narrow economic self-interests will be determining the fate of humankinds common heritage-agricultural diversity.

This fear of oligopoly control is well founded. Figures from the United States Plant Protection Office show that at December 1979 in the United States three corporations held 80 per cent of patents on beans; four corporations held 45 per cent of patents on cotton; four corporations held 60 per cent of patents on lettuce; four corporations held 62 per cent of patents on peas; four corporations held 48 per cent of patents on soya beans; and four corporations held 69 per cent of patents on barley. So much for the market forces which were mentioned by government senators! The simple fact is that this does not exist. The anti-competitive aspects of this have already been brought before the European Court of the European Economic Community. Pricing activities of transnational seed companies or corporations have already led to protests in West Germany. West German farmers objected to paying 70 per cent more than French farmers for the same corn seed. In a significant test case on 14 November 1978 reported in the Common Market law reports, between Mr Eisele and the Institute of National Research Agronomy from France, the effect of the decision was to take away from Mr Eisele the ability to sell seed in Germany at any price . I would like to quote from that decision-page 442-because it sums up in the European context the development of these companies gaining control of the seed industry. It states:

Profit margins in recent years have enabled the largest of these private breeders to control or take over production or distribution of the varieties they exploit. On the world market this trend is reflected in the recent acquisition(s) by Sandoz, Ciba-Geigy, Shell and other groups of major holdings in large American breeders and, hence, in their European agents and subsidiaries , a further illustration of the interest which major international groups are showing in the seed industry.

The decision in the case I have referred to was appealed against this year and the European Commission upheld this movement of the people in Europe. Exclusive rights will be taken out of the European plant breeders rights as a result of that appeal being won by the people of Europe, preventing those multinational companies at this stage from engaging in the activities that they have been involved in.

The Bill provides for future inclusions of crops in the scheme to be made without reference to Parliament, only by assent of the Australian Agricultural Council. No species is specifically included in or excluded from the Bill. It is vital to realise that the scheme as passed could be extended to cover any crops without Parliament first being consulted. The Bill embodies that characteristic of other schemes in that merit is no criteria for receiving a patent. Plant variety rights will not be granted for varieties whose seeds or plants have previously been sold in Australia or have been on sale overseas for longer than four years, and in some cases six years. However, those provisions are easily circumvented. Minor physical changes can be made to existing varieties and patents can be applied for. These minor changes, plus strong promotion, can mean some company could have a winner, but I suggest the growers and the people will not benefit.

Clause 13 (2) extends plant variety rights to foreign residents and varieties developed overseas. The danger here is that non-Australian companies can take out patents on new varieties that they develop after taking advantage of research performed by public institutions such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, universities and departments of agriculture. The 1979 Senate inquiry into industrial research and development revealed that overseas corporations were taking out 90 per cent of Australian patents. The danger is that under this legislation the same thing would happen in this area of activity.

There is an increasing tendency overseas for companies involved in food processing to develop varieties more suited to their cultivation, harvesting and production methods than to eating. I am on the side of the eaters. People are entitled to make sure that the food process is not interfered with by these giant companies. This legislation is one more step in letting loose the profit motive in our agriculture in a devastating way. I have already mentioned Mr Godden's reference to oligopoly developing. As I have shown, oligopoly in the United States of America and Europe is synonmous with plant variety rights. Seed companies with chemical interests would tend to develop seeds that are dependent upon oil based pesticide coatings rather than being naturally pest resistant. Yet this is what plant variety rights encourages at great cost to the world, particularly the Third World's energy and economic future. I disagree strongly with Senator Hill on this matter. The simple facts are that these companies that I have referred to tonight are well known. In fact, they are infamous throughout the world.

Rather than regulating to push farmers down these damaging paths the Government should be doing all it can to encourage long-term ecologically stable agriculture. We may not pay the price for plant variety rights, but our children will unless we are very cautious. I believe with the controversy surrounding this matter that caution is best dealt with by referring this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources and making sure that the Australian people know more of the dangers behind this legislation. The genetic resources of our planet are our future, but they are falling more and more into private hands. According to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation one company, United Brands, controls two-thirds of the world's germ plasm of bananas. Plant variety rights is not the only cause of this depletion and concentration of genetic resources, but it is part of the process. It illustrates the problem that I referred to earlier.

There are many reasons why I think all Australians have a stake in this debate. The Opposition has proposed that this matter go before a Senate committee which allows the people to make their representations. People in all walks of life are concerned about this issue. I urge all honourable senators to support the amendment moved by Senator Walsh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1982 is long overdue. It is in the area of plant variety rights in Australia that lack of protection acting as a disincentive has become extremely pronounced. There are simply no incentives to produce new plant varieties. After all, why should a person devote time, energy and finance to developing new concepts and new products when, without the protection another may plagiarise and profit from that invention? That is graphically illustrated by the experience which the British have had in plant variety rights legislation. Over the last five years alone in England there has been a 500 per cent increase in private investment in plant breeding. In addition the number of private companies involved in plant breeding has increased from 10 in 1967, just after the introduction of the PVR legislation, to 23 currently.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for PVR legislation in Australia is, to say the least, in simple terms twofold. Firstly, it will provide a stimulus to private plant breeding by affording protection to new seed discoveries and, therefore, providing the incentive of profit for plant breeding. It is for this reason that in 1976 the Industries Assistance Commission report on financial rural research recommended- I refer honourable senators to paragraph 40-that the introduction of plant breeders rights be expedited. An example of the present lack of commercial interest in plant breeding was given recently by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture. In a statement made last year in reference to the breeding of open pollinated crops it noted that it would cost a breeder with all necessary equipment and supporting staff $100,000 a year. New plant varieties would take a minimum of five and sometimes up to 10 years to develop. Under these circumstances it is clear that without PVR legislation to protect new varieties private plant breeding will simply not grow in this country. The second need for plant variety rights legislation-in my view this shares equally in importantance with the first-stems from the desirability of Australian farmers and nurserymen being able to tap international seed breeding.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tax Deductibility of Donations to School Building Funds-Opening of the National Gallery-Standing Committe on Finance and Government Operations

PROCTEXT.PARA: Tax Deductibility of Donations to School Building Funds-Opening of the National Gallery-Standing Committe on Finance and Government Operations

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under the sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a question concerning the application by a voluntary non-profit body for status under section 78 (1) (a) ( xv) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which makes provision for the tax deductibility of gifts to the value of $2 and upwards made towards a public fund established and maintained exclusively for providing money for the acquisition, construction or maintenance of a building used or to be used as a school or a college by a government or public authority or by a society or association which is carried on otherwise than for the purposes of profit or gain to individual members of that society or association.

SPEECH.PARA: On 21 October 1981 such an association, namely, the Australian Association for Buddhist Studies Ltd, which is a public company limited by guarantee and registered under section 11 of the Companies Act 1961 and is a non-profit organisation, made application for the status of a school building fund pursuant to that section of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It wanted to establish an educational institution and the name of the fund was to be called the Tara Institute Building Fund. I do not wish to canvass the merits of this application or to prejudice the question of whether the proposed educational institution falls within the criteria set out in that secion of the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, I wish to make the point that the first application was first made to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Victoria on 21 October 1981. In that application the Association indicated in a broad way how the Tara Institute educational organisation would function. It indicated particularly that its senior teachers had been educated in the traditional education system of Tibet in monasteries and monastic institutions. Some telephone conversation and correspondence has taken place between the Australian Association for Buddhist Studies and the Taxation Office. Letters have flowed on 13 April 1982 and as recently as 5 August 1982 providing clarification to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in relation to certain queries and matters raised by the gift assessor in relation to this application.

My simple point is that, without prejudicing the outcome of this matter, one would have hoped that in the 11 months since the original application by this institute for tax deductibility of its building fund some resolution of the matter might have been reached. To a certain extent it does not matter whether the answer is yes or no, though I would hope the answer will be yes. But certainly it is required so that donors may contribute to the fund with the knowledge that any substantial donation they may wish to make will attract the tax deductibility provided for in the Income Tax Assessment Act. After 11 months the need is becoming urgent for certainty in this matter so that the building program may proceed. I simply ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) whether he would be so kind as to follow up this matter with a view to getting a reasonably speedy answer.

I would like to bring up one other small matter before Senator Peter Rae rises to speak. During the week I and other senators received an invitation to attend the opening by Her Majesty the Queen of the National Gallery in October.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Wilderness Society? Did you receive that invitation?
—To tonight's festivities? Yes, but unfortunately I had another engagement outside of the Parliament.
—But perhaps you might like to talk about the importance of it .

—I wish to direct my remarks at the moment to the importance of this highlight of our social and cultural life in Australia, namely, the opening of the National Gallery. As I said, all honourable senators received an invitation. For those who are currently in the married state the invitation was addressed to the senator and wife or husband, as the case may be. In other words , it was an invitation to the senator and spouse. In the case of those eight senators who are not in the bliss of the married state at the moment, no such invitation to be accompanied by a guest, companion or partner was extended. I asked my office to make an inquiry as to why this was so. A phone call was made to the RSVP phone number on the invitation and a secretary said that she and the National Gallery were highly embarrased by the situation but had been instructed by the Government that the invitations were to go out in this manner. I should like to know who within the Government gave this direction which is so discriminatory and unfair in its impact on those senators who normally attend such functions in the company of a partner or a companion. Certainly, those who attend without a partner or companion will feel singled out in this situation. It is an important social and cultural highlight of our national life and I should like somebody to take it up, to find out who within the Government gave the direction to the National Gallery to that effect, with a view to reprimanding that person and to getting the direction reversed.

—I wish to speak very briefly in relation to the meeting today of the Cattle Council of Australia in Queensland and certain challenges reported extensively in the media-made to me and my Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in relation to something rather elusive so far as the exact nature of the challenge was concerned. I make publicly a plea that people who wish to make challenges, or otherwise refer to the operation of Senate committees, should kindly make known to the people concerned the nature of the challenge before, or at least contemporaneously with, the publication of it to the media. This challenge appeared on almost every section of radio news broadcasts that have taken place today.
—I think you have had this trouble with that body before.

—Yes. I recently had occasion to write to the publication known as the Cattleman, a monthly journal published by the Cattlemen's Union of Australia which has amongst other contributors a Mr John Carter who just happened to get things about as fouled up as one could possibly get them. He made a vitriolic attack upon a Senate committee, without justification, which is factually inaccurate. He was forced, as a result of the letter which was written , to apologise rather pathetically to that Committee for having totally and absolutely misrepresented what the Committee had done. But it suited his vitriolic purpose-I refrain from going further-to misrepresent what had been stated and to apologise in a most abstruse way at the bottom of his column. All I can say is that in due course in the courts he will find that that apology was totally inadequate. The point I raise tonight is that I think there is a need to make clear that if the parliamentary system of Australia-the democratic system of Australia-is to operate we need to have a little co-operation instead of a stand-off. It does not enhance the operation of the system to hear through the media that challenges have been thrown out in some way to some parliamentary committee to do something unspecified, unknown and never requested. I think that is probably as far as I should go this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been three contributions to the adjournment debate tonight. Senator Rae indicated in his contribution that there may be some legal action flowing from some of the things which were said. On that basis I do not wish to take up any of the substance of the matters, except to make the observation that he was asking for courtesy in dealings between people. I think all honourble senators would acknowledge the force and the correctness of that request. Senator Tate raised two matters. The reason I am in the chamber, of course, is that word went out that the first matter concerned a school. I think the honourable senator will recognise that although the matter possibly concerns a school, it is not a matter for the Minister of Education. It is, in fact, a matter which relates to activities of the Treasurer (Mr Howard).

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator's point in relation to the Australian Association for Buddhist Studies is a perfectly proper point-that is, there is a matter before the Government requiring a decision. Eleven months have passed and no decision has emerged. The honourable senator asked that a decision be forthcoming. It is my belief that my colleague, the Treasurer, would be most anxious to have no delay in any matters of this kind requiring action from within his Department. I will undertake to place the matter before him. I hope that we can get an answer for the honourable senator. I make only one comment. One of the tests we apply in my Department in relation to certain matters concerning schools is that they should be registerable in a State. It may or may not be that that is an issue but, as I said, I will put the matter before the Treasurer and see where it takes us.

I understand the point made by Senator Tate in relation to the opening of the National Gallery. I am aware that some honourable senators and honourable members of the Parliament who are not married make use of the position of official nominee. An official nominee can be designated by an honourable senator or an honourable member and in many circumstances the official nominee is included on invitations. I do not know-Senator Tate may not know or he may have omitted to say-whether official nominees have been included.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just the senator.

—They have not been included. I understand the honourable senator's point. I know that there is enormous pressure upon the available spaces at the opening. I do not know how decisions have been taken, as to who-
—I will not be there; so I will forgo my extra seat for Senator Tate.

—I do not know how invitations have or have not been offered . Senator Tate asked that the matter be referred to the appropriate Minister. I will undertake to have his request passed on to see whether we can obtain an early answer to the matter which he has raised.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.14 p.m.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total number of hours of Australian Broadcasting Commission television drama produced in each of the financial years ending: (a) 30 June, 1975; (b) 30 June, 1976; (c) 30 June, 1980; and (d) 30 June, 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what way is the impact of existing FM stations in Melbourne being assessed.
(2) Who is doing such an assessment.
(3) When will it be completed.
(4) Will the results be released.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An assessment of the impact of existing FM stations in Melbourne will be undertaken when Phase I of the development of FM public broadcasting has been substantially completed. Phase I is defined in the Ministerial Statement of 5 April 1978 as ''the period from the present to that point at which engineering studies on multiple FM transmissions allow a definite assessment of frequency availability to be made. The intention is that this Phase should be as short as is consistent with proper caution in planning and Phase II will be announced as soon as possible.''
(2) The assessment will be carried out by my Department.
(3) Phase I is not yet completed. The assessment is continuous, but no date has been set for completion.
(4) Yes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When can Senator Evans expect a reply to his Question No. 1768 placed on the Notice Paper on 16 February 1982.

(3) Does the Government propose to provide, as anticipated in that communication, 'further clarification in relation to the reservation regarding article 10' and 'a more detailed insight' in relation to the reservation regarding 'Convicted Persons'.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Centre for the Independence of Judges and Lawyers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government investigated allegations by the Centre for the Independence of Judges and Lawyers (CIJL) of Geneva concerning the repression of lawyers in Iran, specifically that the Iranian Government-
(a) in June 1980 prevented the Bar Association of Teheran from holding its internal elections;
(b) in May 1981 occupied the Bar Association's offices by force, confiscating its archives, library and funds;
(c) on 30 January 1982 arrested the President, Secretary and other members of the Bar Council; and
(d) has executed lawyers, for example Mohammad Reza Khasar Baktiari, and Mohsen Jahandar, for having defended persons on trial in revolutionary tribunals; if not, will the Government do so?
(2) What action has the Minister for Foreign Affairs taken, or does he propose to take, in respect of such repression.
(3) Is the Government aware of allegations by the CIJL concerning-
(a) the arrest of the President of the Istanbul Bar Association, Mr Apaydin;
(b) infringements on the professional and personal freedom of lawyers in Turkey ;
(c) restrictions on Defence Attorneys, particularly in representing real or suspected opponents of the Turkish Government;

(d) the erosion of fundamental legal rights in Turkey by means such as detention without charge, prosecution for activities prior to the September 1980 coup which were legal under the existing law of that time, and the holding of mass trials.
(4) Has the Government noted the irregularities in respect of the trial in Turkey of 52 leaders of the DISK trade union federation, apparently an attempt to destroy this 500,000 member organisation.
(5) What action has the Government taken or does it propose to take, in respect of the matters referred to in paragraphs 3 and 4.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government has attempted to investigate allegations concerning the position of lawyers in Iran raised in the first part of the honourable senator's question.

It has not so far been possible to obtain confirmation of all the specific allegations listed by the Centre for the Independence of Judges and Lawyers. I understand, however, that lawyers and the Bar Association in Iran have been under considerable pressure for at least the past twelve months and that the Bar Association has been evicted from its offices in Teheran.

The Australian Government will continue to seek further information on developments relating to the status of lawyers in Iran and will consider what action might be appropriate in the light of whatever further information is obtained.
(3) (a)-(d) Yes. The Australian Government is aware of the allegations by the Centre for the Independence of Judges and Lawyers relating to the situation of lawyers in Turkey.

(4) The Australian Embassy in Ankara is monitoring the trial of the leaders of the Revolutionary Trade Union confederation (DISK). An official from the Embassy recently attended a session of the trial in Istanbul. While some aspects of the trial give the Government cause for concern, the trial would appear to be following properly constituted procedures.

(5) The Government has on three occasions in the Parliament this year expressed its serious concern at the human rights situation in Turkey. The Australian Embassy in Ankara has also made representations to the Turkish Government, as have officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra. These representations have stressed that human rights can only be effectively guaranteed by the restoration of civilian rule, and have also brought to the attention of the Turkish Government the concern expressed in the Australian Parliament. The Government will continue to make its views known to the Turkish Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the latest figures from the Australian Electoral Office show that habitation reviews ceased in Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania in July 1981 and is it reported that they have now ceased in the other three States.
(2) Does this mean that the current enrolment figures for Federal divisions are inadequate and unclear from the point of view of accuracy and equity.
(3) Is this change of procedure a change in Government policy or a process arising from cutbacks in public sector expenditure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. In 1981-82 there was a limit to the funds which could be applied to the various operations of the Australian Electoral Office and habitation review activity was reduced. No reviews were conducted in Queensland and Tasmania and percentage reviews only were conducted in New South Wales (67 per cent), Victoria (75 per cent), Western Australia (32 per cent) and South Australia (36 per cent).

(2) No. Recent State elections in the joint roll States of New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania generated considerable enrolment activity and the follow- up by the relevant State Electoral Offices of non-voters at those elections assisted in the roll cleansing process. In Queensland the State Electoral Office has been conducting a roll canvass and is providing the Australian Electoral Office with the information obtained. It must also not be forgotten that whatever additional roll maintenance activities are undertaken by the Electoral Office, the final responsibility for being correctly enrolled rests with each individual elector.
(3) No. Funds have been provided in the 1982-83 budget to enable a full habitation review to be undertaken in all States and Territories this financial year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Inquiry into Teacher Education Committee

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Commonwealth Department of Education's response to the recommendations of the National Inquiry into Teacher Education Committee's report on Aboriginal education.

(2) What steps is the Department of Education taking to provide programmes designed specifically for Aboriginal people and which aim to facilitate Aboriginal people's access to tertiary qualifications in such areas as teaching.
(3) What progress can the Minister for Education report in response to such programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Education endorses the need, identified in the Committee' s report, to improve access to teacher education courses by Aboriginals who are a seriously under-represented group at the present time.

(2) The Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme (Abstudy), administered by my Department , facilitates the access of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to post- school education and training, including teacher education at tertiary institutions. It does so primarily by the provision of student allowances which have contributed in large measure to the increase in numbers of Aboriginal students undertaking tertiary study in recent years. In 1975 the number of Abstudy grantholders in tertiary institutions was 163. By 1980 this number had risen to 1003, a significant increase.

In addition, the Department makes a contribution to a number of educational and training programs specifically designed to meet the needs of Aboriginal people, through the payment of course fees on behalf of grantholders. Some of these special course programs have provided Aboriginals with access to tertiary education and have taken the form of
Bridging courses which enable Aboriginals to improve their education and gain admission to normal tertiary education courses.

Programs which provide special counselling and tutoring services, and other support staff to assist Aboriginals in courses leading to standard qualifications. These programs may also include special arrangements regarding admission requirements and course structure.
In 1981-82 approximately $200,000 was allocated in this way to assist tertiary institutions mount special teacher education programs for Aboriginals.
(3) The following table shows the number of Abstudy grantholders enrolled in full-time teacher education courses at tertiary institutions in the years 1975 to 1980:
No. of Year

Growth in enrolments is still limited by the relatively small number of Aboriginal students completing secondary education. However, there are signs of improvement in Aboriginal retention rates in secondary school which could provide a basis for increased enrolments in tertiary institutions in the future.

(See Question No. 1661, Senate Hansard, 18 May 1982, page 2073).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's decision on this matter was taken specifically in the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and related only to the 1982-84 triennium.

The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission examined the question of a university in the Northern Territory over the longer term, and its recommendations encompassed other tertiary education matters. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Department of Health indicate in its Circular MB No. 239 of June 1981 that larger health benefit organisations were required to hold reserves equivalent to two months of contribution income, while smaller organisations would be required to have reserves equivalent to four months of contribution income; if so, is Medibank Private satisfying those requirements in each State and has it done so since its establishment in October 1976; if not, what action is the Department of Health taking to ensure that Medibank Private satisfies the Government's requirements in relation to reserves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Health Circular MB No. 239/HB No. 158 did not require that larger health benefit organisations hold reserves equivalent to two months' contribution income and smaller organisations to hold reserves equivalent to four months' contribution income. The Circular recognised that some organisations could have inadequate reserves and advised that in the circumstances of the industry, it would not seem generally practicable to achieve in those cases a rapid build-up of reserves. Accordingly, organisations were advised that there would be no objection to their incorporating components in proposed contribution rates to achieve a build-up over time. For larger organisations, reserves equivalent to two months' contribution income would be acceptable and for smaller organisations the target would be equivalent to four months' contribution income.

Since its inception, Medibank Private has achieved a level of reserves in accordance with the above-mentioned guidelines in the State of Victoria only. A review of the operations of Medibank Private was recently undertaken by an interdepartmental committee, which, among other things, commented on the reserves position of Medibank Private. In due course, I shall be reporting to the Government on the committee's findings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Do representatives of the Australian Chemical Industry Council have contact with the Minister for Health, his staff, and officers of his Department and bodies under his control; if so, what has been the nature and frequency of that contact since January, 1977.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not recall any contact with the Australian Chemical Industry Council (ACIC ). However, my Department does have contact with ACIC. Several past and present members of National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC) committees in the occupational health and industry liaison areas are, or have been, members also of ACIC. The NH and MRC is a body under my control and the secretariats for its committees are provided by my Department. The NH and MRC committees usually meet at least twice yearly, and considerable interchange of information has therefore occurred between the two Councils.

ACIC provides representatives at meetings of various committees of the Standards Association of Australia (SAA) at which may be officers representing my Department. ACIC once approached my Department concerning the use of Departmental computing facilities for information on hazardous chemicals. Otherwise contact has been limited, with ACIC seeking emergency information for enquiries to the National Poisons Information Service. My Department has also approached ACIC for assistance in contacting manufacturers who may handle a particular chemical or class of chemical.

Because of the professional interests of Departmental officers and members of ACIC, association at national and international meetings occurs when topics of common interest are being discussed. Similarly, correspondence and telephone discussions on scientific issues are not infrequent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: In the 12 months to 30 June 1982, for each Federal electoral division, how many marriage registrations were notified to the Commonwealth Electoral Officer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Marriage of itself imposes no obligation to change enrolment details and no statistics of any roll changes consequent upon marriage are maintained by the Divisional Returning Officer.

The State Government Registrars, on a regular basis, provide the Australian Electoral Office with details of marriage registrations, although not all notifications relate to enrolled electors. Where appropriate, the Divisional Returning Officer writes to the wife in the following terms:
'One of my most important responsibilities is to keep the electoral roll for this Division up-to-date, and I have now been advised of your recent marriage.

You may now prefer to enrol under your husband's surname, or you may wish to remain on the roll or become enrolled under your maiden name. The choice is yours. To adjust your enrolment, if this is necessary, would you please fill in the enclosed electoral claim card and return it to the address on the top of this letter. A post free envelope is enclosed.

If you are not now living at the address to which this letter has been sent you will need to register any permanent change of address on the electoral roll. If this is the case, would you please fill in the claim card. It is compulsory to register any change of address within 21 days of becoming qualified to enrol at your new address.
The card can therefore be used to change your address and, if you wish, to change your name.
In case there are any changes required to your husband's enrolment details I have enclosed an additional claim card. Cards are also available at all electoral offices and post offices.
You are entitled to enrol only if you are an Australian citizen or other British subject.'

The Special Organising Committee for ASIAD '82 is headed by Sardar Buta Singh, Minister of State for Shipping and Transport, assisted by K. T. Satarawala, Vice Chairman and Coordinator for ASIAD '82, and Mr K. Sankaran Nair, Secretary-General, ASIAD '82. The Special Organising Committee for ASIAD '82 is located at 1, Pragati Maidan, New Delhi. In turn, the SOC has established a steering committee headed by the Union Minister for Education and Culture, Mr S. B. Chavan, to implement SOC decisions.

(8) The Host Government is responsible for funding the Games. With arrangements for succeeding Games being decided upon during the preceding Games and as the Asian Games Federation, as such, does not have a permanent address, there would not appear to be any financial support between each Asian Games.
In respect to questions 9-14, the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following information:
(9) to (14) To our knowledge, the Australian Government has never received an invitation to compete in any of the Asian Games that have been conducted since the inception of the Games in 1951.

The Australian Olympic Federation (which is responsible for the organisation of Australian Olympic teams) has approached the Asian Games organisers at past International Olympic Committee (IOC) meetings on behalf of one or two of its member sports, on the possibility of these Australian sports competing in the Asian Games. On each occasion, the AOF has received a negative response as the organisers do not regard Australia as being part of the Asian region. (The IOC regards Australia as being part of the Oceania region.)
Based on this advice, it would appear unlikely that any Australian sporting teams would be permitted or invited to compete in future Asian Games.

The report of the Interdepartmental Committee on Economic Strategy referred to one way of measuring the tax burden, namely, taxation as a proportion of GDP.

In his statement of 21 August 1981, the Prime Minister used a different measure of the burden imposed by Government on the community, namely, a combination of income tax and the burden of the deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1159) Senator Macklin asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Can the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology inform the Senate whether the Government has cut from $50m to $33.3m the funding to more than 120 Australian companies for industrial research and development?
(2) Can the Minister inform the Senate of the types of projects which will be affected by the funding cuts?
(3) Can the Minister confirm that such technology will have to be imported and paid for by Australian exports if technology is not developed in Australia?

During a reply which I gave to a similar question which I received from Senator Townley on 25 March 1981, I drew Senator Macklin's attention to a very detailed answer and explanation given in relation to this matter by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle on 24 March 1982.
The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following additional answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) A full reply to this question was provided by the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, in her reply to a question from Senator Watson . The reply appears at page 1095 of the Hansard of 24 March 1982.

(2) I am unable to provide specific details concerning industrial research and development projects for which companies are seeking grants as this information is confidential to those companies and is covered by the secrecy provisions of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976. However, the projects referred to by the honourable senator would relate to products and processess extending across a broad spectrum of manufacturing, mining and construction industries.

(3) There is no simple substitutional relationship between Government supported industrial research and development and the procurement of technology from overseas, particularly as market forces provide a strong inducement to companies in Australia to keep abreast of developments in technology occuring overseas and to adapt that technology, as necessary, to local production circumstances. However, I would point out that it is the long term effect which must be considered in this situation. The limitation on further commitment to project grants to which the honourable senator refers is essentially a current situation relative to the operations of the IR&D Incentives Scheme this financial year. The Incentives Act was amended in June 1981 and the Government then reaffirmed its commitment to providing this form of encouragement to industry by extending the life of the Act for a further five years. As pointed out by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in her earlier reply to Senator Watson, funding levels will be determined in the 1982-83 Budget context in the light of the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's report on certain budgetary assistances to industry and the Government's obligation to provide funding under existing agreements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1574) Senator Button asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is it not a fact that when the proposal to establish a select committee to inquire into the sale of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory came before the Senate there was not one vote in the Senate dissenting from that proposition?

(2) Is it not also a fact that in November of last year-before the committee had been established-the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, whom Senator Chaney represents, wrote to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory Area Committee saying that the establishment of a Senate Committee would result in difficulties in selling the factory?

A proposal to lease the factory was subsequently examined but the Government considered it did not meet its requirements or its commitment to the people of Bendigo. On 7 July 1982 the Government announced that the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo would not be sold or leased and would be retained as a Government operated factory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1565) Senator Button asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Has the Government has decided to call offers for the sale or lease of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.
(2) Has the Government tried unsuccessfully on two occasions over the past 12 months to sell the factory?

(3) Does the Government not appreciate the further uncertainty that will be created amongst employees of the factory and the population of Bendigo by the prospect of the establishment being leased?
