TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1982, (Hansard, page 1572) Senator Primmer asked me the following question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that there has been and still is a waiting period of six months for people applying for Australian citizenship? Is the bulk of this delay-that is, four months-due to the time taken by the police doing security checks of applicants? If so, will the Government take the action necessary to shorten this inordinate delay which has caused and is causing problems for the applicants?
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The current average national processing time between date of receipt of an application for Australian citizenship until date of decision (approval or refusal) is 22 weeks. On average a further six weeks elapses for conferral of citizenship at a Departmental ceremony. Public ceremonies are conducted by local government authorities and the waiting period for these ceremonies varies considerably according to the size of the municipality and number of conferrals undertaken by the particular authority.

Several initiatives have been taken to reduce bottlenecks and to streamline processing procedures generally. These include a joint review of citizenship procedures conducted by the Public Service Board and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The recommendations of that review are currently under consideration. The time taken for completion of penal checks by the Australian Federal Police has been significantly reduced and the average turnaround period for these checks is currently three weeks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1574), Senator Kilgariff asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs a question without notice on the current situation in regard to the reunification of Timorese families in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Since this matter falls within the portfolio of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, he has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In addition to normal migrant entry (including family reunion provisions), successive arrangements providing for re- laxed migrant entry of East Timorese into Australia have been made since 1975. Of these, the East Timor Special Humanitarian program (SHP) and the special family reunion list program are still current.

The SHP provides for those East Timorese whose lives were disrupted by the events of 1975 and who are living temporarily outside East Timor on 30 September 1980 and experiencing settlement difficulties to be reunited with their relatives in Australia; to date 1,800 people have arrived in Australia or have been approved for entry under this arrangment. Another 800 persons currently in Portugal may qualify under this program.
The family reunion list program resulted in 359 people arriving in Australia by the end of June 1982 but progress has been slow.

Recently, through the involvement of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), progress is being achieved. The Indonesian Government has agreed to resumption of processing of remaining persons on the list by this international agency as a humanitarian gesture. The ICRC is tracing the remaining list members, identifying those who wish to travel to Australia, assisting in the processing of movement to Australia, and obtaining the necessary exit permits.
The first group of 10 persons processed under these new arrangements arrived in Australia on 9 July 1982 and were reunited with their families.
The Government hopes that with the co-operation of the ICRC and the Indonesian authorities the program can be finalised as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1815) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether Australian support for the British attempt to regain possession of the Falkland Islands was conditional on the observance of a declared 200-mile zone around the Falkland Islands area. I ask, in search of information I might say by way of explanation: Was the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano within that 200-mile limit at the time it was sunk? Secondly, was it in fact positioned between the 200-mile zone or the perimeter of that zone and the Argentine coast? Thirdly, has the Government any information on whether there is truth in the allegation, and indeed the boast, by some representatives of the British government that the United Kingdom forces had been seeking to entice the General Belgrano into the 200-mile zone for several days but that the vessel had failed to succumb to those enticements at the time it was sunk?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Australian support for Britain in the Falkland Islands dispute was not conditional on observance of a declared 200-mile zone around the Falklands.
The exact position of the Argentine vessel, the General Belrano, at the time it was sunk is a matter of dispute between Britain and Argentina.

The British Government has stated that the General Belgrano was posing a direct threat to the British task force and that the action taken against the General Belgrano was fully consistent with the duty of the British task force to defend its ships and men.

So far as allegations that representatives of the British Government had said that United Kingdom forces had been seeking to entice the General Belgrano into the 200-mile zone are concerned I have not previously heard of these, nor have I information bearing on the truth of this matter.
At the time, the Australian Prime Minister expressed concern about the loss of life involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1818) Senator Chipp asked me, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, without notice, a supplementary question:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate or the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs a supplementary question arising from the Minister's answer. I specifically asked whether the Government would intercede and use its good offices with the United States of America to make representations to both sides on this question? The Minister has said that the Government has taken every step and is taking every step that it can. Does that include representations to the United States as I asked in my earlier question?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following additional information in response to the honourable senator's question:

As the Prime Minister has stated, the Australian Government has been in close touch with the United States in relation to the Falklands situation. For example, the matter was discussed with Vice President Bush during his visit to Australia and again during the Prime Minister's visit to Washington on 17 May. The Prime Minister said after these discussions that there was no divergence of views between Australia and the United States over the Falklands. The Government supported the mediation efforts of Secretary of State Haig. It expressed disappointment that these efforts did not result in agreement and paid tribute to the role the Secretary of State had played.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2012) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services by saying that no doubt he will remember the statement made by Mr Newman during the last week that some politicians in this country are associated with criminal activities. As this statement places all politicians under a cloud-I believe this is something Senator Jessop mentioned recently, and I and many other politicians do not appreciate it one little bit- will the Minister advise the Senate of the names of those politicians thought to be so associated? If not, can he say whether the Minister meant State politicians or Federal politicians?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It would seem to be an important aspect of organised crime, based on overseas experience, that to ensure its survival and growth, organised crime elements seek to infiltrate or influence legitimate business and public activities.

Dr Alfred McCoy, lecturer at the University of New South Wales, referred, in his book Drug Traffic-Narcotics and Organised Crime in Australia, to a number of disturbing instances of close relationships between organised crime figures and influential politicians in recent decades.
To effectively tackle the problems posed by organised crime, the possibility- however unlikely it may seem-of infiltration or corruption needs to be recognised and faced up to.

It cannot be assumed that a certain group is necessarily beyond infiltration or corruption. In this regard, the steadfast denial that it could not happen to a particular group in the community, be they businessmen, politicians or others , may be a costly delusion resulting in an incomplete, and perhaps therefore ineffectual, strategy for tackling organised crime.
My comments to which the honourable member has referred were made in this context.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1982, (Hansard, page 2495) Senator Missen asked Senator Durack, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Government confirm its commitment to Australia's many export traders through the continuation of the export development grant and export expansion grant schemes; and secondly, what long term policies does the Government have to encourage exporters to seek long term business and to maintain Australia's viability as a trading nation?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The Government has recently announced its decision on the future of export incentives. I refer the honourable senator to my media release of 19 July 1982 in which I set out the details. Legislation to give effect to the changes will be introduced shortly.
(2) The Government has acted consistently to provide the sound and stable economic climate essential for the development of efficient export oriented industries.

The Government is also committed to provide direct help to exporters. The trade promotion budget for 1981-82 was over $6m. Some 1,000 Australian firms participated in overseas trade fairs, displays and exhibitions, and my Department organised and funded several overseas and inwards trade missions. A trade promotion program of similar magnitude has been approved for the current financial year. The export finance facility of the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation assists the sale of Australian capital goods and related services. Australian firms continue to use the services of Australian trade commissioners in some 54 locations overseas. These efforts are bearing fruit in markets for Australian exporters and they will continue. Less visible but of equal importance are the Government's efforts to seek to achieve improvements in the international trading environment which Australian exporters must face. Consultations and negotiations by ministers and officials are undertaken continuously with our trading partners to safeguard our interests and to gain further benefits for our exporters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 August 1982 (Hansard, page 106) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the National Kangaroo Management Program and the possible variation of States' culling targets following completion of a review of the program.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The State Wildlife Authorities may request quotas different from those set in 1982 and consequently I am unable to give an assurance that the quotas will not be changed. However, I can assure Senator Mulvihill that the quotas will be set on the basis of the latest available scientific and other relevant information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 August 1982 (Hansard, page 103) Senator Macklin asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the increase in the disease eradication component of the livestock slaughter levy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

For a number of years the cattle industry has been meeting 70 per cent of the operating costs of the eradication campaign. In 1975 and again in 1982 the campaign was the subject of Industries Assistance Commission reports which confirmed that the major beneficiary of the campaign was the cattle industry and that the industry should meet the major costs. Where there have been shortfalls in the funds provided for the campaign by the industry the Commonwealth Government has met these by making loan advances. At 30 June 1982 the total of these advances plus interest amounted to $23.5m.
Recognising the current financial difficulties faced by the industry the Government has agreed to write-off this substantial amount thus relieving the industry of a considerable burden.

The funds raised through the previous $3 per head levy have not kept pace with the actual operating costs of the campaign and this has been exacerbated by the reduction in the number of animals coming forward for slaughter in recent months. To meet the costs of the campaign and to prevent a similar large debt in the future of Government has decided it is necessary to increase the levy from $3 to $4 per head.

However, the Government recognises that there are particular problems facing marginal pastoral properties especially in the northern areas of Australia. In order to develop a specific program for these areas and to accelerate, if possible, the current programs, the Government supported the setting up by the Australian Agricultural Council of two special groups. These are charged with the urgent task of preparing a comprehensive national and operational administrative plan, including funding requirements for finally eradicating brucellosis and tuberculosis. The groups will give particular attention to the special problems of northern Australia and will recommend what further funding may be necessary to achieve success for the campaign and how any additional funding may be met.

The Government has also agreed to lift its share of the net compensation payable for animals slaughtered for tuberculosis to 75 per cent from the end of the present arrangements bringing it into line with brucellosis provisions.

The increase in the disease eradication component of the livestock slaughter levy is not seen as a deterrent to the continued participation in the eradication scheme by marginal pastoral properties. The groups developing the future national eradication plan will be studying the situation of those properties experiencing special financial and managemental difficulties in following an individual property eradication plan and will be making recommendations on what, if any, additional assistance such properties may require.

Because it will be the major beneficiary from the eradication of these diseases the Government believes that the cattle industry should continue to fund a substantial share of the operational costs. However, the Government will study closely the recommendations coming forward from the National BTEC Planning Group to ensure the ultimate success of the campaign.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1982 (Hansard, page 391) Senator Townley asked me a question about cloud seeding.

ANSWER.PARA: I have received the following information about the question from the Minister for Science and Technology:

I am advised by the Minister for Science and Technology that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has ended its cloud seeding research program. A statement to this effect was made on 28 October 1981.
CSIRO will maintain expertise in cloud physics and provide advice to State authorities and other people using the cloud seeding technique for drought relief and other purposes.
The decision is based on scientific evidence and increasing costs.

In August 1979 the CSIRO Division of Cloud Physics commenced a five year cloud seeding experiment to be conducted in western Victoria, in collaboration with the Victorian Department of Agriculture, subject to a review to be carried out at the end of the second year of the project.
The experiment aimed to increase the rainfall in the Warracknabeal area by seeding suitable clouds with silver iodide smoke spread from aircraft.

However, meteorological data obtained during the two seasons of the experiment indicated that the number of opportunities for cloud seeding was far less than previously anticipated, and that no statistically significant result could be obtained during the remaining three years of the experiment.

The paucity of genuine seeding opportunities, combined with the fact that the cost of hiring light aircraft is increasing at a much faster rate than the price of wheat, made it evident that economic benefit to Australian agriculture would be unlikely to result from the experiment.
CSIRO and the Victorian Department of Agriculture therefore agreed to terminate the experiment.
